Any individual may for compensation prepare or assist with the preparation of a tax return or claim for refund, appear as a witness for a taxpayer before the IRS, or furnish information at the request of the IRS or any of its officers or employees.

The following individuals are subject to the Regulations contained in Circular 230. However, any individual who is authorized generally to practice (a recognized representative) must be designated as the taxpayer's representative and file a written declaration with the IRS stating that he or she is authorized and qualified to represent a particular taxpayer. Form 2848 can be used for this purpose.

Any individual who prepares appraisals supporting the valuation of assets in connection with one or more federal tax matters is subject to the regulations contained in Circular 230. Appraisers have no representation rights but may appear as witnesses on behalf of taxpayers.

Because of their special relationship with a taxpayer, the following individuals may represent the specified taxpayers before the IRS, provided they present satisfactory identification and, except in the case of an individual described in (1) below, proof of authority to represent the taxpayer. 1. An individual. An individual can represent himself or herself before the IRS and does not have to file a written declaration of qualification and authority. 2. A family member. An individual can represent members of his or her immediate family. Immediate family includes a spouse, child, parent, brother, or sister of the individual. 3. An officer. A bona fide officer of a corporation (including a parent, subsidiary, or other affiliated corporation), association, or organized group can represent the corporation, association, or organized group. An officer of a governmental unit, agency, or authority, in the course of his or her official duties, can represent the governmental unit, agency, or authority before the IRS. 4. A partner. A general partner can represent the partnership before the IRS. 5. An employee. A regular full-time employee can represent his or her employer. An employer can be, but is not limited to, an individual, partnership, corporation (including a parent, subsidiary, or other affiliated corporation), association, trust, receivership, guardianship, estate, organized group, governmental unit, agency, or authority. 6. A fiduciary. A fiduciary (trustee, executor, personal representative, administrator, receiver, or guardian) stands in the position of a taxpayer and acts as the taxpayer, not as a representative. See Fiduciary under When Is a Power of Attorney Not Required , later.

Any individual may represent an individual or entity, who is outside the United States, before personnel of the IRS when such representation also occurs outside the United States. See section 10.7(c)(1)(vii) of Circular 230.

Any CPA who is not currently under suspension or disbarment from practice before the IRS and who is duly qualified to practice as a CPA in any U.S. state, possession, territory, commonwealth, or the District of Columbia may practice before the IRS.
Any enrolled agent in active status who is not currently under suspension or disbarment from practice before the IRS may practice before the IRS.

Any enrolled retirement plan agent in active status who is not currently under suspension or disbarment from practice before the IRS may practice before the IRS. The practice of enrolled retirement plan agents is limited to certain Internal Revenue Code sections that relate to their area of expertise, principally those sections governing employee retirement plans.

Any individual who is enrolled as an actuary by the Joint Board for the Enrollment of Actuaries who is not currently under suspension or disbarment from practice before the IRS may practice before the IRS. The practice of enrolled actuaries is limited to certain Internal Revenue Code sections that relate to their area of expertise, principally those sections governing employee retirement plans.

Under certain circumstances, a student who is supervised by a practitioner at a law school or equivalent program providing tax services for low income taxpayers may request authorization to represent a taxpayer before the IRS. For more information, see Authorization for Special Appearances , later.

An unenrolled return preparer is an individual other than an attorney, CPA, enrolled agent, enrolled retirement plan agent, or enrolled actuary who prepares and signs a taxpayer's return as the paid preparer, or who prepares a return but is not required (by the instructions to the return or regulations) to sign the return. Unenrolled return preparers may represent taxpayers only before revenue agents, customer service representatives, or similar officers and employees of the Internal Revenue Service (including the Taxpayer Advocate Service) and only during an examination of the tax returns they prepared and signed prior to December 31, 2015. Unenrolled return preparers may not represent taxpayers before appeals officers, revenue officers, counsel or similar officers or employees of the Internal Revenue Service or the Department of the Treasury. Unenrolled return preparers may not execute closing agreements, extend the statutory period for tax assessments or collection of tax, execute waivers, or sign any document on behalf of a taxpayer. If an unenrolled return preparer does not meet the requirements for limited representation, you may authorize the unenrolled return preparer to inspect and/or request your tax information by filing Form 8821. Completing Form 8821 will not authorize the unenrolled return preparer to represent you before the IRS. For more information, see Form 8821 and its separate instructions. Annual Filing Season Program Record of Completion. Only unenrolled return preparers with a valid PTIN and who hold a record of completion for BOTH the tax return year (2015 or thereafter) under examination and the year the examination is conducted may represent under the following conditions: Unenrolled return preparers with the necessary record(s) of completion may represent taxpayers only before revenue agents, customer service representatives, or similar officers and employees of the Internal Revenue Service (including the Taxpayer Advocate Service) and only during an examination of the tax year or period covered by the tax returns they prepared and signed. Unenrolled return preparers may not represent taxpayers, regardless of the circumstances requiring representation, before appeals officers, revenue officers, counsel or similar officers or employees of the Internal Revenue Service or the Department of the Treasury. Unenrolled return preparers may not execute closing agreements, extend the statutory period for tax assessments or collection of tax, execute waivers, or sign any document on behalf of a taxpayer. If an unenrolled return preparer does not meet the requirements for limited representation, you may authorize the unenrolled return preparer to inspect and/or request your tax information by filing Form 8821. Completing Form 8821 will not authorize the unenrolled return preparer to represent you before any IRS personnel. For more information, see Form 8821 and its separate instructions.

In general, individuals who are not eligible, or who have lost the privilege as a result of certain actions, may not practice before the IRS. If an individual loses eligibility to practice, the IRS will not recognize a power of attorney that names the individual as a representative.

Generally, individuals lose their eligibility to practice before the IRS in the following ways. Not meeting the requirements for renewal of enrollment (such as continuing professional education). Requesting as an enrolled agent to be placed in inactive retirement status. Being suspended or disbarred, or determined ineligible for practice, by the Office of Professional Responsibility for violating the regulations contained in Circular 230 or the standards in Revenue Procedure 81-38. Losing their state license to practice as an attorney or a certified public accountant, irrespective of the basis for the license revocation.

Enrolled individuals and AFSP Record of Completion holders who fail to comply with the requirements for eligibility for renewal will be notified by the IRS. The notice will explain the reason for ineligibility and provide the individual with a time-sensitive opportunity to furnish information for reconsideration.

Enrolled individuals who request to be placed in an inactive retirement status will be ineligible to practice before the IRS. They must continue to adhere to all renewal requirements. They can be reinstated to active enrollment status by filing an application for renewal and providing evidence that they have completed the required continuing professional education hours for the enrollment cycle.

All individuals practicing before the IRS are subject to disciplinary proceedings and may be censured, suspended, disbarred or monetarily penalized for violating any regulation in Circular 230. This includes engaging in acts demonstrating incompetence or disreputable conduct. For more information, see Incompetence and Disreputable Conduct under What Are the Rules of Practice , later. Practitioners who are suspended or disbarred in a disciplinary proceeding are not allowed to represent taxpayers before the IRS during the period of suspension/disbarment. A practitioner can seek reinstatement from the Office of Professional Responsibility at the earlier of a specified period of suspension or after five years of disbarment. See What Is Practice Before the IRS , earlier. If the practitioner seeks reinstatement, he or she may not practice before the IRS until the Office of Professional Responsibility grants reinstatement. The Office of Professional Responsibility may reinstate the practitioner: If the practitioner's future conduct is not likely to be in violation of the regulations, and If granting the reinstatement would not be contrary to the public interest. Subject to other conditions for a reasonable period.

The IRS website IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Enrolled-Agents/Become-an-Enrolled-Agent provides complete information on the steps to be taken to become an enrolled agent. For complete rules on earning an Annual Filing Season Program Record of Completion, see IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/General-Requirements-for-the-Annual-Filing-Season-Program-Record-of-Completion.

The rules governing practice before the IRS are published in the Code of Federal Regulations at 31 C.F.R. Subtitle A, Part 10 and released digitally as Treasury Department Circular No. 230 (Circular 230). The regulations can be accessed at IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Circular-230-Tax-Professionals. An attorney, CPA, enrolled agent, enrolled retirement plan agent, or enrolled actuary authorized to practice before the IRS (referred to hereafter as a practitioner) and an appraiser has the duty to perform certain acts and is restricted from performing other acts. In addition, a practitioner cannot engage in disreputable conduct (discussed later). Any practitioner who does not comply with the rules of practice or who engages in incompetent or disreputable conduct is subject to disciplinary action. Also, unenrolled return preparers must comply with the rules of practice and conduct to exercise the privilege of limited practice before the IRS. There are two specific sets of rules that apply, both are contained in Circular 230: 1. Duties and restrictions relating to practice (Subpart B of Cir. 230), and 2. Conduct considered to exhibit incompetence or disrepute (Subpart C, Section 10.51 of Cir. 230).

Individuals subject to Circular 230 must promptly submit records or information sought by a proper and lawful request from officers or employees of the IRS, except when the practitioner believes on reasonable grounds and good faith that the information is privileged. Communications with respect to tax advice between a federally authorized tax practitioner (See Internal Revenue Code (IRC) sec. 7525) and a taxpayer generally are confidential to the same extent that communication would be privileged if it were between a taxpayer and an attorney if the advice relates to: Noncriminal tax matters before the IRS, or Noncriminal tax proceedings brought in federal court by or against the United States.

This protection for tax advice communications does not apply to any written communications between a federally authorized tax practitioner and any person, including a director, shareholder, officer, employee, agent, or representative of a corporation if the communication involves the promotion of the direct or indirect participation of the corporation in any tax shelter.

An individual subject to Circular 230 who knows that his or her client has not complied with the revenue laws or has made an error or omission in any return, document, affidavit, or other required paper, has the responsibility to advise the client promptly of the noncompliance, error, or omission, and the consequences of the noncompliance, error, or omission.

Individuals subject to Circular 230 must exercise due diligence when performing the following duties. Preparing or assisting in the preparing, approving, and filing of returns, documents, affidavits, and other papers relating to IRS matters. Determining the correctness of oral or written representations made by him or her to the Department of the Treasury. Determining the correctness of oral or written representations made by him or her to clients with reference to any matter administered by the IRS.

A presumption that due diligence has been exercised will apply in situations where there has been reliance on the work product of another person if reasonable care was used in engaging, supervising, training, and evaluating the person, taking proper account of the nature of the relationship between the Circular 230 individual and the person.

Individuals subject to Circular 230 may not take acknowledgments, administer oaths, certify papers, or perform any official act as a notary public with respect to any matter administered by the IRS and for which he or she is employed as counsel, attorney, or agent, or in which he or she may be in any way interested.

Individuals subject to Circular 230 may not endorse or otherwise negotiate any check (including directing or accepting payment by any means, electronic or otherwise, into an account owned or controlled by the practitioner or any firm or other entity with whom the practitioner is associated) issued to a client by the government in respect of a Federal tax liability.

Individuals subject to Circular 230 may be disbarred or suspended from practice before the IRS, or censured, for incompetence or disreputable conduct. A monetary penalty may also be imposed, in addition to any other discipline, on both individuals and their firms. The following list contains examples of conduct that is considered disreputable. Further examples are shown in Circular 230, Sec. 10.51(a). Being convicted of any criminal offense under the internal revenue laws or of any offense involving dishonesty or breach of trust. Knowingly giving false or misleading information in connection with federal tax matters, or participating in such activity. Soliciting employment by prohibited means as discussed in section 10.30 of Circular 230. Willfully failing to file a federal tax return, evading or attempting to evade any federal tax or payment, or participating in such actions. Misappropriating, or failing to properly and promptly remit, funds received from clients for payment of taxes or other obligations due the United States. Directly or indirectly attempting to influence the official action of IRS employees by the use of threats, false accusations, duress, or coercion, or by offering gifts, favors, or any special inducements. Being disbarred or suspended from practice as an attorney, CPA, public accountant, or actuary, by the District of Columbia or any U.S. state, possession, territory, commonwealth, or any federal court, or any federal agency, body, or board. Knowingly aiding and abetting another person to practice before the IRS during a period of suspension, disbarment, or ineligibility of that other person. Using abusive language, making false accusations or statements knowing them to be false, circulating or publishing malicious or libelous matter, or engaging in any contemptuous conduct in connection with practice before the IRS. Giving a false opinion knowingly, recklessly, or through gross incompetence; or engaging in a pattern of providing incompetent opinions on questions arising under the federal tax laws.

The Secretary of the Treasury, or delegate, after notice and an opportunity for a proceeding, may censure, suspend, or disbar an individual subject to Circular 230 from practice before the IRS if the individual is shown to be incompetent or disreputable, fails to comply with the regulations in Subpart B; or with intent to defraud, willfully and knowingly misleads or threatens a client or prospective client. Censure is a public reprimand. Individuals subject to Circular 230 include any attorney, certified public accountant, enrolled agent, enrolled retirement plan agent, or enrolled actuary engaged in taxpayer representation or advice-giving activity, as well as any Annual Filing Season Program Record of Completion holder who represents taxpayers and any appraiser engaged in appraising asset values for federal tax purposes.

A power of attorney is your written authorization for an individual to receive your confidential tax information from the IRS and to perform certain actions on your behalf. If the authorization is not limited, the individual generally can perform all acts that you can perform, except negotiating or endorsing a check. The authority granted to enrolled retirement plan agents, enrolled actuaries and unenrolled return preparers holding records of completion is limited. For information on the limits regarding annual filing season program record of completion holders, see Revenue Procedure 2014-42 and IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Return-Preparer-Office-RPO-At-a-Glance.

Attorneys, certified public accountants, and enrolled agents may perform the following acts: 1. Represent you before any office or employee of the IRS. 2. Sign an offer or a waiver of restriction on assessment or collection of a tax deficiency, or a waiver of notice of disallowance of claim for credit or refund. 3. Sign a consent to extend the statutory time period for assessment or collection of a tax. 4. Sign a closing agreement.

When a return is signed by a representative, it must be accompanied by a power of attorney (or copy) authorizing the representative to sign the return. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 2848.

A recognized representative can substitute or delegate authority under the power of attorney to another recognized representative only if the act is specifically authorized by you on the power of attorney. After a substitution has been made, only the newly recognized representative will be recognized as the taxpayer's representative. If a delegation of power has been made, both the original and the delegated representative will be recognized by the IRS to represent you.

Your representative cannot execute consents that will allow the IRS to disclose tax return or return information to a third party unless you specifically delegate this authority to your representative on line 5a of Form 2848.

A power of attorney is generally terminated if you become incapacitated or incompetent. The power of attorney can continue, however, in the case of your incapacity or incompetency if you authorize this on line 5a "Other acts authorized" of the Form 2848 and if your non-IRS durable power of attorney meets all the requirements for acceptance by the IRS. See Non-IRS powers of attorney , later.

Submit a power of attorney when you want to authorize an individual to receive your confidential tax information and represent you before the IRS, whether or not the representative performs any of the other acts cited earlier under What Is a Power of Attorney . A power of attorney is most often required when you want to authorize another individual to perform at least one of the following acts on your behalf. 1. Represent you at a meeting with the IRS. 2. Prepare and file a written response to an IRS inquiry.

Use IRS Form 2848 to appoint a recognized representative to act on your behalf before the IRS. Individuals recognized to represent you before the IRS are listed under Part II, Declaration of Representative, of Form 2848. Your representative must complete that part of the form.

The IRS will not accept your non-IRS power of attorney if it does not contain all the information listed above. You can sign and submit a completed Form 2848 or a new non-IRS power of attorney that contains all the information. If you cannot sign an acceptable replacement document, your attorney-in-fact may be able to perfect (make acceptable to the IRS) your non-IRS power of attorney by using the procedure described next.
The following hints are summaries of some of the line-by-line instructions for Form 2848.

Generally, you can mail or fax a paper Form 2848 directly to the IRS. To determine where you should file Form 2848, see Where To File in the Instructions for Form 2848. If Form 2848 is for a specific use, mail or fax it to the office handling that matter. For more information on specific use, see Line 4. Specific Use Not Recorded on CAF in the Instructions for Form 2848.

The IRS will accept a copy of a power of attorney that is submitted by facsimile transmission (fax). If you choose to file a power of attorney by fax, be sure the appropriate IRS office is equipped to accept this type of transmission. !This is an Image: taxtip.gif Your representative may be able to file Form 2848 electronically via the IRS website. For more information, your representative can go to IRS.gov/eServices. If you complete Form 2848 for electronic signature authorization, do not file Form 2848 with the IRS. Instead, give it to your representative, who will retain the document.

Submit any update or modification to an existing power of attorney in writing. Your signature (or the signature of the individual(s) authorized to sign on your behalf) is required. Do this by sending the updated Form 2848 or non-IRS power of attorney to the IRS office(s) where you previously sent the original(s), including the service center where the related return was, or will be filed. A recognized representative may substitute or delegate authority if you specifically authorize your representative to substitute or delegate representation in the original power of attorney. To make a substitution or delegation, the representative must file the following items with the IRS office(s) where the power of attorney was filed. 1. A written notice of substitution or delegation signed by the recognized representative. 2. A written declaration of representative made by the new representative. 3. A copy of the power of attorney that specifically authorizes the substitution or delegation.

A newly filed power of attorney concerning the same matter will revoke a previously filed power of attorney. However, the new power of attorney will not revoke the prior power of attorney if it specifically states it does not revoke such prior power of attorney and either of the following are attached to the new power of attorney. A copy of the unrevoked prior power of attorney, or A statement signed by the taxpayer listing the name and address of each representative authorized under the prior unrevoked power of attorney.

If you want to revoke a previously executed power of attorney and do not want to name a new representative, you must write “REVOKE” across the top of the first page of the Form 2848 with a current signature and date immediately below this annotation. Then, you must mail or fax a copy of the power of attorney with the revocation annotation to the IRS, using the Where To File Chart in the Instructions for Form 2848, or if the power of attorney is for a specific matter, to the IRS office handling the matter. If you do not have a copy of the power of attorney you want to revoke, you must send the IRS a statement of revocation that indicates the authority of the power of attorney is revoked, lists the matters and years/periods, and lists the name and address of each recognized representative whose authority is revoked. You must sign and date this statement. If you are completely revoking authority, write "remove all years/periods" instead of listing the specific matters and years/periods.

If your representative wants to withdraw from representation, he or she must write “WITHDRAW” across the top of the first page of the Form 2848 with a current signature and date immediately below the annotation. Then, he or she must provide a copy of the power of attorney with the withdrawal annotation to the IRS in the same manner described in Revocation by taxpayer above. If your representative does not have a copy of the power of attorney he or she wants to withdraw, he or she must send the IRS a statement of withdrawal that indicates the authority of the power of attorney is withdrawn, lists the matters and years/periods, and lists the name, TIN, and address (if known) of the taxpayer. The representative must sign and date this statement. A power of attorney held by a student will be recorded on the CAF system for 130 days from the receipt date. If you are authorizing a student to represent you after that time, you will need to submit another updated Form 2848.

!This is an Image: caution.gif For partnership tax years beginning after December 31, 2017, the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015, which repealed the TEFRA partnership audit and litigation procedures and the rules applicable to electing large partnerships and replaced them with a new centralized partnership audit regime, has eliminated the role of “tax matters partner” and replaced it with “partnership representative.” Pursuant to Treasury Regulation section 301.9100-22T, certain partnerships can elect to have the new regime apply to partnership returns for tax years beginning after November 2, 2015, and before January 1, 2018.

A power of attorney will be recognized after it is received, reviewed, and determined by the IRS to contain the required information. However, until a power of attorney is entered on the CAF system, IRS personnel may be unaware of the authority of the person you have named to represent you. Therefore, during this interim period, IRS personnel may request that you or your representative bring a copy to any meeting with the IRS.
How the power of attorney is processed and handled depends on whether it is a complete or incomplete document.

If Form 2848 is incomplete, the IRS will attempt to secure the missing information either by writing or telephoning you or your representative. For example, if your signature or signature date is missing, the IRS will contact you. If information concerning your representative is missing and information sufficient to make a contact (such as an address and/or a telephone number) is on the document, the IRS will try to contact your representative. In either case, the power of attorney is not considered valid until all required information is entered on the document. The individual(s) named as representative(s) will not be recognized to practice before the IRS, on your behalf, until the document is complete and accepted by the IRS.

If the power of attorney is complete and valid, the IRS will take action to recognize the representative. In most instances, this includes processing the document on the CAF system. Recording the data on the CAF system enables the IRS to direct copies of mailings to authorized representatives and to readily recognize the scope of authority granted.

After a valid power of attorney is filed, the IRS will recognize your representative. However, if it appears the representative is responsible for unreasonably delaying or hindering the prompt disposition of an IRS matter by failing to furnish, after repeated requests, nonprivileged information, the IRS can contact you directly. For example, in most instances in which a power of attorney is recognized, the IRS will contact the representative to set up appointments and to provide the representative with lists of required items. However, if the representative is unavailable, does not respond to repeated requests, and does not provide required items (other than items considered privileged), the IRS can bypass your representative and contact you directly. If a representative engages in conduct described above, the matter can be referred to the Office of Professional Responsibility for consideration of possible disciplinary action.

If you want to authorize your representative to receive copies of all notices and communications sent to you by the IRS, you must check the box that is provided under the representative's name and address.No more than two representatives may receive copies of notices and communications sent to you by the IRS. Do not check the box if you do not want copies of notices and communications sent to your representative(s).

If you have questions about a tax issue, need help preparing your tax return, or want to download free publications, forms, or instructions, go to IRS.gov and find resources that can help you right away.

Go to IRS.gov/Help or IRS.gov/LetUsHelp pages for a variety of tools that will help you get answers to some of the most common tax questions. The IRS uses the latest encryption technology to ensure your electronic payments are safe and secure. Go to IRS.gov/WMAR to track the status of Form 1040X amended returns. Please note that it can take up to 3 weeks from the date you mailed your amended return for it to show up in our system and processing it can take up to 16 weeks.

The Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS that helps taxpayers and protects taxpayer rights. Our job is to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights.

The Taxpayer Bill of Rights describes 10 basic rights that all taxpayers have when dealing with the IRS. Our Tax Toolkit at TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov can help you understand what these rights mean to you and how they apply. These are your rights. Know them. Use them.

Low Income Taxpayer Clinics (LITCs) are independent from the IRS. LITCs represent individuals whose income is below a certain level and need to resolve tax problems with the IRS, such as audits, appeals, and tax collection disputes. In addition, clinics can provide information about taxpayer rights and responsibilities in different languages for individuals who speak English as a second language. Services are offered for free or a small fee. To find a clinic near you, visit TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/LITCmap or see IRS Publication 4134, Low Income Taxpayer Clinic List PDF.

Go to IRS.gov/Forms to view, download, or print all of the forms and publications you may need. You can also download and view popular tax publications and instructions (including the 1040 instructions) on mobile devices as an eBook at no charge. Or, you can go to IRS.gov/OrderForms to place an order and have forms mailed to you within 10 business days.

Go to IRS.gov/Account to securely access information about your federal tax account. View the amount you owe, pay online or set up an online payment agreement. Access your tax records online. Review the past 18 months of your payment history. Go to IRS.gov/SecureAccess to review the required identity authentication process.

The fastest way to receive a tax refund is to combine direct deposit and IRS e-file. Direct deposit securely and electronically transfers your refund directly into your financial account. Eight in 10 taxpayers use direct deposit to receive their refund. IRS issues more than 90% of refunds in less than 21 days.

Due to changes in the law, the IRS can’t issue refunds before mid-February 2018, for returns that properly claimed the earned income credit (EIC) or the additional child tax credit (ACTC). This applies to the entire refund, not just the portion associated with these credits.

The quickest way to get a copy of your tax transcript is to go to IRS.gov/Transcripts. Click on either "Get Transcript Online" or "Get Transcript by Mail" to order a copy of your transcript. If you prefer, you can: Order your transcript by calling 1-800-908-9946. Mail Form 4506-T or Form 4506T-EZ (both available on IRS.gov).

Go to IRS.gov/Tools for the following. The Earned Income Tax Credit Assistant (IRS.gov/EIC) determines if you’re eligible for the EIC. The Online EIN Application (IRS.gov/EIN) helps you get an employer identification number. The IRS Withholding Calculator (IRS.gov/W4App) estimates the amount you should have withheld from your paycheck for federal income tax purposes. The First Time Homebuyer Credit Account Look-up (IRS.gov/HomeBuyer) tool provides information on your repayments and account balance. The Sales Tax Deduction Calculator (IRS.gov/SalesTax) figures the amount you can claim if you itemize deductions on Schedule A (Form 1040), choose not to claim state and local income taxes, and you didn’t save your receipts showing the sales tax you paid.

The IRS doesn’t initiate contact with taxpayers by email or telephone to request personal or financial information. This includes any type of electronic communication, such as text messages and social media channels. Go to IRS.gov/IDProtection for information and videos. If your SSN has been lost or stolen or you suspect you’re a victim of tax-related identity theft, visit IRS.gov/ID to learn what steps you should take.

This publication covers the general rules for filing a federal income tax return. The publication supplements the information in your instructions. It also explains the tax laws to make sure you pay only the tax you owe and no more.

This publication follows closely Form 1040, U.S. Individual Income Tax Return; Form 1040-SR, U.S. Tax Return for Seniors; and their three schedules 1 to 3. Publication 17 is divided into four parts. Each part is subdivided into chapters that normally explain a line of the form or a line of one of the three schedules. The introduction at the beginning of each part indicates the (s) schedule(s) explained in that part. The table of contents that appears at the beginning of this publication, the introduction of each part, and the index that appears at the end will be helpful to you in finding the information you need.

This publication will help you determine your filing status for the return you are entitled to file. It will also help you determine whether you can claim a dependent and whether the income you receive is subject to tax. The publication also explains the standard deduction, the types of expenses you may be able to deduct, and several credits you may be able to take to reduce your taxes. Throughout this publication, there are examples that show how tax laws apply in typical situations. There are also flowcharts and tables in this publication that present tax information in an easy-to-understand way. Many of the topics covered in this publication are explained in more detail in other IRS publications. References to these publications and information on whether they are available in Spanish or English are included.

This publication provides general information about federal tax laws that apply to you if you are self-employed or a statutory employee. This publication contains information about business income, expenses, and tax credits that may help you, as a small business owner, file your income tax return.

{ "English": "You are self-employed if you carry on an occupation or business as a sole proprietor or as an independent contractor. To be self-employed, you do not have to perform business activities on a full-time basis. Having a part-time business in addition to your regular employment or business could be considered self-employment. Business. Generally, an occupation or business is an activity that you perform to earn money. The facts and circumstances of each case determine whether any activity constitutes an occupation or business. You do not have to earn money to carry on an occupation or business, as long as you have the motive of earning a profit. You must, however, perform continuous efforts to promote the interests of your business. Limited liability company (LLC). A limited liability company (LLC, for its acronym in English) is an entity established in accordance with state laws by filing an official certificate of formation. Generally, a single-member LLC is not considered a separate entity from its owner, and its income and deductions are reported on the owner's federal income tax return. For example, if the LLC of a single member is not engaged in farming and the owner is an individual, the owner could use Schedule C. Sole proprietor of a business. A sole proprietor of a business is someone who, by himself, owns a non-incorporated business. You are also a sole proprietor of a business for tax purposes if you are an individual and the sole member of a domestic LLC, unless you elect to treat the LLC as a partnership. Independent contractor. Generally, people such as doctors, dentists, veterinarians, lawyers, accountants, contractors, subcontractors, court reporters or auctioneers who exercise occupations, businesses or professions as independent contractors to the general public are independent contractors. However, whether a person is an independent contractor or an employee depends on the facts in each case. The general rule is that an individual is an independent contractor if the person who pays has the right to control or direct only the result of the work and not how it is performed. Below are some of the tax changes for 2024. Maximum net income. The maximum net self-employment income subject to the Social Security part of the self-employment tax is $168,600 for 2024. There is no maximum income subject to the Medicare part of the self-employment tax. Special depreciation. The special depreciation deduction under section 168(k) continues its gradual phaseout in 2024 with a reduction from 80% to 60% of the applicable limit. Standard mileage rate. For 2024, the standard mileage rate for the business use of your car, van, pickup truck, or delivery truck per mile driven in 2024 increased to 67 cents per mile.For more information, see Business Expenses in chapter 8. Uncollectible debts. Publication 535, Business Expenses, has been discontinued. The information on uncollectible debts provided in that publication is now incorporated in chapter 8 under Uncollectible Debts in Publication 334.

Below are some of the tax changes for 2025. For information on other changes, go to IRS.gov/Espanol. Maximum self-employment income. The maximum self-employment income subject to the Social Security part of the self-employment tax is $176,100 for 2025. Standard mileage rate. For 2025, the standard mileage rate for the business use of your car, van, pickup truck, or delivery van is 70 cents per mile.

After you calculate your business income and expenses, you're ready to calculate your business net income or business net loss. You do this by subtracting your business expenses from your business income. If your expenses are less than your income, the difference is your business net income and it becomes part of your income on line 3 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). If your expenses are more than your income, the difference is a business net loss. You can usually deduct it from your gross income on line 3 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). However, in some situations, your loss is limited. This chapter briefly explains three of those situations. Other situations that could limit your loss are explained in the instructions for line G and line 32 in the instructions for Schedule C. If you have more than one business, you must calculate your net income or net loss for each business on a separate Schedule C.

Your loss of a job or business may be limited. Use Form 461 to determine the amount of your business loss in excess, if any. Your business loss in excess will be included as income on line 8p of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) and treated as a net operating loss (NOL) that must be carried over to subsequent years and deducted in a subsequent tax year. For more information about the business loss in excess limit, see Form 461 and its instructions.

A loss resulting from the operation of a business is the most common reason for a net operating loss. For more information about NOLs, see Publication 536. This explains how to calculate a net operating loss, when to use it, how to claim a deduction for a net operating loss, and how to calculate a transfer of a net operating loss to the following year.

If you don't operate your business to make a profit, there's a limit on the deductions you can take. You can't use a loss from the activity to offset other income. Activities you carry on as a hobby, or mainly for recreation or sport, are subject to this limit. For details about non-profit activities, see Hobby or business: what you need to know (about that extra work).
Self-employment tax rules apply regardless of your age and even if you are already receiving Social Security and Medicare benefits.
Generally, you have to pay self-employment taxes and file Form 1040 Schedule SE if your net self-employment income was $400 or more. Use Schedule SE to figure your net self-employment income.
If you work as a sole proprietor or independent contractor, you generally use Schedule C (Form 1040) to figure your net earnings from self-employment.
For 2024, the self-employment tax rate on net income is 15.3% (12.4% of Social Security plus 2.9% of Medicare tax).

Only the first $168,600 of the combination of your wages, tips, and net earnings in 2024 are subject to payment of any combination of the 12.4% of the Social Security part of self-employment taxes, Social Security tax, or Railroad Retirement Tax (Level 1). All your wages, tips, and net earnings combined in 2024 are subject to payment of any combination of the 2.9% of the Medicare part of self-employment taxes, Medicare tax, or the Medicare part of Railroad Retirement Tax. If your wages and tips are subject to the Social Security tax or the Railroad Retirement Tax (Level 1), or both, and they total at least $168,600, do not pay the 12.4% of the Social Security part of self-employment taxes on any of your net earnings. However, you must pay the 2.9% of the Medicare part of self-employment taxes on all your net earnings.

If you have self-employment income from more than one occupation, business, or profession, you must combine the net earnings (or losses) from each to figure your total self-employment income. A loss from one business reduces your earnings from another business.

If any income from an occupation or business, other than a partnership, is income of the community (marital property) under state law, it is included in the income subject to self-employment tax for the spouse who performs the occupation or business.

Do not include in the income subject to self-employment tax the gains or losses from the disposition of property held primarily for sale to customers. It does not matter whether the disposition is a sale, exchange, or involuntary conversion.

If you are self-employed and reduce or suspend your business activities, any payment you receive from the insurance or from other sources for the loss of business income is included in the income subject to self-employment taxes. If you are not working at the time you receive the payment, it is still related to your business and is included in the income subject to self-employment taxes, even if your business is temporarily inactive.

If you work for a church or a qualified church-controlled organization (that is not as a minister, member of a religious order, or Christian Science practitioner) that elected to have Social Security and Medicare taxes withheld from your pay, you are subject to self-employment tax if you receive $108.28 or more in church or organization pay. For more information, see Publication 517, Social Security and Other Information for Members of the Clergy and Religious Workers.
The fees you receive for services performed as a public notary are reported on Schedule C, but are not subject to self-employment taxes (see Instructions for Schedule SE (Form 1040)).

He is subject to self-employment tax if he is an employee of a state or local government, is paid exclusively on a flat fee basis, and his services are not covered by Social Security under a federal-state agreement.

You are subject to self-employment tax if both of the following conditions are true: 1. You are a U.S. citizen employed in the United States, Puerto Rico, Guam, the U.S. Virgin Islands, or the Northern Mariana Islands by: 1. A foreign government, 2. An agency or instrumentality of a foreign government, or 3. An international organization. 2. Your employer is not required to withhold Social Security and Medicare taxes from your wages.

If you are a U.S. citizen or foreign resident who works for yourself and lives outside the United States, in most cases you must pay self-employment tax on your self-employment income. Self-employment income earned abroad cannot be reduced by your foreign earned income exclusion when calculating self-employment tax.

The United States has social security agreements with many countries to eliminate double taxation under two social security systems. Under these agreements, you generally have to pay Social Security and Medicare taxes only to the country where you live. The country to which you pay the taxes will issue a certificate that serves as proof of exemption from Social Security taxes in the other country. For more information, see Instructions for Form 1040, Schedule SE.

You may want to use the optional methods (explained below) if you have a loss or little net income, and apply any of the following situations: You want to receive credit for Social Security benefit coverage. You incurred expenses for the care of children or dependents for which you may claim a credit. (An optional method could increase your work income, which could increase your credit). You are entitled to the work income credit. (An optional method could increase your work income, which could increase your credit). You are entitled to the additional child tax credit. (An optional method could increase your work income, which could increase your credit).

Using an optional method could increase your self-employment taxes. Paying more in self-employment taxes could result in higher benefits when you retire. Using the optional methods may also decrease your adjusted gross income (AGI, as defined in the instructions for Form 1040 or 1040-SR) because half of the self-employment tax is deducted from your AGI. This may affect your eligibility for credits, deductions, or other items that are subject to an AGI limit. Calculate your AGI with and without using the optional methods to see if the optional methods will benefit you. If you use one or both of the optional methods, you must calculate and pay the self-employment taxes due under these methods even if you had a lower or no tax using the regular method. The optional methods can be used only to calculate your self-employment taxes. To calculate your income taxes, include your actual income in your gross income, regardless of which method you use to calculate your self-employment taxes.

To calculate net income using the regular method, multiply your self-employment income by 0.9235. For your net income calculated using the regular method, see line 4a of your Schedule SE (Form 1040). Net income calculated using the regular method is also called net income realized.

Use the optional non-agricultural method only for income that is not from agriculture (agricultural activities). You can use this method if you meet all of the following requirements: 1. You work for yourself on a regular basis. This means that your net income from self-employment was $400 or more in at least 2 of the 3 tax years before the year for which you use this method. For this purpose, net income from the previous year can come from agricultural or non-agricultural income or both. 2. You have used this method for less than 5 years. (There is a lifetime limit of 5 years). The years do not have to be consecutive. 3. Your non-agricultural net income was: 1. Less than $7,493 and 2. Less than 72.189% of your non-agricultural gross income.
However, you may need to adjust the amount reported on Form 1065, Schedule K-1, if you are a general partner or if you have a loss.

Si usa un año fiscal que no sea el año natural, debe utilizar la tasa impositiva y el límite máximo de ingresos en efecto al comienzo de su año fiscal. Aunque cambie la tasa impositiva o el límite máximo de ingresos durante su año fiscal, continúe utilizando la misma tasa y límite durante su año fiscal.

Use Schedule SE (Form 1040) to calculate and report your self-employment taxes. If you file Form 1040 or 1040-SR, report your self-employment taxes on line 4 of Schedule 2 and attach Schedule SE to your form. If you file Form 1040-SS, report your self-employment taxes on line 3 and attach Schedule SE to your form. If you need to pay self-employment taxes, you must file Form 1040, 1040-SR or 1040-SS, as applicable, (with Schedule SE attached) even if you otherwise do not have to file a federal income tax return.

Although you file a joint return, you cannot file a joint Schedule SE. This is true whether one or both spouses have self-employment income. If both of you have self-employment income, each of you must file a separate Schedule SE. Attach both schedules to your joint return.

Si tiene más de una ocupación o negocio, debe combinar las ganancias (o pérdidas) netas de cada negocio para calcular sus impuestos sobre el trabajo por cuenta propia. Una pérdida de un negocio reducirá su ganancia de otro negocio. Presente un (1) Anexo SE que muestre los ingresos del trabajo por cuenta propia, pero presente un Anexo C o un Anexo F por separado para cada negocio.
This chapter explains the review, appeal, collection, and refund processes.

We accept most tax returns as filed by taxpayers. If we ask for information about your return or select it for review, this does not mean you are dishonest. The review or investigation may or may not result in additional tax. We may close your case without making any changes or you may receive a refund. The process of selecting a return for review usually begins in one of two ways. One way is using computer programs to identify returns that may have incorrect amounts. These programs can be based on information returns, such as Forms 1099 and W-2, past review studies, or certain issues identified by other special projects. Another way is using information from tax compliance projects that indicate a return may include incorrect amounts. These sources can include newspapers, public records, and individuals. If we determine the information is true and reliable, we may use it to select a return for review. Publication 556, Examination of Returns, Appeal Rights, and Claims for Refund, explains the rules and procedures we follow during reviews. The sections that follow below provide a summary of how we conduct audits.

We process many reviews and investigations by mail. We can send you a letter asking for more information or telling you why we think we may have to make a change to your tax return. You can reply by mail or request an in-person interview with the reviewer. If you provide us with the requested information or an explanation by mail, we may or may not agree with you and we will explain the reasons for any change. Don't hesitate to write to us about something you don't understand.

If we notify you that we will conduct your review through an in-person interview, or if you request it, you have the right to request that the interview be held at a time and place that is convenient for you and the IRS. If our examiner proposes any changes to your tax return, he or she will explain the reasons for such changes. If you do not agree with these changes, you may meet with the supervisor of the examiner.

Si revisamos las mismas partidas en su declaración de impuestos en cualquiera de los 2 años anteriores y no propusimos cambios a su deuda tributaria, comuníquese con nosotros lo antes posible para así poder determinar si debemos descontinuar la revisión.

If you do not agree with the changes proposed by the examiner, you may appeal to the IRS Independent Office of Appeals. Most disagreements can be resolved without incurring the time and expense of going to court. Your rights of appeal are explained in detail in Publication 5, Your Rights of Appeal and How to Prepare a Protest If You Disagree, and in Publication 556. If you do not want to use the Independent Office of Appeals or if you are not satisfied with its determinations, you may appeal your case to the U.S. Tax Court, the U.S. Court of Federal Claims, or the U.S. District Court that serves the area where you live. If you take your case to court, the IRS will have the burden of proving certain facts if you kept adequate records showing your tax liability, cooperated with the IRS, and meet certain other conditions. If the court agrees with you on most of the determinations in your case and finds that our position was largely unjustified, you may be able to recover some of the administrative and litigation expenses you incurred. You will not be entitled to recover these expenses unless you tried to resolve your case through the administrative process, including following the appropriate procedures through the appeals process and providing us with the necessary information to resolve your case.
Your rights to appeal the assessments are explained in detail in Publication 1660, Rights to Appeal Assessments.

Generally, you and your spouse are jointly and individually liable for paying the full amount of any tax, interest, or penalty due on your joint return. To request relief from any liability related to your spouse (or former spouse), you must file Form 8857, Request for Spouse Innocent Relief. In some cases, you may have to file Form 8857 within 2 years from the date the IRS first attempted to collect the tax from you. Do not file Form 8857 with your Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For more information, see Publication 971, Innocent Spouse Relief, and Form 8857, or call the Innocent Spouse (Spouse Innocent) toll-free at 855-851-2009.

You may file a refund claim if you believe you have paid too much tax. You generally have to file the claim within 3 years from the date you filed your original return or 2 years from the date you paid the tax, whichever is later. Publication 556 contains additional information about refunds. If you were entitled to receive a refund but did not file a return, then you will have to file a refund claim within 2 years from the date you paid the tax in order to receive the refund. The law, generally, stipulates that interest be paid on the amount of your refund, if it is not paid within a 45-day period from the date you filed your return or refund claim.

This part explains whether you have to file an income tax return and when you have to file it. It also explains how to pay your taxes.

You must file a tax return for 2024 if you had $400 or more in net self-employment income. If you had less than $400 in net self-employment income, you still must file a tax return if you meet any of the other filing requirements listed in the Instructions for Form 1040.

File your tax return using Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR and attach a Schedule C. Report the net income or loss from Schedule C on Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Use Schedule C to calculate the net income or loss from your business. If you operated more than one business as a sole proprietor, you must attach a separate Schedule C for each business.

The filing of electronic returns is easier than you think, and is available to most taxpayers who file their returns electronically — including those who are filing their first tax return and were 16 years old or older at the end of 2024. If you file an electronic return using tax preparation software or the services of a tax professional, you will sign your return using the IRS's self-select PIN method. If you are married and filing a joint return, you and your spouse will each need to create a PIN and use them as your electronic signatures. To create a PIN, you will need to know your adjusted gross income (AGI) from your original 2023 tax return (not your Form 1040-X, Amended U.S. Individual Income Tax Return, or the AGI that appears on an IRS notice about a mathematical error). You will also need to provide your date of birth (DOB). Be sure your date of birth is correct and matches the information on file with the SSA before using the e-file system. To verify, check your annual Social Security statement. With a self-selected PIN, there is nothing to sign or to mail, not even your Form(s) W-2. For more details about the self-select PIN method, go to IRS.gov/Espanol.

In most states, you can file a state tax return electronically at the same time as your federal tax return. For more information, contact your state tax agency, a tax professional, or visit IRS.gov/Spanish.

You can have your refund check mailed to you, or you can have your refund deposited directly into your checking or savings account. With the IRS e-file system, your refund will be issued in half the time it would take with a paper tax return. Most refunds are issued in less than 21 days.

The IRS cannot issue refunds before mid-February 2025 for returns that claim the work income credit or the additional child tax credit. This applies to the full refund, not just the portion related to these credits.

All you need to file your tax return using the IRS e-file system is a computer with Internet access. For calendar year 2024, the filing deadline for Form 1040 or 1040-SR is April 15, 2025. If you use a fiscal year (explained in Chapter 2), the filing deadline for your tax return is the 15th day of the 4th month after the end of your fiscal year. If you file your return late, you may have to pay penalties and interest. If you can't file your tax return on time, use Form 4868, Application for Automatic Extension of Time to File U.S. Individual Income Tax Return, to request an automatic 6-month extension. For calendar year taxpayers, this extends the filing deadline to October 15. However, filing an extension request does not extend the tax payment deadline, only the tax return filing deadline.

Social Security benefits are available to self-employed people in the same way as to people who earn wages or salaries. Your self-employment taxes contribute to your coverage under the Social Security system. Social Security coverage provides you with retirement benefits, disability benefits, survivor benefits, and hospital insurance (Medicare) benefits. Be sure to report all your self-employment income. If you don't report all your income, you may reduce your Social Security benefits when you retire.

You must be insured (covered) by Social Security before you can start receiving Social Security benefits. You will be covered if you have earned the required number of credits (also called quarters of coverage), explained below.
Self-employment tax rules apply regardless of your age and even if you're already receiving Social Security or Medicare benefits.
The self-employment tax rate on net income is 15.3% (12.4% of the Social Security tax plus 2.9% of the Medicare tax).

Only the first $168,600 of the combination of your wages, tips, and net earnings in 2024 are subject to payment of any combination of the 12.4% of the Social Security portion of self-employment taxes, Social Security tax, or the Railroad Retirement Tax Level 1 employee tax. All your wages, tips, and net earnings combined in 2024 are subject to any combination of the 2.9% of the Medicare portion of self-employment taxes, Social Security tax, or the Railroad Retirement Tax Level 1 employee tax. If your wages and tips are subject to the Social Security tax or the Railroad Retirement Tax Level 1 employee tax, or both, and they total at least $168,600, do not pay the 12.4% of the Social Security portion of self-employment taxes on any of your net earnings. However, you must pay the 2.9% of the Medicare portion of self-employment taxes on all your net earnings. Deduct half of the amount of your self-employment taxes as a adjustment to income on line 15 of Form 1040.

For more information, see Publication 15, Employer’s Tax Guide. That publication explains your tax responsibilities as an employer. Do not reduce your Social Security and Medicare tax deduction by the non-reimbursable and reimbursable portions of the FFCRA and ARP Act 2021 sick leave and family leave credits claimed on a payroll tax return. Instead, report the credits as income.. To help you determine whether the people who work for you are employees, see Publication 15-A. That publication contains information to help you determine whether a person is an independent contractor or an employee. If you misclassify an employee as an independent contractor, you may be responsible for paying payroll taxes for that employee, in addition to a penalty.
For more information on excise taxes, see Publication 510, Excise Taxes.

Taxes on articles of use and consumption that are reported on Form 720, Quarterly Federal Excise Tax Return (Federal quarterly excise tax return for articles of use and consumption), consist of several broad categories of taxes, including the following: Environmental taxes on the sale or use of ozone-depleting chemicals and imported products containing or manufactured with those chemicals. Communications and air transportation taxes. Fuel taxes. Tax on the initial retail sale of heavy trucks, trailers, and tractors. Manufacturer's taxes on the sale or use of a variety of different articles. Tax on indoor tanning services.

There is a federal tax on the use of certain trucks, tractor-trailers, and buses on public roads. The tax applies to vehicles that have a gross taxable weight of 55,000 pounds or more. File the tax on Form 2290, Heavy Vehicle Use Tax Return. For more information, see the instructions for Form 2290.

If you have to file a quarterly Illinois Use Tax Return on Form 720, you may have to pay your Illinois Use Tax before the filing deadline for the return. To see the details on how to pay your Illinois Use Tax, see the Instructions for Form 720.

If you make or receive payments in your business, you may have to report them to the IRS by using information returns. The IRS compares the payments shown on the information returns with the payments shown on the income tax returns of each person to see if the payments were included as income. You must give a copy of each required information return to the payee or payor. In addition to the forms described below, you may have to use other forms to report certain types of payments or transactions. For more information about information returns and when you must file them, see General Instructions for Certain Information Returns.
You will also use Form 1099-MISC to report your sales of $5,000 or more in consumer products to a person who will resell them in any other place than a permanent retail establishment.

You also have to file Form 1099-NEC for each person you withheld any federal income tax (as reported in box 4) according to the additional tax withholding rules regardless of the amount of the payment. If you use Form 1099-NEC to report sales of $5,000 or more of consumer products, then you have to file Form 1099-NEC with the IRS by January 31.

You must file Form W-2 to report payments made to your employees, such as salaries, tips, and other types of compensation; and income tax and Social Security and Medicare taxes withheld. You can file Form W-2 online. For more information about Form W-2, see General Instructions for Forms W-2 and W-3.

The law provides the following penalties if you do not file the (one or more) Form(s) 1099-MISC, Form(s) 1099-NEC, or Form(s) W-2 or if you do not report the information correctly. For more information, see General Instructions for Certain Information Returns. For not filing information returns. This penalty applies if you do not file the information return by the due date, do not include all the required information, or report the information incorrectly. For not providing the correct payee statements. This penalty applies if you do not provide the correct statement of payment to a payee for the due date, do not include all the required information, or report the information incorrectly.

You must file Form 8300, Report of Cash Payments in Excess of $10,000 Received by a Trade or Business, if you receive more than $10,000 in cash in a single transaction, or in two or more related business transactions. Cash includes currency and foreign currency. It also includes certain monetary instruments, such as cashiers' checks and travelers' checks, as well as wire transfers. Cash does not include personal checks (personal checks). For more information, see Publication 1544, Report of Cash Payments in Excess of $10,000.

Civil and criminal penalties, including up to 5 years in prison, may be imposed for failing to file Form 8300, filing (or causing to be filed) a false or fraudulent Form 8300, or structuring a transaction to evade reporting requirements.

You must calculate your taxable income and file a tax return on your income for a fiscal year that is called the tax year. You must also use a consistent method of accounting that clearly shows your income and expenses for that tax year.

Unless you are required to use a specific tax year, you adopt the tax year when you file your first income tax return using that tax year. A specific tax year is a tax year required by the Internal Revenue Code or the Income Tax Regulations.

If you filed your first income tax return using the calendar year and later start a business as a sole proprietor, you must continue to use the calendar year, unless you receive IRS approval to change it or otherwise are allowed to make the change without IRS approval. For more information, see Changing Tax Year, later. If you adopt the calendar year, you must keep your books and records, and report your income and expenses for the period from January 1 through December 31 of each year.

A fiscal tax year consists of a consecutive 12-month period that ends on the last day of any month, except December. A 52 or 53-week tax year is a tax year that varies from 52 to 53 weeks but does not end on the last day of a month. If you adopt a fiscal tax year, you must keep your books and records, and report your income and expenses using the same tax year. For more information about fiscal tax years, including a 52 or 53-week tax year, see Publication 538.

Generally, you must file Form 1128, Application to Adopt, Change, or Retain a Tax Year, to request IRS approval to change your tax year. See Instructions for Form 1128 for the exceptions. If you qualify for automatic approval, you won't have to pay an administrative fee. If you don't qualify for automatic approval, you must request a decision. See Instructions for Form 1128 for information about administrative fees if you request a decision.

You must use the same accounting method to calculate your taxable income and to keep your books. In addition, you must use an accounting method that clearly shows your income.

To obtain approval, you must file Form 3115. You can obtain approval from the IRS to change your accounting method under the automatic change procedures or the advance consent request procedures. You may have to pay a user fee. For more information, see Instructions for Form 3115.

Certain taxpayers may assume that they have the IRS approval to change their accounting methods. Approval is granted for the tax year for which the taxpayer requests the change (change year), if the taxpayer meets the requirements of the automatic change procedures. No user fee is required for a request filed under an automatic change procedure generally covered in Revenue Procedure 2015-13 (Revenue Procedure 2015-13) that is found on page 419 of Internal Revenue Bulletin 2015-5 (Internal Revenue Bulletin 2015-5), available at IRS.gov/IRB/2015-05_IRB#RP-2015-13 (or its successor). Generally, you must use Form 3115 to request an automatic change. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 3115.

You can record business and personal transactions using different accounting methods. For example, you can calculate your business income using a cash basis method, even if you use a accrual basis method to calculate personal transactions.

If you have two or more separate and distinct businesses, you can use different accounting methods for each, as long as the method clearly reflects the income of each business. They are considered separate and distinct only if you maintain separate books and records for each business.

Most individuals and many sole proprietors who do not have inventory use the cash method because they find it easier to keep records on a cash basis. However, if you need to keep inventory to record your income, you generally will have to use the accrual method for sales and purchases, unless you are a small business taxpayer (defined later in this chapter). For more information, see Inventory, later.

Under the cash method, include in your gross income all income items you receive in cash or implicitly during the tax year. If you receive goods or services, you must include their fair market value in your income.

You receive income implicitly when a sum is credited to your account or made available to you without restriction. It is not necessary for you to be in possession of it. If you authorize another person to be your agent and receive income on your behalf, you are considered to have received it when your agent receives it.

You cannot retain checks or postpone from one tax year to another the taking possession of similar assets to avoid paying taxes on income. You must declare the income in the year in which you receive the assets or when they are made available to you without restrictions.
A receipt for a valid check at the end of the tax year is, implicitly, receipt of the income that year, even though the check cannot be cashed or deposited until the following year.

If someone else pays your debts or if your creditors cancel them, you may have to report all or part of that debt relief as income. If you receive income this way, you receive the income implicitly when the debt is canceled or settled. For more information, see Canceled Debt under Types of Income in Chapter 5.

If you include an amount in income and later have to refund all or part of it, you generally can deduct the refund in the year you make it. If you refund more than $3,000, a special rule applies. To see the details of the special rule, see Refunds in chapter 8 of Publication 17.

Under the cash method, you generally deduct expenses in the tax year in which you actually pay them. This includes business expenses for which you dispute the liability. However, you may not be able to deduct a prepaid expense or that you must capitalize certain costs, as explained below under Uniform Capitalization Rules.

Under a cash basis of accounting method, you generally include an amount in your gross income for the tax year in which all the conditions that establish your right to receive the income have occurred, and you can determine the amount with reasonable accuracy. For a taxpayer with an applicable financial statement or other financial statement as specified by the Secretary, the proof of all the events for a gross income item is considered satisfied no later than when it is taken into account in an applicable financial statement or in some other financial statement similar.

If you include a reasonable estimate of your gross income and then determine that the exact amount is different, take into account the difference in the tax year in which you determine the difference.

Generally, you report an advance payment as income for the year you receive the payment. However, if you receive an advance payment, you may choose to defer the inclusion of the advance payment in your income until the next tax year. You cannot defer the inclusion of the payment beyond that tax year. For more information, see Publication 538 and section 451 of the Internal Revenue Code.

Under an accrual method of accounting, you generally deduct or capitalize an expense of business when both of the following conditions are met: 1. The all-events test is satisfied. The all-events test is satisfied when: 1. All the conditions that establish the fact of the liability have occurred, and 2. The liability can be determined with reasonable accuracy. 2. An economic benefit has occurred.

Generally, you cannot deduct or capitalize a business expense until economic benefit has occurred. If your expense is related to goods or services provided to you, or to your use of goods, economic benefit occurs when the goods or services are provided to you, or as you use the goods. If your expense is related to goods or services that you provide to others, economic benefit occurs as you provide the goods or services. An exception allows certain recurring items to be treated as if they had been incurred during a tax year, even though economic benefit has not occurred. For more information about economic benefit, see Economic Benefit (Beneficio económico) under Accrual Method (Método a base de lo devengado) in Publication 538.

When production, purchase or sale of merchandise constitutes an activity that generates income for your business, you generally have to account for inventory at the beginning and end of your tax year, unless you are a small business taxpayer. If you have to account for inventory, you generally have to use the accrual method of accounting for your purchases and sales. For more information, see Inventory, later.

You cannot deduct business expenses and interest owed to a related person who uses the cash method of accounting until you make the payment and the amount can be included in the related person's gross income. For purposes of this rule, determine the relationship or link at the end of the tax year for which, otherwise, the expenses or interest would be deductible. If a deduction is not allowed under this rule, the rule will continue to apply even if your relationship or link with the related person ends before the expenses or interest can be included in the related person's gross income. Related persons include immediate family members, including siblings (whether of the same parents or half-siblings), your spouse, your ancestors and your lineal descendants. For a list of other related persons, see section 267 of the Internal Revenue Code.

Generally, you can use any combination of accounting methods, whether cash, accrual, and other special methods, if the combination clearly shows your income and expenses, and you use the method consistently. However, the following restrictions apply: If you need to keep an inventory to record your income, you generally have to use the accrual method of accounting for sales and purchases. (However, see Inventory, below). You can use the cash method of accounting for all other income and expense items. If you use the cash method to calculate your income, you have to use the cash method to declare your expenses. If you use an accrual method to declare your expenses, you have to use the accrual method to calculate your income. If you use a combined method that includes the cash method, treat that combined method as the cash method.
Generally, if you produce, purchase or sell merchandise in your business, you must keep an inventory and use the accrual method of accounting for merchandise purchases and sales.

If you are a small business taxpayer, you may elect not to maintain an inventory, but you still must use an inventory accounting method that clearly reflects your income. If you elect not to maintain an inventory, you are not considered to not clearly reflect income if your inventory accounting method treats inventory as materials or supplies that are not incidental, or if it is consistent with your financial accounting treatment of inventory. However, if you elect to maintain an inventory, you generally must use a cost-of-goods-sold (COGS) method and value your inventory annually to determine the cost of goods sold in Part III of Schedule C.

You qualify as a small business taxpayer if (a) your average gross receipts for the 3 previous tax years were $30 million or less and (b) you are not a tax haven (as defined in section 448(d)(3)). If your business has not existed for the entire 3-year tax period used to calculate average gross receipts, base your average on the period that actually existed, and if your business has a predecessor entity, include the gross receipts of the predecessor entity for the 3-year tax period when calculating average gross receipts. If your business (or predecessor entity) had short tax years for any of the years in the 3-year tax period, annualize your business gross receipts for the short tax years that are part of the 3-year tax period. See Publication 538 for more information.

If you account for inventory as non-incidental materials and supplies, you deduct the amounts paid or incurred to acquire or produce the inventory treated as non-incidental materials and supplies in the year in which the inventory is used or consumed for the first time in your business. Inventory treated as non-incidental materials and supplies is used or consumed in your business in the year in which you provide the inventory to your customers.

Your financial inventory accounting treatment is determined with respect to the accounting method you use in your applicable financial statement (as defined in section 451(b)(3)) or, if you do not have an applicable financial statement, with respect to the accounting method you use in your books and records that have been prepared in accordance with your accounting procedures.
If you want to change your inventory accounting method, you must file Form 3115, Application for Change in Accounting Method. See Change in Accounting Method, later.
