You must value your inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year to determine your cost of goods sold (line 42 of Schedule C). To determine the value of your inventory, you need a method to identify the items in your inventory, as well as a method to value those items. Inventory valuation rules cannot be the same for all types of businesses. The method you use to value your inventory must be in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) for similar businesses and must clearly reflect your income. Your inventory management practices must be consistent from year to year.

Under the uniform capitalization rules, you must capitalize direct costs and part of indirect costs of production or resale activities. Include these costs in the base of the property you produce or acquire for resale, instead of claiming them as a current deduction. When you use, sell, or otherwise dispose of the property, you recover the costs through depreciation, amortization, or the cost of goods sold.

You may be subject to the uniform capitalization rules if you perform any of the following activities, unless the property is produced for use in a nonbusiness activity or is held for sale in the ordinary course of a trade or business: Produce real property or tangible personal property. For these purposes, tangible personal property includes motion pictures, sound recordings, video tapes, books, or similar property. Acquire property to resell.

These rules do not apply to the following: 1. Small business taxpayers, as defined above under Inventory. 2. Goods that you produce if your indirect production costs for the goods are $200,000 or less.

If you dispose of business property, you may have a gain or loss to report on your tax return. However, in some cases, you may have a taxable gain or a non-deductible loss. This chapter explains whether you really have a disposition, how to calculate the gain or loss, and where to report the gain or loss.

A like-kind exchange is the exchange of one type of property for another of the same type. It is the most common type of nontaxable exchange. To constitute a like-kind exchange, both the property given up and the property received must be both (a) real property and (b) business or investment property. Report like-kind exchanges on Form 8824, Like-Kind Exchanges. For more information about like-kind exchanges, see chapter 1 of Publication 544.

A sale on credit is the sale of property in which you receive at least one payment after the tax year in which the sale was made. If you provide financing to the buyer of your property, instead of the buyer obtaining a loan or mortgage from a third party, you probably made a sale on credit. For more information about sales on credit, see Publication 537.

Generally, the sale of a business is not the sale of a single asset. Instead, all the assets of the business are sold. Usually, when this occurs, each asset is treated as if it were sold separately for purposes of determining how to treat the gain or loss. Both the buyer and the seller involved in the sale of the business must report to the IRS the allocation of the sale price among the business assets. Use Form 8594, Asset Acquisition Statement Under Section 1060, to provide this information. Both the buyer and the seller must attach Form 8594 to their respective federal income tax returns for the year in which the sale occurred. For more information about the sale of a business, see Publication 544.

The cost or purchase price of the property is usually its basis for calculating gain or loss on its sale or other disposition. However, if you acquired the property by gift, inheritance, or some other means other than buying it, you must use a different basis. For more information about basis, see Publication 551, Basis of Assets.

The adjusted base of a property is generally its original cost or other base, plus certain additions and minus certain deductions, such as depreciation and losses from force majeure events. In determining the gain or loss, the costs of transferring the property to a new owner, such as selling expenses, are added to the adjusted base of the property.

Generally, the amount realized on a disposition is the total amount of money received plus the fair market value of all property or services received. The amount received also includes any of its liabilities assumed by the purchaser, as well as any liabilities to which the property disposed of is subject, such as property taxes or a mortgage.

The fair market value (FMV , for its acronym in English) is the price that the goods would have if they were exchanged between a buyer and a seller, without either having been forced to buy or sell and both having had reasonable knowledge of all relevant facts.

Your gain or loss from the disposition of property generally constitutes a gain or loss recognized for tax purposes. Recognized gains must be included in gross income. Recognized losses are deductible from gross income. However, a gain or loss from certain types of exchanges of property is not recognized. See Non-taxable exchanges, above. In addition, you cannot deduct a loss from the disposition of property held for personal use.

You must classify your gains and losses as ordinary or capital gains or losses. You must do this so that you can calculate your net capital gain or loss. You generally have a capital gain or loss when you dispose of a capital asset. Most of the property you own and use for personal or investment purposes is a capital asset. Certain property you use in your business is not a capital asset. A gain or loss from the disposition of that property is an ordinary gain or loss. However, if you owned the property for more than 1 year, you may be able to treat the gain or loss as a capital gain or loss. These gains or losses are called Section 1231 gains or losses. For more information about ordinary and capital gains, see chapters 2 and 3 of Publication 544.

If you have a capital gain or loss, you must determine whether it is long-term or short-term. Whether a gain or loss is long-term or short-term depends on how long you owned the property before you disposed of it. The period of time you own a property before you dispose of it is called the holding period.

All of the following credits are part of the general business credit. The form you will use to calculate each credit is shown in parentheses. You will also need to complete Form 3800. Some credits have filing deadlines. See the instructions for each credit to make sure it is available for 2024.
This credit applies to the cost of any property that is qualified alternative fuel vehicle refuelling property. For more information, see Form 8911.

This credit applies to startup costs of a defined benefit or defined contribution (including a 401(k) plan), a SIMPLE plan, or a simplified employee pension plan (SEP, for its acronym in English). For more information, see Publication 560, Retirement Plans for Small Business.

This is a non-refundable tax credit for a small business that meets the requirements and that pays or incurs expenses to provide access to people with disabilities. It must pay or incur the expenses to allow its business to comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA). For more information, see Form 8826.
This credit is available to distillers and importers of distilled spirits, as well as to wholesalers of distilled spirits who meet the requirements. For more information, see Form 8906.
This credit applies to wages paid to qualified employees while on family and medical leave, subject to certain conditions. For more information, see Form 8994.
You may be eligible to receive this credit if you have employees and operate a business in an empowerment zone for which the credit is available. For more information, see Form 8844.
This credit is available to contractors who meet the requirements and who build certain homes that are sold for use as a residence. For more information, see Form 8908.
The investment credit is the total of the various credits. For more information, see Form 3468.
Generally, this credit applies to each low-income building placed in service after 1986. For more information, see Form 8586.
This credit is for investments in qualified stock (qualified equity investments) in qualified community development entities. For more information, see Form 8874.
This credit applies to qualified expenses incurred in testing certain drugs for rare diseases and conditions. For more information, see Form 8820.
These credits are for certain clean vehicles placed in service during the tax year. For more information, see Form 8936.
This credit applies to qualified railroad track maintenance expenses paid or incurred during the tax year. For more information, see Form 8900.
This credit is for the sale of renewable electricity produced in the United States or in U.S. territories of qualified energy resources at a qualified facility. For more information, see Form 8835.
This credit provides incentives to businesses to hire individuals from certain groups that have particularly high unemployment rates or other special labor needs. For more information, see Form 5884.

This credit is for carbon dioxide captured at a qualified facility and disposed of in a secure geological storage facility or used in a qualified enhanced oil recovery or natural gas recovery project. For more information, see Form 8933.

This credit provides businesses with an incentive to continue paying the salary of an employee who is serving on active duty in the uniformed services of the United States for more than 30 days. For more information, see Form 8932.

This credit applies to qualified expenses you paid for child care for your employees' children and qualified expenses you paid for resources and services of referred child care. For more information, see Form 8882.
This credit was designed to motivate businesses to increase the amounts they invest in research and development activities, including energy research. For more information, see Form 6765.
This credit applies to the cost of certain health insurance coverage that you provide to certain employees. For more information, see Form 8941.

To claim a general business credit, first you must obtain the forms you need to claim your business credits for the current year. In addition to the form for the credit, you also need to file Form 3800.

This chapter explains mainly business income and how to report it on your tax return, what items are not considered as income, and provides guidelines for selected occupations. If there is a connection between any type of income you receive and your business, the income is business income. There is a connection if it is evident that the payment of the income would not have occurred if you did not have the business. You may have business income even if you do not participate in the activity on a regular full-time basis. Business income from a job you do in addition to your regular employment may be business income. For example, you may be in the business of providing services for a ride-sharing business as a second job. Most business income, such as income from the sale of your products or services, is reported on Schedule C. But income from the sale of business assets, such as land and office buildings, is reported on other forms instead of Schedule C. For information about the sale of business assets, see Chapter 3.

Business income includes amounts received in your business that were properly reported on Form 1099-NEC. This includes amounts reported as compensation for non-employee persons in box 1 of the form. You can find more information in the instructions on the back of Form 1099-NEC that you received.

If you have a business, you may receive a Form 1099-K that represents the total dollar amount of total payment transaction reportable. This may not be the amount you have to report as income, as it may not include all income and may include items that are not included in your income (such as sales tax).
The income you report on Schedule C may be business income and may entitle you to a deduction on line 13 of your Form 1040 or 1040-SR. See Form 8995-A or Form 8995 to figure your deduction, if any.

In your tax return, you must report all income you receive from your business, including income that has not been reported on a Form 1099 filed by the payer, unless the law excludes it. In most cases, you will receive business income in cash, checks, and credit card charges. However, business income may be received in other ways, such as in goods or services. These and other types of income are explained below. If you are a U.S. citizen with business income from sources outside the United States (foreign income), you must report that income on your tax return unless it is income that is exempt from tax under U.S. laws. If you are a resident of a foreign country, you may be able to exclude part or all of your business income from sources in that country. For details, see Publication 54, Tax Guide for U.S. Citizens and Resident Aliens Abroad.

Barter is an exchange of goods or services. You must include in your gross income the fair market value of those goods or services you receive in barter at the time you receive them. If you exchange services with another person and both have agreed in advance as to the value of the services, that value will be accepted as the fair market value, unless otherwise shown to be different.

Si usted es un corredor de bienes raíces que recibe ingresos del alquiler de bienes raíces, o es dueño de un hotel, motel, etc., que provee servicios (servicios de limpieza, etc.) a los huéspedes, declare los ingresos y gastos de alquiler en el Anexo C. Si no es un corredor de bienes raíces o el tipo de dueño descrito en la oración anterior, declare los ingresos y gastos de alquiler en el Anexo E. Para más información, vea la Publicación 527, Residential Rental Property (Propiedad residencial de alquiler).

You are a real estate broker if you are engaged in the business of selling real estate to customers for the purpose of making a profit from those sales. The rental income you receive from the real estate you have for sale to customers is subject to self-employment taxes. However, rental income you receive from real estate you hold for speculation or investment is not subject to self-employment taxes.

Rental income from a mobile home park is subject to self-employment tax if you are a mobile home park owner who works for yourself by providing lots and facilities for mobile homes to be located, as well as substantial services for the convenience of your tenants. Generally, you are considered to provide substantial services to tenants if the services are primarily for the convenience of the tenants and are not normally provided for the purpose of keeping the lots in habitable condition. Services are substantial if the compensation received for the services constitutes a material part of the rental payments of the tenants. Examples of services that are normally not provided for the convenience of the tenants include supervising and maintaining a recreation center provided by the park, delivering a monthly newsletter to the tenants, operating a laundry facility, and assisting tenants in buying or selling their mobile homes. Examples of services that are normally provided for the purpose of keeping the lots in habitable condition for the tenants include sewer, electrical connections, and passable roads.

Advance payments received under a lease that imposes no restrictions on its use or enjoyment are income in the year in which you receive them. This is true regardless of the accounting method or accounting period you use.
A bonus you receive from a landlord for granting a lease is an addition to your rent. Include it in your gross receipts for the year you received it.

If your tenant makes payments to another person under an agreement to pay their debts or obligations, include those payments in your gross receipts when the tenant makes the payments. A common example of this type of income is the payment by the tenant of property taxes on the leased property.

The payments you receive to settle the obligation of a tenant to restore a leased property to its original condition constitute rental income to the extent the payments exceed the adjusted basis of improvements in the leased property that were destroyed, damaged, removed, or disconnected by the tenant.

If you operate a business of renting personal property (equipment, vehicles, formal wear, etc.), include the amount of rent you receive in your gross income on Schedule C. Rent paid in advance and other payments described under Rent of Personal Property, above, may also be received by renting personal property. If you receive any of those payments, include them in your gross income as explained in that section.

Interest received on bills receivable that you have accepted during the regular course of your business transactions is business income. Interest received on loans is business income if you are in the business of lending money.

Dividends are generally business income for stockbrokers. However, for most sole owners of businesses and statutory employees, dividends are not business income. If you own stock as a personal investment that is separate from your business activity, dividends from the stock are not business income. If you receive dividends from commercial insurance premiums that you deducted in a prior year, you must report all or part of your dividends as business income on your tax return. To determine how much you must report, see Recovery of Previously Deducted Items under Other Income, later.

Generally, if your debt is canceled or forgiven, that is not a gift or bequest to you, you must include the amount canceled in your gross income for tax purposes. Report the amount canceled on line 6 of Schedule C if you incurred the debt in a business. If the debt is not a business debt, report the amount canceled on line 8c of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).
The following discussion covers some exceptions to the general rule for canceled debt.

If you have a debt with the seller for goods you bought and the seller reduces the amount you owe, you generally don't have income from the reduction. Unless you are bankrupt or are classified as insolvent, treat the amount of the reduction as a purchase-price adjustment and reduce your basis in the property.
Usted no devenga ingresos de una deuda cancelada en la medida en que el pago de la deuda hubiera resultado en una deducción.

If a canceled debt is excluded from income because it results from a bankruptcy case, the exclusions in situations (2) to (5) do not apply. If the discharge occurs when you are insolvent, the exclusions in situations (3) and (4) do not apply to the extent that you are insolvent.

You can elect to exclude (up to certain limits) the cancellation of commercial real estate debt. If you make this election, you must reduce the basis of your depreciable real estate by the amount excluded. Make this reduction at the beginning of your tax year after the tax year in which the cancellation occurs. However, if you dispose of the property before that date, you must reduce your basis immediately before the disposition.

The qualified real property business indebtedness includes the refinancing of the debts described in the condition (3), previously, but only to the extent that it does not exceed the refinanced debt. If you are the owner of an ignored entity (an entity not considered as separate from its owner (e.g. a single-member LLC)), see Qualified Real Property Business Indebtedness in chapter 1 of Publication 4681 to see if it qualifies for this exclusion. You cannot exclude more than one of the following two amounts: 1. The excess (if any) of: 1. The principal amount due on a qualified real property business indebtedness (immediately before cancellation); over 2. The fair market value (immediately before cancellation) of the real property business that secures the indebtedness, reduced by the principal amount due on any other qualified real property business indebtedness secured by that property immediately before cancellation. 2. The total adjusted bases of depreciable real property that you have immediately before cancellation. These adjusted bases are determined after any reduction of base due to cancellation by bankruptcy or insolvency, or of qualified agricultural indebtedness.

To make this election, complete Form 982 and attach it to your income tax return for the tax year in which the cancellation occurs. You must file your return by the due date (including extensions). If you filed your return for the year on time without making the election, you can still make the election if you file an amended return within 6 months of the due date for filing your return (excluding extensions). For more information, see When To File in the instructions for the form.

Restricted property is property with certain restrictions that affect its value. If you receive restricted stock or other restricted property in exchange for services performed, the fair market value of the property that exceeds your cost is included in your income on Schedule C at the time the restriction is removed. However, you may choose to pay the tax in the year you receive the property. For more information about including restricted property in income, see Publication 525, Taxable and Nontaxable Income.
This rule does not apply to depreciation. Depreciation is recovered under the rules explained below.
In the following situations, you must recover the depreciation deduction. That means that you will include in your income part of or all of the depreciation that you deducted in previous years.

If the commercial use of listed property (which is explained in Chapter 8 under Depreciation) is reduced to 50% or less during a tax year after the tax year in which you placed the property in service, you may have to recover part of the depreciation deduction. You do this by including part of the depreciation you took in previous years in your income on Schedule C. Use Part IV of Form 4797 to figure the amount to include on Schedule C. For more information, see What Is the Business-Use Requirement? in Chapter 5 of Publication 946. That chapter explains how to determine whether the property is used more than 50% in your business.

If you take a deduction under section 179 (which is explained in chapter 8 under Depreciation) for an asset, and before the end of the asset's recovery period the business use percentage is reduced to 50% or less, you must recover part of the section 179 deduction. You do this by including part of the deduction you took in your income on Schedule C. Use Part IV of Form 4797 to figure the amount to include on Schedule C. See chapter 2 of Publication 946 to find out when you recover the deduction.

If you sell or exchange depreciable property and realize a gain, you may have to treat all or part of the gain as ordinary income. Income from the recovery of depreciation is calculated in Part III of Form 4797. For more information, see chapter 4 of Publication 544.

Do not report on Form 8949 or Schedule D any gain or loss from the disposition of property that is not a stock or securities held primarily for sale in the ordinary course of a trade or business. Instead, report these gains and losses on other forms. For more information, see Chapter 3.

You must report the bonds and other evidence of debt that you have received in a sale or exchange of property that is held primarily for sale to customers on Schedule C. You generally report the face amount (less any unstated interest) or the issue price (for OID debt instruments) when you receive them.

If you reduce or suspend your business activities, use Schedule C to report any payment you receive for the loss of business income from insurance or other sources. Report it on Schedule C even if your business is inactive when you receive the payment.

You must include in your gross income the compensation you receive during the tax year as a result of any of the following damages related to your business: Patent infringement. Breach of contract or fiduciary duty. Antitrust injury.

You may be entitled to a deduction from income if it compensates you for actual economic loss. Your deduction is the lesser of the following amounts: The amount you receive or accumulate for damages during the tax year reduced by the amount you pay or incur during the tax year to recover that amount. Your loss for the damage that you have not yet deducted.

If you receive illegal commissions, include them in your income on Schedule C. However, do not include them if you properly treat them as a reduction of a related expense item, a capital expense, or the cost of goods sold.

If you recover an uncollectible debt or any other deduction taken in a prior year, include the recovery in your income on Schedule C. However, if all or part of the deduction in prior years did not reduce your tax, you may exclude the part that did not reduce your tax. If you exclude part of the recovery from income, you must include with your return a statement showing how you calculated the exclusion.
The increase in value of your property does not constitute income until you realize the increase by selling or otherwise disposing of the property in a taxable transaction.

If a tenant erects buildings or makes improvements to his property, the increase in the value of the property due to the improvements does not constitute income to you. However, if the facts indicate that the improvements constitute the payment of rent to you, then the increase in value would constitute income.
Money borrowed through a bona fide loan is not income.
State and local sales taxes are taxes that you had to collect and pay to the state or local government, and that do not constitute income.

Consignments of merchandise for others to sell for you are not sales. Title to the merchandise remains with you, the consignor, even after the consignee possesses the merchandise. Therefore, if you send goods on consignment, you have no gains or losses until the consignee sells the merchandise. The merchandise you have sent on consignment is included in your inventory until it is sold. Do not include merchandise you receive on consignment in your inventory. Include your gain or commission on merchandise consigned to you in your income when you sell the merchandise or when you receive your gain or commission, depending on the accounting method you use.

A short-term lease is a lease (or other agreement for occupancy or use) of a commercial space for 15 years or less. The following rules apply in determining whether the lease is for 15 years or less: Consider renewal options when determining whether the lease is for 15 years or less. However, do not consider any renewal options at fair market value determined at the time of renewal. Two or more successive leases that are part of the same transaction (or a series of related transactions) for the same commercial space or a substantially similar commercial space are treated as one lease.
A commercial space is a real estate property that you rent, occupy or otherwise use as a tenant in your business of selling tangible personal property or services to the general public.

A qualified long-term real property interest is a nonresidential real property interest that is part of, or otherwise present in, your business space and that reverts to the landlord when the lease ends.

Generally, if you exchange business or investment-use real property for other business or investment-use real property of a similar type, no gain or loss is recognized. This means that the gain is not taxable and the loss is not deductible. For more information, see Form 8824.
This section provides information to determine if your income must be reported on Schedule C (Form 1040).

You must report these income regardless of whether they were reported to you on an information return. You are a direct seller if you meet all of the following conditions: 1. Perform one of the following occupations or businesses: 1. Sell or solicit the sale of consumer products, either in a home or elsewhere other than a permanent retail establishment, or to any purchaser on a buy-sell or deposit-commission basis for resale in a home or elsewhere other than a permanent retail establishment. 2. Deliver or distribute newspapers or sales advertising (including any related services directly connected with that occupation or business). 2. Substantially all of your pay (whether paid in cash or not) for the services described above is directly related to sales or other production (including the performance of services) rather than to the number of hours worked. 3. Your services are performed under a written contract between you and the person for whom you perform the services, and the contract states that you will not be treated as an employee for federal tax purposes.

If you are a futures commission merchant or commodities broker, your gains and losses from transactions or purchases and sales of contracts under section 1256 (futures contracts, foreign currency contracts, securities options, non-participating securities options, and futures contracts on securities of the broker) or property related to those contracts (such as securities used to hedge options) are reported on Schedule C. For more information, see sections 1256 and 1402(i).

You are a stockbroker or commodities trader if you are engaged in the business of buying and selling stock or commodities for your own account. As a stockbroker or commodities trader (even if you made the election under section 475(f) of the adjusted market value as a stockbroker or commodities trader), your gain or loss from the disposition of stock or commodities is not reported on Schedule C. For more information about stockbrokers or commodities traders, see Publication 550, Investment Income and Expenses, and Topic 429, Stockbrokers.
If the fees do not meet the above requirements, declare them on line 8z of Annex 1 (Form 1040).

If you are a crew member of a vessel that catches fish or other marine life, your income is reported on Schedule C if you meet all the requirements in Chapter 10 under Crew Member of a Fishing Vessel.

The termination payments you receive as a self-employed insurance agent working for an insurance company for services performed for that company are not reported on Schedule C if all of the following conditions are met: You received payments after the end of your agreement to perform services for the company. You did not perform any services for the company after the end of your service agreement and before the end of the year in which you received the payment. You signed a non-compete agreement with the company for at least 1 year from the date your service agreement ended. The amount of the payments was primarily based on the policies sold by you or credited to your account during the last year of your service agreement or to the extent that those policies remain in force during some period after the end of your service agreement, or both conditions. The amount of the payment was not based in any way on the length of service or the general profits from services performed for the company (regardless of whether eligibility for the payments depended on the length of service).

Insurance company income paid to a self-employed retired insurance agent based on a percentage of commissions received before retirement is reported on Schedule C. In addition, renewal commissions and deferred commissions from sales made before retirement are generally reported on Schedule C. However, renewal commissions paid to the survivor of an insurance agent are not reported on Schedule C.
The fees you receive for services you perform as a public notary are reported on Schedule C. These payments are not subject to self-employment tax (see Instructions for Schedule SE (Form 1040)).

Public officials generally do not report what they earn by serving in public office on Schedule C. This rule applies to payments received by a state-elected tax collector from state funds on the basis of a fixed percentage of the taxes collected. Public office includes any elected or appointed office of the United States or its territories, the District of Columbia, a state or its political subdivisions, or a dependency (instrumentality) wholly owned by any of them. Public officials of state or local governments report their fees received from the public on Schedule C if they are paid solely on the basis of fixed fees and if their services meet the requirements for, but are not covered by, Social Security under a federal-state agreement.
