You are subject to taxes on all income you earn. You cannot avoid taxes by having income paid to a third party.

You must use the chosen method every year for all your purchase discounts. If you use the second method, the balance of credit in the account at the end of your tax year constitutes business income. Under this method, you do not reduce the cost of goods sold by the cash discounts you received. When valuing your closing inventory (end), you cannot reduce the invoice price of the merchandise in existence (on hand) at the end of the tax year by the average or estimate of discounts received for the merchandise.

These are reductions of the list or catalog prices and are generally not written on the invoice or charged to the customer. Do not record these discounts in your accounting books. Instead, use only the net amount as the cost of the merchandise purchased. For more information, see Trade Discounts in Chapter 6.

If the buyer of your property places part or all of the purchase price in escrow, do not include any part of it in gross sales until it is received in fact or implied. However, upon fulfilling the terms of the contract and the escrow agreement, you will have income subject to taxes, even if you do not accept the money until the next year.
The credits you allow customers for returned merchandise and any other discount you make on sales are deductions from gross sales to calculate net sales.
In Chapter 2, the special rules related to the accrual method for recording payments received in advance under the Accrual Method are examined.

If you receive a payment from an insurance company or other type of refund for a loss from a fortuitous event or theft, you must subtract it from the loss when you figure your deduction. You can't deduct the reimbursed part of a loss from a fortuitous event or theft. For more information about losses from fortuitous events or thefts, see Publication 547.

If you produce or buy goods to sell, you can deduct the cost of goods sold from your gross receipts in Schedule C. However, to determine these costs, you must value your inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year. This chapter applies to you if you are a manufacturer, wholesaler, or retailer, or if you carry on any business that produces, buys, or sells goods to generate income. This chapter does not apply to a personal services business, such as the business of a doctor, lawyer, carpenter, or painter. However, if you work in a personal services business and also sell or charge for the materials and supplies that are normally used in your business, this chapter applies to you. There are exceptions for small business taxpayers that may change how you calculate the cost of goods sold for your business. For more information, see chapter 2 ..

If you are a merchant, the initial inventory is the cost of the merchandise (on hand) at the beginning of the year and which you will sell to customers. If you are a manufacturer or producer, it includes the total cost of raw materials, work in process, finished goods and materials and supplies used in the manufacture of the goods (see Inventory in Chapter 2). Usually, the initial inventory will be identical to the closing inventory of the previous year. You must explain any difference in an attachment to your return.

If you donate inventory (goods you sell in the course of your business), the amount you can claim as a charitable donation deduction is the lesser of the fair market value on the day you donated it or its basis. The basis of donated inventory is any cost incurred for the inventory in a prior year that you would otherwise include in your opening inventory for the year of the donation. You must reduce the amount of your charitable donation deduction from your opening inventory. It is not part of the cost of goods sold. If the cost of donated inventory is not included in your opening inventory, the basis of the inventory is zero and you cannot claim a charitable donation deduction. Treat the cost of inventory the same way you would ordinarily under your method of accounting. For example, include the purchase price of inventory purchased and donated in the same year in the cost of goods sold for that year. A special rule applies to certain donations of food inventory. See Publication 526, Charitable Contributions.

The differences between the nominal prices of the items and the actual prices you pay for them are called trade discounts. You must use the prices you pay (not the nominal prices) when you calculate your cost of goods sold. Do not show the amount of the discount separately as a line item of gross income. An automobile dealer must record the cost of a car in inventory reduced by any manufacturer's discount that constitutes a trade discount.

Cash discounts are amounts that your vendors allow you to deduct from your purchase invoices for paying on time. There are two methods of accounting for cash discounts. You can credit them to a separate discount account or deduct them from the total of your purchases for the year. Regardless of the method you use, you must be consistent. If you want to change your method for calculating inventory costs, you must file Form 3115. For more information, see Change in Accounting Method in Chapter 2. If you credit cash discounts to a separate account, you must include this credit balance in your business income when you complete the tax year. If you use this method, do not reduce your cost of goods sold by the amount of cash discounts.
You must deduct all your returns and discounts from the total of your purchases during the year.

If you remove merchandise for personal use or for your family, you must exclude this cost from the total amount of merchandise purchased for sale. Do this by crediting the purchases or sales account with the cost of the merchandise you removed for personal use. You also must charge the amount to your advance account. An advance account is a separate account you must maintain to keep track of business income you remove to pay personal and family expenses. As explained above, you also use it to keep track of merchandise removed for personal or family use. This account is also known as a withdrawal account or personal account.

Labor costs are generally a component of cost of goods sold only in manufacturing or mining businesses. Small merchants (wholesalers, retailers, etc.) usually do not have labor costs that can be properly charged to cost of goods sold. In a manufacturing business, labor costs that can be properly assigned to cost of goods sold include direct and indirect labor used to convert raw materials into finished products that can be sold.

Direct labor costs are the salaries you pay to employees who devote all of their time to working directly in the manufacture of products. They also include a portion of the salaries you pay to employees who work directly in the products on a part-time basis, if you can determine that portion of the salaries.

The indirect labor costs are the salaries you pay to the employees who perform general factory functions that do not have an immediate or direct connection with the manufacture of the product for sale, but that are part of the necessary manufacturing process.

Other labor costs that cannot be properly charged to cost of goods sold may be deducted as selling or administrative expenses. Generally, the only types of labor costs that may be properly charged to cost of goods sold are direct or indirect labor costs, as well as certain other types of costs treated as properly charged overhead to the manufacturing process, as explained more fully under Line 39 — Other Costs.

Materials and supplies, such as equipment and chemicals, used in the manufacture of goods are charged to the cost of goods sold. Those not used in the manufacturing process are treated as deferred charges. They are deducted as business expenses when used. Business expenses are explained in chapter 8.
Examples of other costs incurred in the manufacturing or mining processes that you charge to your cost of goods sold are the following.

Packaging and packaging materials that are an integral part of the manufactured product are part of the cost of goods sold. If they are not an integral part of the manufactured product, the costs of the same constitute shipping or sales expenses.
Delivery freight costs, express delivery freight and delivery freight for raw materials, supplies used in production and merchandise purchased for sale are all part of cost of goods sold.

General expenses include expenses such as rent, heating, lighting, electricity, insurance, depreciation, taxes, maintenance, labor and supervision. General expenses in which you incur as direct and necessary expenses of the manufacturing operation are included in your cost of goods sold.

Deduct the value of your closing inventory (including, as appropriate, the assignable portion of the cost of raw materials and supplies, direct labor, and overhead) from line 40. Closing inventory at the end of the year is also known as closing inventory or final inventory. Your closing inventory will generally become the inventory at the beginning of the following tax year.
When you subtract your closing inventory (inventory at the end of the year) from the cost of goods available for sale, the remaining is your cost of goods sold during the tax year.

After calculating your gross business income (Chapter 5) and cost of goods sold (Chapter 6), you're ready to calculate your gross profit. You need to determine your gross profit before you can deduct any business expenses. These expenses are explained in Chapter 8.

Calculate your gross income by first calculating your net income. Calculate net income on line 3 of Schedule C (line 3) by subtracting any refunds and discounts (line 2) from gross income (line 1). Refunds and discounts include cash or credit refunds to customers, discounts and other discounts from the actual purchase price. Then, subtract cost of goods sold (line 4) from net income (line 3). The result is your gross income from the business.

You do not have to calculate the cost of goods sold if the sale of merchandise is not a factor that generates income for your business. Your gross income is equal to your net receipts (gross receipts less any refunds, allowances, or other discounts). Most professions and businesses that sell services instead of products can calculate gross income directly from net receipts in this way.
This illustration of the gross profit section of a retail business's income statement shows how gross profit is calculated.

At the end of each business day, make sure your records match your actual cash and credit card entries for the day. You may find it helpful to use cash registers to keep track of the entries. You should also use an appropriate billing system and maintain a separate bank account for your business.

Compare this figure with the inventory at the end of the previous year. Normally, the two amounts should be equal.Compare this figure with the inventory at the end of the previous year. Normally, the two amounts should be equal.

If you take inventory items for your personal use (to use yourself, provide to your family, give as personal gifts, etc.), make sure to remove them from the cost of goods sold. For details on how to adjust the cost of goods sold, see Goods taken from inventory in Chapter 6.

If you operate a retail or wholesale business, you can verify the accuracy of your gross profit figure. First, divide gross profit by net sales. The resulting percentage measures the average difference between the cost of goods sold and the selling price of the merchandise. Then, compare that percentage with your profit margin policy. A small or no difference between these two percentages shows that your gross profit figure is accurate. A large difference between these two percentages could indicate that you did not calculate sales, purchases, inventory, or other cost items accurately. You will need to determine the reason for the difference.

You operate a retail business. On average, you add a profit margin to the merchandise so that you will earn a 331/3% gross profit on your sales. The net income (gross income less returns and discounts) shown on your income statement is $300,000. Your cost of goods sold is $200,000. This results in gross profits of $100,000 ($300,000 − $200,000). To verify the accuracy of the results for this year, you divide the gross profits ($100,000) by the net income ($300,000). The resulting percentage of 331/3% confirms your 331/3% profit margin percentage.

If your business has income from a source other than the regular business operations, report the income on line 6 of Schedule C and add it to the gross business income. The result is the gross business income. Examples include income from a savings account that earns interest, income from the sale of scrap (waste), income from certain credits and refunds of fuel taxes and amounts recovered from bad debts.

You can deduct the costs of operating your business. These costs are known as business expenses. They are costs that you do not have to capitalize or include in the cost of goods sold, but you can deduct in the current year. To be deductible, a business expense has to be both ordinary and necessary. An ordinary expense is one that is common and accepted in the scope of your business. A necessary expense is one that is useful and appropriate for your business. An expense does not have to be indispensable to be considered necessary. For more information on the general rules for deducting business expenses, see section 162 and its regulations. If you have an expense that is partly business and partly personal, separate the personal part from the business part. The personal part is not deductible.

SEP, SIMPLE, and qualified plans allow you and your employees to save for retirement with tax advantages. You can deduct contributions you make to the plan on behalf of your employees on line 19 of Schedule C. If you are the sole owner of a business, you can deduct contributions you make to the plan for yourself on line 16 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). You can also deduct trustee fees if the contributions to the plan do not cover them. Income generated on contributions generally remains free of tax until you or your employees receive distributions from the plan. You may also be able to claim a credit if you start a new qualified defined benefit or defined contribution plan (including a 401(k) plan), a SIMPLE or SEP plan. For more information about this credit and the self-employment and spouse participation credits, see Form 8881 and its instructions separately. Under certain plans, employees may have you contribute to the plan limited amounts of their pay before taxes. These amounts (and the income generated on them) generally remain free of tax until your employees receive distributions from the plan. For more information about retirement plans for small businesses, see Publication 560. Publication 590-A, Contributions to Individual Retirement Arrangements (IRAs), explains other ways to save for retirement with tax advantages.

Rent is any amount you pay for the use of a property that you do not own. You can generally deduct rent as a business expense only if the rent is for a property that you use in your business. If you have or will have capital invested in the property or will receive title to the property, you cannot deduct rent for that property.

You cannot take a deduction for unreasonable rents. Normally, the question of reasonableness arises only if you and the landlord are related. Rent paid to a related person is reasonable if it is the same amount that you would pay to an unrelated person for the use of the same property. Rent is not unreasonable just because it is calculated on the basis of a percentage of gross income. Related persons include immediate family members, including siblings (whether of the same parents or half-siblings), your spouse, your ancestors and your lineal descendants. For a list of other related persons, see Section 267 of the Internal Revenue Code.

If you rent your home and use part of it as your business location, you may be able to deduct the rent you pay for that part. You must meet the business use requirements for your home. For more information, see Business Use of Your Home, later.

Generally, rental payments made in the course of your business are deductible in the year in which they are paid or accrued. If you pay the rent in advance, you may deduct only the amount that corresponds to your use of the leased property during the tax year. You may deduct the remainder of your payment only during the period to which it corresponds.
In Annex C you can deduct the payment of several federal, state, local and foreign taxes directly attributable to your business.

You can deduct state income taxes on gross income (as opposed to net income) directly attributable to your business. If you itemize your deductions, you can deduct other state and local income taxes on Form 1040, Schedule A.

You can deduct Social Security, Medicare, and federal unemployment taxes (FUTA, for its acronym in English) that you paid as an employer from your own funds. Payroll taxes are briefly explained in Chapter 1. You can also deduct payments made as an employer to a state unemployment compensation fund or to a state disability benefits fund. Deduct those payments as taxes.
You can deduct half of your self-employment taxes on line 15 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Self-employment taxes are explained in Chapter 1 and Chapter 10.
You can deduct any state or local property tax imposed on property used in your business. You can also deduct registration fees for the right to use the property within a state or local area.

In Annex C you can deduct real estate taxes you pay for your business property. Deductionable real estate taxes are all state, local or foreign real estate taxes that are levied for the general welfare of the public. The tax authority must levy these taxes uniformly at a similar rate on all properties under its jurisdiction and the income must be for community or governmental purposes in general.

Treat any sales tax you pay for a service or for the purchase or use of property as part of the cost of the service or property. If the service or the cost or use of the property is a business expense that is deductible, you can deduct the tax as part of that service or cost. If the property is merchandise you buy for resale, the sales tax is part of the cost of the merchandise. If the property is depreciable, add the sales tax to the base for depreciation. For more information about the base of the property, see Publication 551. Do not deduct state and local sales taxes that you have to collect and pay to the state or local government. Do not include those taxes in your gross receipts or gross sales.

In Annex C you can deduct all consumption taxes on items of use and consumption that are ordinary and necessary expenses of operating your business. Consumption taxes on items of use and consumption are briefly explained in Chapter 1.

Generally, taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, and other motor fuels used in your business are included as part of the cost of fuels. Do not deduct these taxes as a separate item. You may be able to get a credit or refund for federal excise taxes on motor fuels used for certain purposes. For more information, see Publication 510.
This section briefly explains the types of travel and meal expenses that you can deduct on Schedule C.

Generally, your tax home is your principal place of business, regardless of where you maintain your family home. It includes the entire city or general area in which your business is located. See Publication 463 for more information. The following is a brief explanation of the expenses you can deduct.
You can deduct the cost of travel by air, train, bus or car between your home and your business destination.
You can deduct the fees for these and other types of transportation between the airport or station and your hotel, or between the hotel and your place of work away from your home.

You can deduct the cost of operating and maintaining your vehicle while traveling away from home for business purposes. You can deduct the actual expenses or the standard mileage rate (which was explained above under Business Auto and Truck Expenses), as well as tolls and parking expenses related to business. If you rent a car while away from home for business purposes, you can only deduct the portion of the expenses that are related to business use.

You can deduct the cost of meals and lodging if your business trip is one night or is long enough that you need to stop to sleep or rest in order to perform your duties properly. You can use your actual expenses or the standard meal allowance to figure your deduction. In most cases, you can deduct only 50% of your meal expenses. See Publication 463 for more information.
You can deduct dry cleaning and laundry expenses while you are traveling for business.
You can deduct the cost of business calls while traveling for business purposes, including business communications by fax or other communication devices.

To deduct expenses related to the part of your home (residence) used for business, you must meet specific requirements. However, your deduction may be limited. To qualify to claim expenses for business use of your home, you must meet the following requirements: 1. Your use of the business part of your home must be: 1. Exclusive (however, see Exceptions to exclusive use, below), 2. Regular and 3. For your business. 2. The business part of your home must be one of the following: 1. Your principal place of business (which is defined below), 2. A place to meet or deal with your patients or customers in the normal course of your business or 3. A separate structure (not attached to your home) that you use in connection with your business.

To qualify under the exclusive use requirement, you must use a specific area of your home only for your occupation or business. The area used for business can be a room or other separate and identifiable space. The space does not have to be marked by a permanent wall divider. You do not meet the conditions of the exclusive use requirement if you use the area in question for both business and personal purposes.
To get an explanation of these exceptions, see Publication 587, Business Use of Your Home.

To qualify under the requirement of regular use, you must use a specific area of your home in a continuous manner for business. You do not satisfy the requirement if your use of the area for business is only occasional or incidental, even if you do not use the area for any other purpose.

Yes, if, after considering your places of business, your home cannot be identified as your principal place of business, you cannot deduct expenses for an office in your home. However, to see other ways to qualify for deducting expenses for an office in your home, see Publication 587.
Do not include in entry (2), above, your deduction for one-half of self-employment taxes. Use Form 8829, Expenses for Business Use of Your Home, to figure your deduction.

The IRS provides a simplified method for determining your expenses for using your home for business purposes. The simplified method is an alternative to the calculation and justification of actual expenses. In most cases, you will calculate your deduction by multiplying $5 by the area of your home used for qualified business use. The area used to calculate your deduction is limited to 300 square feet. For more information, see Instructions for Form 1040, Schedule C.
For more information about the deduction of business use of your home, see Publication 587.

Generally, you must capitalize the cost of acquiring or producing tangible personal property used in your occupation or business, such as buildings, equipment, or furniture. However, if you choose to use the safe harbor for de minimis for tangible personal property, you may deduct the amounts of de minimis paid to acquire or produce certain tangible personal property if these amounts are deducted by you for financial accounting purposes or in maintaining your books and records. If you have an applicable financial statement, you may use this safe harbor to deduct the amounts paid for tangible personal property of up to $5,000 per item or invoice. If you do not have an applicable financial statement, you may use the de minimis safe harbor to deduct the amounts paid for tangible personal property of up to $2,500 per item or invoice. The amounts that qualify under this de minimis safe harbor must be included as other expenses in Part V of Schedule C.
For more information on how to make this election and the requirements for using the safe harbor for tangible property, see Tangible Property Regulations (Regulation on tangible property).

You may also be able to deduct the following expenses: Advertising. Bank fees. Donations to business organizations. Educational expenses. Expenses related to a disability. Interview expenses. Licenses and fees. Moving machinery. Services to help you get another job. Fines and penalties you pay for late filing or for breaking a contract. Repairs and maintenance of real property or tangible personal property. Reimbursement of income. Supplies and materials. Utilities.

Generally, you cannot deduct the following business expenses: Illegal bribes and commissions. Charitable donations. Demolition expenses. Business, social, athletic, lunch, airline, and hotel club dues. Entertainment expenses. Improvements to real or tangible personal property. The improvements are amounts paid for improvements to your property, restoration of your property, or work that adapts your property to a new or different use. Lobbying expenses. Fines and penalties you pay to a governmental agency or instrumentality because you violated the law. Personal, maintenance, or family expenses. Political contributions. Settlement agreements or payments related to sexual harassment or sexual abuse if the settlement agreement or payment is subject to a nondisclosure agreement.

If you use your car or truck in your business, you may be able to deduct the cost of operating and maintaining your vehicle. You may also be able to deduct other local transportation costs and business travel costs that require you to spend the night away from home.

Local transportation expenses do not include expenses incurred during trips away from your home that require you to spend the night away from it. These expenses are deductible as travel expenses and are explained more below under Travel and Meals. However, if you use your car during trips away from your home that require you to spend the night away from it, use the rules in this section to figure the car expense deduction. Generally, your home state is your principal place of business, regardless of where you maintain your family home.

Your place of business may be your home if you have an office in your home that meets the requirements to be a principal place of business. For more information, see Use of Your Home as a Business Location, later.

Para viajes de negocios, puede utilizar el método de tarifa estándar por milla o los gastos reales. Para viajes de negocios que requieran pernoctar fuera de su domicilio, puede utilizar el método de tarifa estándar por milla o los gastos reales.

You cannot use the standard mileage rate if: 1. You operate five or more vehicles at the same time; 2. You claimed a deduction for depreciation on the vehicle using a method other than the straight-line method, for example, ACRS (Accelerated Cost Recovery System) or MACRS (Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System); 3. You claimed a deduction on the vehicle under section 179; 4. You claimed the special depreciation allowance on the vehicle; 5. You claimed the actual expenses of a leased vehicle; or 6. You are a rural carrier who has received a qualified reimbursement.

In addition to using the standard mileage rate, you can deduct all parking and toll charges that are related to your business. (Parking charges that you pay for parking the car at your workplace are non-deductible commuting expenses.)
For more information about the rules for claiming automobile and truck expenses, see Publication 463.

Generally, you can deduct the amounts you reimburse your employees for automobile and truck expenses. The reimbursement you deduct and how you do so will depend in part on whether you reimburse expenses under an accountable plan or a nonaccountable plan. For more details, see Publication 15. That publication explains accountable and nonaccountable plans, and tells you whether you must report the reimbursements to your employees on your employees' Form W-2s.

If you acquire property for use in your business that you expect to last more than 1 year, you generally can't deduct the full cost as a business expense in the year you acquire it. You must spread the cost over more than 1 tax year and deduct part of the cost each year on Schedule C. This method of deducting the cost of business property is called depreciation. The explanation offered here is brief. You can find more information about depreciation in Publication 946.

You can depreciate property if it meets all of the following requirements: It must be property that you own. It must be used in the business or held for the production of income. You can never depreciate inventory (explained in Chapter 2) because it is not held for use in your business. It must have a useful life that extends substantially beyond the year in which it is placed in service. It must have a determinable useful life, which means it must be something that wears out, deteriorates, is exhausted, becomes obsolete, or loses its value by natural causes. You can never depreciate the cost of land because land does not wear out, become obsolete, or be exhausted. It cannot be property that is excluded. This includes property that is put to use and disposed of in the same year.

Generally, you don't depreciate repair or maintenance costs if they don't improve your property. Instead, you deduct these amounts on line 21 of Schedule C. Improvements are amounts paid for improvements to your property, repairs to your property, or work that adapts your property to a new or different use.

You can make an election to treat certain repairs or replacements in your occupation or business as improvements subject to depreciation. This election is available if you treat these amounts as capital expenditures in your regular books and records used to compute your income and expenses.

The method for depreciating most business and investment property placed in service after 1986 is called the Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System (MACRS). MACRS is explained in detail in Publication 946.

You can elect to deduct a limited amount of the cost of certain depreciable property in the year you place the property in service. This deduction is known as the Section 179 deduction. The maximum amount you can elect to deduct during 2024 is generally $1,220,000 (higher limits apply to certain property). This limit is generally reduced by the amount by which the cost of the property placed in service during the tax year exceeds $3,050,000. The total amount of depreciation (including the Section 179 deduction) you can take for a passenger automobile that you use in your business and that was placed in service for the first time in 2024 is $12,400 ($20,400 if you take the special depreciation allowance for qualified passenger automobiles placed in service in 2024). Special rules apply to trucks and vans. For more information, see Publication 946. This explains what property qualifies for the deduction, what limits apply to the deduction, and when and how to claim the deduction. Your election under Section 179 for the cost of any utility vehicle (SUV, by its abbreviation in English) and certain other vehicles is limited to $30,500. For more information, see the Instructions for Form 4562 or Publication 946.

Use Form 4562, Depreciation and Amortization if you claim any of the following: Depreciation of property placed in service during the tax year. A deduction under section 179. Depreciation of any listed property (whether or not placed in service during the tax year).
You cannot deduct your own salary or any withdrawals you make from your business for personal purposes. As a sole owner of a business, you are not an employee of the business.

Some of the ways in which you can pay your employees are shown below: Awards. Bonuses. Educational expenses. Marginal benefits (explained below). Loans or advances that you do not expect employees to repay if they are for personal services that have actually been performed. Property that you transfer to an employee as payment for services. Reimbursements of the business expenses of employees. Sick pay. Vacation pay.

Generally, you can deduct the cost of fringe benefits you provide on your Schedule C in any category in which the cost falls. For example, if you allow an employee to use a car or other property you rent, deduct the cost of the rental contract as a rental expense. If you own the property, include your deduction for its cost or other basis as a deduction under section 179 or a deduction for depreciation. You may be able to exclude all or part of the fringe benefits you provide from your employees' wages. For more information about fringe benefits and the exclusion of fringe benefits, see Publication 15-B.

Generally, you can deduct the premiums you pay for the following types of insurance related to your business: 1. Fire, theft, flood, or similar insurance. 2. Credit insurance that covers losses on commercial accounts receivable. 3. Group health and medical insurance for employees, including long-term care insurance. 4. Liability insurance. 5. Professional liability insurance that covers your personal liability for professional negligence resulting from injuries or damage to patients or clients. 6. Workers' compensation insurance established by state law that covers any claims for physical injuries or diseases related to work suffered by employees in your business, regardless of responsibility. 7. Contributions to the state unemployment insurance fund are deductible as taxes if they are considered taxes under state law. 8. Business expense insurance that pays the business' general expenses during periods of long disability caused by an injury or illness. 9. Automobile and other vehicle insurance that covers vehicles used in your business against liability, damage, and other losses. If you operate a vehicle in part for personal use, deduct only the portion of the insurance premium that applies to the business use of the vehicle. If you use the standard mileage rate to calculate your automobile expenses, you cannot deduct any automobile insurance premium. 10. Life insurance that covers your employees if you are not the direct or indirect beneficiary of the contract. 11. Business interruption insurance that pays the profits you lose if your business closes due to a fire or other cause.

You cannot deduct premiums for the following types of insurance: 1. Self-insurance reserves. You cannot deduct amounts credited to a reserve established as self-insurance. This applies even if you cannot obtain commercial insurance coverage for certain business risks. However, your actual losses may be deductible. For more information, see Publication 547. 2. Income loss. You cannot deduct premiums for a policy that pays for loss of your income due to illness or disability. However, see entry (8) above. 3. Certain life and annuity insurance. 1. Under contracts issued before June 9, 1997, you cannot deduct premiums for a life insurance policy that covers you, an employee, or any other person with a financial interest in your business if you are the direct or indirect beneficiary of the policy. You are included among the possible beneficiaries of the policy if the owner of the policy is required to use the proceeds of the policy to pay off a loan you have made to the business. A person has a financial interest in your business if that person is the owner or partial owner of the business, or has loaned money to the business. 2. Under contracts issued after June 8, 1997, you generally cannot deduct premiums for any life insurance, endowment, or annuity policy if you are the direct or indirect beneficiary. This prohibition applies regardless of who is covered by the policy. 4. Loan-related insurance. If you obtain a policy on your life or the life of another person with a financial interest in your business to obtain or protect a commercial loan, you cannot deduct the premiums as a business expense. You also cannot deduct the premiums as interest on commercial loans or as a financing expense for commercial loans.
It is possible that you may be able to deduct the amount you pay for medical and dental insurance, and for qualified long-term care insurance for you and your family.

See Form 8962, Premium Tax Credit (PTC) (Health Insurance Premium Tax Credit or PTC, for short) and its instructions separately and use Publication 974 if the health insurance plan established, or that is considered established, under your business was obtained through the Health Insurance Marketplace and you are claiming the health insurance premium tax credit.

You cannot deduct expenses in advance, even if you pay them in advance. This rule applies to any expense paid with sufficient advance to effectively create an asset with a useful life that extends substantially beyond the end of the current tax year.

Certain taxpayers are required to limit the deduction of business interest expenses. See the Instructions for Form 8990 to determine if you are required to limit the deduction of business interest expenses, who must file Form 8990, and how certain businesses may elect that the limitation of business interest expenses does not apply to them. You cannot use Schedule C to deduct the interest you pay on personal loans. If a loan is partly business and partly personal, you must split the interest between the personal and business parts.

Below are some additional points you should take into account: How to allocate the interest between personal and business use. Limiting business interest. When to deduct the interest. Rules for a loan with a below-market interest rate. (This is generally a loan for which no interest is charged or for which the interest is charged at a rate below the corresponding federal rate).

Professional and legal fees, such as fees charged by accountants, which are ordinary and necessary expenses directly related to the operation of your business are deducted in Schedule C. However, you usually cannot deduct legal fees you pay to acquire business assets. Add them to the basis of your property. If the fees include payments for personal work (such as writing a will), you can take a business deduction only for the part of the fee related to your business.

You can deduct the cost of preparing the part of your tax return that relates to your business as a sole proprietor or as a statutory employee. You can also deduct the amount you pay or incur to resolve certain tax deficiencies related to your business as a sole proprietor or as a statutory employee.

A non-resident alien (and certain resident aliens) from a country with which the United States has a tax treaty on income may be eligible for certain benefits. Most treaties require that the non-resident alien be a resident of the treaty country in the year in which the benefit is claimed. However, in the case of certain students, apprentices, teachers, or researchers, some treaties only require that the non-resident alien be a resident of the treaty country immediately before coming to the United States.

You can access the tax treaty tables on IRS.gov/TreatyTables. In addition, you can access the text of the U.S. income tax treaties on the Treasury Department's website as soon as they are available to the public, as well as the technical explanations of the tax treaties that accompany them. Note that the treaty documents and TIEAs are available on that website after they are signed and before they are ratified and enter into force. The full text of the tax treaties is also available on IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. For more information about tax treaties, go to IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Tax-Treaties. Generally, you can make arrangements to reduce or eliminate the withholding tax on wages and other income that qualifies for treaty benefits. See Income with Treaty Benefits in Chapter 8.

Foreign nonresident income is gross income on which the tax is limited by a tax treaty. Foreign nonresident income includes, for example, dividends from sources within the United States that are taxed at a rate under a tax treaty that does not exceed 15%. Foreign nonresident income is gross income of a foreign nonresident on which the tax is not limited by a tax treaty. To determine the tax on treaty income, calculate the tax on each item of income separately at the reduced rate that applies to that item under the tax treaty. To determine the tax on non-treaty income, calculate the tax either at the 30% rate or at the graduated rate, depending on whether the income is directly related to your occupation or business in the United States. Your tax liability is the sum of the treaty income tax plus the non-treaty income tax, but it may not be greater than the tax liability calculated as if the tax treaty had not come into effect.

The paragraphs below briefly explain the exemptions that are available under tax treaties for personal services income, remittances, study scholarships, professional development scholarships, and capital gains income. The conditions for claiming the exemptions vary according to each tax treaty. For more information about the conditions under a particular tax treaty, download the full text of most tax treaties with the United States at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. Technical explanations for many of those treaties also are available at that website. Also see Publication 901. The benefits of tax treaties also cover income such as dividends, interest, rents, royalties, pensions, and annuities. This type of income may be exempt from U.S. tax or subject to a reduced rate of tax. For more information, see Publication 901 or the tax treaty that applies.

Some tax treaties on income contain a provision on “independent personal services”, which allows residents of a treaty country to exempt income earned as an independent contractor or as a self-employed person from US taxes if they are present in the United States for a period that does not exceed a certain number of days and if they do not have a regular fixed base available in the United States.

According to many tax treaties on income, teachers or professors who are non-resident aliens and who temporarily visit the United States with the principal purpose of teaching in a university or other educational institution accredited are not subject to United States income tax on compensation received for teaching during the first 2 or 3 years after their arrival in the United States. Many treaties also provide an exemption for participating in research. Generally, the teacher or professor must be in the United States primarily to teach, lecture, instruct or participate in research. A substantial part of that person's time must be devoted to those tasks. The normal duties of a teacher or professor include not only the formal work in a classroom involving lessons, demonstrations or other regularly scheduled student participation activities, but also the less formal method of presenting ideas in seminars or other informal groups and in joint efforts in the laboratory. If you entered the United States as a non-resident alien, but are now a resident alien, the treaty exemption may still apply. See Foreign Students, Apprentices, Interns, Teachers, Professors and Researchers Who Became Resident Aliens, later, under Resident Aliens.

All treaties have provisions for the exclusion of income earned by certain employees of a foreign government. However, there is a difference between the treaties as to who qualifies for this benefit. Under many treaties, foreign residents of the United States do not qualify. Under most treaties, foreign persons who are not nationals or subjects of the foreign country do not qualify. Employees of a foreign government should carefully read the relevant treaty to determine if they qualify for these benefits. Chapter 10 of this publication also has information for employees of a foreign government.

Most treaties provide for the exemption of gains from the sale or exchange of tangible personal property. Generally, gains from the sale or exchange of real property located in the United States are taxable.
Foreign residents may be eligible for treaty benefits in the situations described below.

Foreign residents generally do not qualify for treaty benefits, because most tax treaties contain a “savings clause” that preserves or “safeguards” the right of the United States to tax its citizens and residents as if the tax treaty had not been put into effect. However, many tax treaties have exceptions to the savings clause, which might allow a foreign resident to continue claiming treaty benefits. Some exceptions to the savings clause apply to all foreign residents (for example, under the treaty between the United States and the People’s Republic of China); others apply only to foreign residents who are not legal permanent residents of the United States (green card holders). In certain cases, you do not need to report your income on Form 1040 or 1040-SR because the income is exempt from United States tax under a treaty. However, if the income has been reported as taxable income on a Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099, or another information return, you must report it on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or 1040-SR (for example, line 1a in the case of wages and salaries reported in box 1 of Form W-2). Enter the amount for which treaty benefits are claimed, in parentheses, on line 8z of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Enter “Exempt income” in the space provided, the name of the treaty country, and the treaty article that provides the exemption. For income that is subject to a reduced rate of tax under the treaty, instead of an exemption, attach a written statement to Form 1040 or 1040-SR that shows the calculation of the reduced rate of tax, the name of the treaty country, and the treaty article that establishes the reduced rate of tax. Enter this tax on line 16 of Form 1040 or 1040-SR. Check the box and enter “Tax from attached statement” in the space next to the box.

Pursuant to the tax treaties with Canada and Germany, if a U.S. resident receives Social Security benefits from Canada or Germany, those benefits are treated for U.S. income tax purposes as if they were received under the U.S. Social Security Act. If you receive Social Security benefits from Canada or Germany, report them on line 1 of your Social Security Work Sheet in the Instructions for Form 1040 for purposes of determining the taxable amount you must report on line 6b of Form 1040 or 1040-SR. You are not required to file Form 8833 for those benefits.

Generally, you must be a foreign student, apprentice, intern, trainee, teacher, professor, or researcher who is not a resident of the United States to claim a treaty exemption for foreign remittances for study and maintenance in the United States, for scholarships, fellowships, and grants for professional development, and for salaries or other compensation for personal services. Once you become a resident of the United States, you generally can no longer claim a treaty exemption for this income. However, if you entered the United States as a nonresident alien, but now are a resident alien for United States tax purposes, the treaty exemption will continue to apply to you if the treaty tax safeguard clause (explained above) provides an exception for this and you otherwise meet the requirements for the treaty exemption (including any deadline for claiming treaty exemptions, explained below). This is true even if you are a nonresident alien spouse treated as a resident, as explained in Chapter 1. If you qualify under an exception to the treaty tax safeguard clause, you can avoid withholding on income by delivering to the payer a Form W-9 with the statement required by the Instructions for Form W-9.

In certain cases, you do not need to report income on your Form 1040 or 1040-SR because the income is exempt from U.S. income tax under a treaty. However, if the income has been reported as taxable income on a Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099, or another information return, you must report it on the appropriate line of your Form 1040 or 1040-SR (for example, line 1a, amounts reported in box 1 of Form W-2). Enter the amount for which treaty benefits are claimed, in parentheses, on line 8z of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Enter in English in the space provided “Exempt income”, the name of the treaty country and the treaty article that provides the exemption.

If you claim benefits under a treaty that invalidate or modify any provision of the Internal Revenue Code and, in claiming these benefits, your tax is reduced, or could be reduced, you must attach to your tax return a properly completed Form 8833. See Exceptions, below, for the situations in which you are required to file Form 8833.
These are the most common situations for which a Form 8833 is required. For additional provisions, see the instructions for Form 8833.

You do not have to file Form 8833 for any of the following situations: 1. Claim a reduced rate under a treaty for the withholding of interest, dividends, rents, royalties, or other fixed or determinable annual or periodic income normally subject to the 30% rate. 2. Claim that a treaty reduces or modifies the taxation of income from (of the) personal services; dependents; pensions; annuities; social security and other public pensions; or income from artists, athletes, students, apprentices, or teachers. This includes scholarships and professional development grants taxable. 3. Claim a reduction or modification of the taxation of income under an International Social Security Agreement (Social Security Treaty) or a diplomatic or consular agreement. 4. Are a partner in a partnership or a beneficiary of a trust or estate and the partnership, trust or estate files the required information on its return. 5. Payments or income items that would otherwise be required to be disclosed do not exceed $10,000. 6. Claim treaty benefits for amounts that are: 1. Reported to you on a Form 1042-S; and 2. Received by you: 1. As a related person of a U.S. partnership as provided in Section 6038A (relating to reporting on Form 5472 filed by U.S. corporations that are 25% owned by a foreign person); or 2. As a direct owner of a U.S. financial institution account or a qualified intermediary, or as a direct owner, beneficiary, or partner of a foreign partnership or trust of retention, of that U.S. financial institution, qualified intermediary, or foreign partnership or trust of retention.
If you are required to file a treaty benefits return but do not, you may be subject to a $1,000 penalty for each failure.

Employees of an international organization may be exempt from their salaries under a provision, if there is one, in the international agreement that establishes the international organization, or by satisfying the requirements for obtaining an exemption for those salaries under the United States tax law. An “international organization” is an organization designated by the President of the United States by Executive Order to qualify for the privileges, exemptions, and immunities provided in the Law on the Immunities of International Organizations. The exemption explained in this chapter applies only to pay received for official services performed for a foreign government or international organization. Other income from U.S. sources received by persons who qualify for this exemption may be fully taxable or may be given favorable treatment under a treaty tax provision that applies. The appropriate treatment of this type of income (interest, dividends, etc.) is explained elsewhere in this publication.

First, you must consult the provisions of the tax exemption under the Vienna Conventions or a bilateral consular convention, if any, to see if your salaries qualify for the U.S. income tax exemption under those provisions. Generally, you are not entitled to the available income tax exemption under the Vienna Conventions or a bilateral consular convention if you are a U.S. citizen or a foreign resident of the United States. For more information on the Vienna Conventions and bilateral consular conventions, email the Office of Foreign Missions (Office of Foreign Missions) of the Department of State at OFMAssistants@state.gov.

If you do not qualify for the tax exemption provided under the Vienna Conventions or a bilateral consular convention but are from a country that has a tax treaty with the United States, you should consult the tax treaty to determine if there is a provision that exempts your wages from United States income tax. If you are a U.S. citizen or foreign resident U.S. taxpayer who works in the United States for a foreign government, your wages are generally not exempt. For more information, see Wages and Pensions Paid by a Foreign Government in Publication 901.

Foreign government employees who do not qualify under the provisions of the Vienna Convention, a bilateral consular convention, or a tax treaty may be exempt from United States income tax on their foreign government salaries if they meet the following requirements for exemption of such salaries under United States tax law. The exemption under United States tax law applies only to current employees of a foreign government and not to former employees. Pensions received by former employees of a foreign government who live in the United States do not qualify for the exemption described here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. The common law rules apply to determine whether you are an employee or an independent contractor. See Publication 1779 and Publication 15-A .. Your salaries do not qualify for the exemption under United States tax law if a “controlled commercial entity” employs you or your services are related primarily to a commercial activity of the foreign government (within or outside the United States). A controlled commercial entity is an entity in which a foreign government has a 50 percent (0.50) or greater ownership interest and that engages in a commercial activity within or outside the United States.

"English": "However, see Foreigners who maintain their immigrant (legal permanent resident) status."), later, for a special rule that may affect your eligibility for this exemption. To claim the exemption, you must be able to demonstrate that you satisfy both the requirements of the U.S. tax law."

A certification from the Department of State, if issued, is the simplest way to establish that you meet the requirements for similar services and equivalent tax exemption, but it is not required for you to qualify for the tax exemption under US tax law. For information on whether a certification has been issued and whether that certification is valid and applies to you, send an email to the Office of Foreign Missions of the Department of State at OFMAssistants@state.gov. When no valid certification exists, you must establish with other written evidence that you provide services of a similar nature to those provided by US government employees in foreign countries and that the country of your government employer abroad grants an equivalent exemption to US government employees who provide similar services in their country.

Many agreements that establish international organizations contain a provision that might exempt their salaries from U.S. income tax. If you are employed by an international organization in the United States, first determine whether the international agreement that establishes the international organization for which you work has such a provision and whether you qualify for the exemption under it. Generally, these provisions do not exempt the salaries of employees who are U.S. citizens and foreign residents.

If the international agreement by which the international organization for which you work does not contain a provision for tax exemption and you are not a U.S. citizen (or if you are a U.S. citizen and also a citizen of the Republic of the Philippines), you may be eligible for tax exemption of your salary under the U.S. tax law. However, see Foreign residents who maintain their immigrant status. This tax exemption under U.S. tax law applies only to current employees of international organizations and not to former employees. Pensions received by former employees of international organizations who live in the United States do not qualify for the exemption discussed here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. The common law rules apply to determine whether you are an employee or an independent contractor. See Publication 1779 and Publication 15-A. To claim the exemption, you must be able to demonstrate that you meet the requirements of the provision of the international organization's agreement or of the U.S. tax law. You must know the article number of the exemption provision of the international organization's agreement, if there is one, and the number of the Executive Order that designates the organization as an international organization.

Si usted es un residente permanente legal (conocido como green card (tarjeta verde)) y firma la dispensa provista por la sección 247(b) de la Ley de Inmigración y Nacionalidad (Formulario I-508 del USCIS) para mantener su estado de residente permanente legal, usted ya no califica para la exención tributaria conforme a la ley tributaria estadounidense desde la fecha de presentación de la dispensa. Si usted es empleado de un gobierno extranjero o de una organización internacional que tiene una “green card”, para poder reclamar la exención conforme a la ley tributaria estadounidense también tiene que poder demostrar con evidencia escrita del USCIS que usted no ha firmado ni presentado el Formulario I-508 del USCIS.

Before leaving the United States, all foreigners (except those listed under Foreigners Who Do Not Need to Obtain Navigation or Exit Permits, below) must obtain a compliance certificate. This document, commonly known as a “navigation permit” or “exit permit,” is part of the income tax return you must file before leaving. You will receive a navigation or exit permit after filing Form 1040-C or Form 2063. These forms are explained in this chapter. To determine whether you need a navigation or exit permit, first read Foreigners Who Do Not Need to Obtain Navigation or Exit Permits, below. If none of the categories under that topic apply to you, you must obtain a navigation or exit permit. Read Foreigners Who Need to Obtain Navigation or Exit Permits, below.

If you are in one of the following categories, you do not need to obtain a navigation or departure permit before leaving the United States. If you are in one of these categories and do not need to obtain a navigation or departure permit, you must be able to substantiate your claim for exemption with appropriate identification or provide the authority that grants the exemption.
Tiene que presentar la declaración escrita ante una oficina del Centro de Asistencia al Contribuyente (TAC , por sus siglas en inglés).

If you are a non-resident who falls under category (1) or (2) above and who filed for exemption under Section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, you must obtain a navigation or departure permit. This is true even if your income is exempt from US income tax due to a tax treaty, a consular agreement, or an international agreement.

Foreign students, including their spouses and children, who enter only on an M-1 or M-2 visa and who do not receive income from U.S. sources while in the United States on those visas, except: Income from employment authorized by USCIS or Interest income on deposits that is not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. (See Interest Income in Chapter 3).

Certain other non-U.S. residents who are temporarily in the United States and who have not received taxable income during the tax year through and including the date of departure or during the preceding tax year. If the IRS has reason to believe that a non-resident has received taxable income and the departure jeopardizes the collection of taxes on the income, it may require the non-resident to obtain a departure permit or a navigation permit. Non-residents in this category are: 1. Military trainees who enter the United States for training under the sponsorship of the Department of Defense and who depart the United States with official military travel orders; 2. Business visitors with a B-1 visa, or with both B-1 and B-2 visas, who do not remain in the United States or in a U.S. territory for more than 90 days during the tax year; 3. Pleasure visitors with a B-2 visa; 4. Foreigners who are in transit through the United States or any of its territories with a C-1 visa or under contract, such as a bond agreement between a transportation line and the Attorney General; and 5. Foreigners who enter the United States with a border crossing identification card or for whom passports, visas, and border crossing identification cards are not required, if: 1. They are pleasure visitors; 2. They are business visitors who do not remain in the United States or in a U.S. territory for more than 90 days during the tax year; or 3. They are in transit through the United States or any of its territories.

Los residentes extranjeros de Canadá o México que se desplazan frecuentemente entre ese país y los Estados Unidos por trabajo, y cuyos salarios están sujetos a la retención de impuestos estadounidenses.

If none of the categories listed above under Non-U.S. Citizens Who Do Not Need to Obtain a Navigation or Exit Permit apply to you, you must obtain a navigation or exit permit. To obtain a permit, file Form 1040-C or Form 2063 (which ever is appropriate) at your local TAC office before leaving the United States. See Forms You Must File, later. You also must pay all taxes shown as due on Form 1040-C and any taxes due for prior years. See How to Pay Taxes and Get Refunds, later.

The process to obtain your navigation or departure permit will be faster if you bring to the TAC office the documents and papers related to your income and your stay in the United States. Bring the following records with you if applicable: 1. Your passport and alien registration card or visa. 2. Copies of your United States income tax returns filed for the last 2 years. If you were in the United States for less than 2 years, bring the income tax returns you filed for that period. 3. Receipts for income tax paid on those returns. 4. Bank statements, canceled checks, and other records that show your deductions, business expenses, and dependents you claimed on your returns. 5. A written statement from each employer showing the wages paid and the tax withheld from January 1 of the current year through the day of departure if you were an employee. If you were self-employed, you must bring a statement of income and expenses through the date you expect to depart. 6. Proof of estimated tax payments for the previous year and this year. 7. Records showing gains or losses from the sale of personal and/or real property, including capital assets and merchandise. 8. Records relating to scholarships and grants for study and professional development, including: 1. Verification of the grantor, source, and purpose of the scholarship. 2. Copies of the application for, and approval of, the scholarship. 3. A statement of the amount paid and your duties and obligations under the scholarship. 4. A list of all previous scholarships. 9. Records indicating that you qualify for any special benefits claimed under a tax treaty. 10. Document showing your United States ITIN, such as a Social Security card or an IRS Notice CP 565 showing your ITIN.

If you need to obtain a navigation or departure permit, you must file Form 2063 or Form 1040-C. Both forms have a section titled “certificate of compliance”. When the certificate of compliance is signed by a Director of Area Center of Taxpayer Assistance agent, it certifies that your U.S. tax obligations are in compliance according to the information available. Your copy of the signed certificate from Form 1040-C, or the disconnection from Form 2063, is your navigation or departure permit.

Foreigners in any of these categories who have not filed a tax return or paid income tax in any tax year must file a tax return and pay income tax before they can be issued a departure permit or departure card on Form 2063. The departure permit or departure card issued on Form 2063 may be used for all departures in the current year. However, the IRS may cancel the departure permit or departure card for any subsequent departure if it believes that the collection of income tax for that subsequent departure is at risk.

If you must obtain a departure or exit permit and do not qualify to file Form 2063, you must file Form 1040-C. Generally, all income received or expected to be received during the tax year up to and including the date of departure, must be reported on Form 1040-C and the tax shown as due on it must be paid. When you pay any tax due as shown on Form 1040-C, file all returns and pay all taxes due for prior years, you will receive a departure or exit permit. However, the IRS may allow you to provide a bond to secure payment instead of paying the taxes for certain years. See Bond to Secure Payment, later. The departure or exit permit issued under the conditions in this paragraph is only for the specific departure for which it is issued.

If you provide the IRS information showing, to the satisfaction of the IRS, that you intend to return to the United States and that your departure does not put at risk the collection of income tax, you may obtain a navigation or departure permit by filing Form 1040-C without having to pay the tax shown thereon. However, you must file all income tax returns that you have not yet filed as required and pay all income tax due on those returns. Your Form 1040-C must include all income received and income that you reasonably expect to receive during the entire year of departure. The navigation or departure permit issued with this Form 1040-C may be used for all departures during the current year. However, the IRS may cancel the navigation or departure permit for any subsequent departure if the payment of income tax appears to be at risk.

Spouses who are in the process of leaving and who are non-resident aliens cannot file joint returns. However, if both spouses are resident aliens, they may file a joint return on Form 1040-C if: It can be reasonably expected that both spouses will qualify to file a joint return at the normal close of their tax year and The tax year of both spouses ends at the same time.

You must pay all the tax shown as due on the Form 1040-C when you file it, except when you provide a bond or the IRS is satisfied that your exit will not jeopardize the collection of your income tax. You also must pay any taxes due for prior years. If the tax calculation on the Form 1040-C results in an overpayment, there is no tax to pay when you file your return. However, the IRS cannot issue a refund at the time of exit. If you are due a refund, you must file Form 1040-NR at the end of the tax year.

Normally, you must pay the tax shown on your Form 1040-C as due when you file. First, you must determine whether, for income tax purposes, you are a nonresident alien or a resident alien. If you are both a nonresident and a resident in the same year, you are a double resident. If you are a non-U.S. citizen, you are considered a non-resident alien unless you meet one of the two requirements described under Foreign Residents below.

You are a U.S. resident alien for tax purposes if you meet the green card requirement or the substantial presence test for 2024 (January 1 through December 31). Although you do not meet either requirement, you may be treated as a U.S. resident for part of the year. See First-Year Election under Foreign Residents with Dual Residency, later.

You are a resident for tax purposes if you are a legal permanent resident of the United States at any time during the 2024 calendar year. (However, see Foreigners with Dual Residency, below). This is known as the “green card” requirement. You are a legal permanent resident of the United States at any time if you have been granted the privilege, under the laws of the United States, to reside permanently in the United States as an immigrant. Generally, you have this immigration status if the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS, for its acronym in English) (or its predecessor organization) has issued you Form I-551, Permanent Resident Card (United States Permanent Resident Card), also known as a green card. You continue to be a legal permanent resident under this requirement, unless you are deprived of the status or it is determined administratively or judicially that you have abandoned it.

It is considered that the state of resident has been withdrawn if the government of the United States has issued a definitive administrative or judicial order of exclusion or deportation. A definitive judicial order is an order that you can no longer appeal to a superior court of competent jurisdiction.

When filing by mail, you must send your return by registered mail, requesting a receipt (or an equivalent foreign document), and keep a copy and a record showing that it was sent and received. Until you have a receipt showing that your letter was received, you remain a foreign resident for tax purposes, even if the USCIS does not recognize the validity of your green card because it is more than 10 years old or because you have been absent from the United States for a period of time. If the USCIS or a United States consular officer initiates this determination, your status of resident will be considered abandoned when the final administrative order of abandonment is issued. If you are granted an appeal before a federal court of competent jurisdiction, a final judicial order is required. Under United States immigration laws, a legal permanent resident who is required to file a tax return as a resident and does not do so may be considered as having abandoned his or her status (of resident) and may lose his or her status of legal permanent resident. A long-term resident (LTR, for its acronym in English) who ceases to be a legal permanent resident may be subject to special tax requirements and provisions. SeeExpatriation Tax in chapter 4.

You are a resident for tax purposes if you meet the substantial presence test for the 2024 calendar year. To meet this test, you must be physically present in the United States for at least: 1. 31 days in 2024 and 2. 183 days during the 3-year period that includes the 2024, 2023, and 2022 calendar years, counting: 1. All the days you were present in 2024, 2. 1/3 of the days you were present in 2023, and 3. 1/6 of the days you were present in 2022.

When calculating days of presence in the United States, you can exclude only the days in which you actually competed in a sporting event. You cannot exclude the days in which you were in the United States to practice for the event, to perform promotional activities or other activities related to the event, or to travel between events. If you qualify to exclude days of presence as a professional athlete, you must file a fully completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See Form 8843 below.

You can demonstrate that you have a closer connection to two foreign countries (but not more than two) if you meet all the following conditions: You maintained a tax home in a foreign country on the first day of the year. You changed your tax home during the year to a second foreign country. You continued to maintain your tax home in the second foreign country for the rest of the year. You had a closer connection to each foreign country than to the United States during the period in which you maintained a tax home in that foreign country. You are subject to taxes as a resident under the tax laws of either of the two foreign countries for the entire year or subject to taxes as a resident in both foreign countries during the period in which you maintained a tax home in each foreign country.

Your tax residency is the general area of your principal place of work, employment or occupation, regardless of where you maintain your family home. Your tax residency is the place where you work permanently or indefinitely as an employee or as a self-employed person. If you do not have a regular or principal place of work due to the nature of your work, then your tax residency is the place where you live regularly. If you are not in any of these categories, you are considered a non-resident and your tax residency is wherever you work. To determine if you have a closer connection to a foreign country, your tax residency also has to exist throughout the current year and has to be located in the same foreign country with which you claim to have a closer connection.

If you are treated as a resident of a foreign country under a tax treaty, you are treated as a nonresident alien for determining your U.S. income tax. Attach Form 1040 or 1040-SR and write “Amended” on the top of the amended return. If you make the choice with the amended return, you and your spouse also have to amend any return that you filed after the year for which you made the choice. Generally, you have to file the amended joint return within 3 years from the date you filed your original U.S. income tax return, or within 2 years from the date you paid your income tax for that year, whichever is later.

You can only use this date if, during the rest of 2024, your tax residency was in a foreign country and you had a closer connection with that foreign country. See Closer Connection with a Foreign Country, previously.

If you are a U.S. resident for any part of 2025 and were a resident for any part of 2024, you will be treated as a resident until the end of 2024. This applies whether you have a closer connection to a foreign country than to the United States during 2024 and whether you are a resident under the substantial presence test or the green card test.

Yes, if at the end of the tax year, you are married and one spouse is a U.S. citizen or foreign resident and the other spouse is a foreign nonresident, you can choose to treat the nonresident spouse as a resident of the United States. This includes situations where one spouse is a foreign nonresident at the beginning of the tax year, but is a foreign resident at the end of the tax year, and the other spouse is a foreign nonresident at the end of the tax year. If you make this election, you and your spouse are treated as residents for tax purposes during the entire tax year. You and your spouse cannot claim under any tax treaty that you are not residents of the United States. You both are subject to taxes on your worldwide income. You must file a joint income tax return for the year you make the election, but you and your spouse may file joint or separate returns in subsequent years. If you file a joint return under this provision, the special instructions and restrictions for residents with dual residence in chapter 6 do not apply to you.
Also check the box and enter the name of the nonresident spouse if you and your nonresident spouse made the election to be treated as residents in a prior year and the election remains valid.

The choice to be treated as a nonresident alien is suspended for any tax year (after the tax year you elected) if neither spouse is a U.S. citizen or foreign resident at any time during the tax year. This means that each spouse must file a separate return as a nonresident alien for that year if either of them meets the requirements for filing as a nonresident alien explained in Chapter 7.
