If you are a nonresident alien in the United States and a bona fide resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you are subject to U.S. taxes, with certain exceptions, under the rules for U.S. resident aliens. For more information, see U.S. Resident Aliens of the U.S. Virgin Islands or Puerto Rico in chapter 5. If you are a nonresident alien of the U.S. Virgin Islands or Puerto Rico who does not qualify as a bona fide resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you are subject to U.S. taxes as a nonresident alien. Foreign residents who were formerly bona fide residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands or Puerto Rico are subject to U.S. taxes under the rules for foreign residents.

After you determine your alien status, you must determine the source of your income. This chapter will help you determine the source of the different types of income you may receive during the tax year.

Foreign resident income is generally subject to US income tax in the same way as income of US citizens. If you are a foreign resident, you must report all interest, dividends, wages or other compensation for services rendered; rental income or royalties; and other types of income on your US tax return. You must report these amounts from sources within and outside the United States.

Foreign non-residents are taxed only on their income from U.S. sources and on certain income related to a U.S. occupation or business (see chapter 4). The general rules for determining U.S. source income that apply to most foreign non-residents are shown in Table 2-1. The discussions below cover the general rules as well as the exceptions to these rules. Not all classes of income from U.S. sources are subject to tax. See chapter 3 ..

Real property is land and buildings and, in general, all that is built upon, that grows upon or that is affixed to land. Gross income from sources in the United States includes gains, profits, and income from the sale or other disposition of real property located in the United States.

The income from the sale of products of any farm, mine, oil or gas well, other natural deposit, or timber located in the United States and sold in a foreign country, or located in a foreign country and sold in the United States, is partly from United States sources. For information on determining that part, see section 1.863-1(b) of the regulations.

Mobile property is property such as machinery, equipment, furniture, stocks, bonds, and other securities that are not real property. The gain or loss from the sale or exchange of mobile property is generally from a U.S. source if you have a U.S. tax home. Otherwise, the gain or loss is generally considered to be from a foreign source.

Your tax residency is the general area of your principal place of work, employment or occupation, regardless of where you maintain your family home. Your tax residency is the place where you work permanently or indefinitely as an employee or as a self-employed worker. If you do not have a regular or principal place of business due to the nature of your work, then your tax residency is the place where you live regularly. If you do not fall under any of those categories, you are considered a non-resident and your tax residency is wherever you work.

Inventory property is tangible personal property that is held for sale in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's business or that is held primarily for sale to customers in the ordinary course of the taxpayer's business. The source of income from the sale of inventory that you bought is determined by the place where the property was sold. Generally, this is where the title to the property passes to the purchaser. For example, income from the sale of inventory in the United States is from a U.S. source, whether you bought it in the United States or in a foreign country. The source of income from the sale of inventory property that you produced in the United States and sold outside the United States (or vice versa) is determined by the place where the property was produced. These rules apply even if your tax home is not in the United States.

To determine the source of any gain from the sale of depreciable property, you must first calculate the portion of the gain that is not greater than the total of the depreciation adjustments to the property. You assign this portion of the gain to U.S. sources on the basis of the ratio between the U.S. depreciation adjustments and the total depreciation adjustments. The remainder of this portion of the gain is considered to be from sources outside the United States. For this purpose, “U.S. depreciation adjustments” are the depreciation adjustments to the property’s basis that are allowed for calculating taxable income from U.S. sources. However, if the property is used primarily in the United States during the tax year, all depreciation deductions allowed for that year are treated as U.S. depreciation adjustments. There are some exceptions for certain transports, communications, and other property used internationally. The source of the gain from the sale of depreciable property that is greater than the total of the depreciation adjustments to the property is determined as if the property were inventory property, as discussed above. The source of a loss is determined in the same way as it was determined for depreciation deductions. However, if the property was used primarily in the United States, the total loss reduces taxable income from U.S. sources. The property’s basis is usually the amount of money plus the fair market value of other property or services that you pay for the property. Depreciation is an amount that you deduct to recover the cost of an asset used in a trade or business. The amount you can deduct depends on the cost of the property, when you start to use the property, how long it will take to recover the cost, and the depreciation method you use. A depreciation deduction is any deduction for depreciation or amortization or any other allowable deduction that treats a capital expenditure as a deductible expense.

Intangible assets include patents, copyrights, trade secrets, goodwill, trademarks, trade names, or other similar property. The source of the gain from the sale of depreciable or amortizable intangible assets, up to the previously allowed depreciation or amortization deductions, is determined in the same manner as for the original deductions. This is the same as the source rule for the gain from the sale of depreciable property. See Depreciable property, earlier, for details on how to apply this rule. The source of excess deductions for depreciation or amortization is determined on the basis of the country where the property is used if the income from the sale depends on the productivity, use, or disposition of that property. If the income does not depend on the productivity, use, or disposition of the property, the source of the income is determined according to its tax home (discussed earlier). If payments for goodwill do not depend on the productivity, use, or disposition of the property, its source is the country in which the goodwill was generated.

Despite any of the above rules, if you do not have a U.S. tax home but maintain an office or other fixed place of business in the United States, treat income from any sale of tangible property (including inventory) that is attributable to that office or place of business as U.S. source income. However, this rule does not apply to sales of inventory for use, disposition, or consumption outside the United States if your office or other fixed place of business outside the United States substantially participated in the sale. If you have a U.S. tax home but maintain an office or other fixed place of business outside the United States, income from sales of tangible property, other than inventory, property subject to depreciation, or intangible property, that is attributable to that office or place of business abroad may be treated as U.S. source income. Income is treated as U.S. source income if a tax on less than 10 percent of the income from the sale is paid to a foreign country. This rule also applies to losses if the foreign country would have taxed a tax on less than 10 percent of the income from the sale as a gain.

The place or mode of payment is irrelevant in determining the source of income. The source of a substitute interest payment made to the grantor of a stock value in a securities lending transaction or a repurchase option transaction is determined in the same way as the source of interest on the stock value transferred.

Income from U.S. sources does not include the following: 1. Interest paid by a foreign resident or a domestic partnership on obligations issued before August 10, 2010, if, for the 3-year period that ends with the close of the taxable year of the payor prior to the payment of interest, at least 80 percent (0.80) of the total gross income of the payor: 1. Is from sources outside the United States and 2. Is attributable to the active conduct of a trade or business by an individual or domestic partnership in a foreign country or U.S. territory. However, interest will be considered income from U.S. sources if either of the following conditions applies: 1. The person receiving the interest is related to the foreign resident or domestic partnership. See section 954(d)(3) for the definition of “related person.” 2. The terms of the obligation are significantly modified after August 9, 2010. Any extension of the term of the obligation is considered a significant modification. 2. Interest paid by a foreign branch of a domestic partnership or domestic corporation on deposits or retirement accounts with savings and loan associations, credit unions, building and loan associations, domestic building and loan associations, domestic savings associations, domestic savings and loan associations, and other savings and loan associations registered and supervised as savings and loan associations or similar institutions under state or federal law if the interest paid or credited can be deducted by the partnership. 3. Interest on deposits with a foreign branch of a domestic partnership or domestic corporation, but only if the branch is in the business of commercial banking.

In most cases, income from dividends received from domestic corporations is U.S. source income. Income from dividends from foreign corporations is generally foreign source income. An exception to the second rule is explained below. The source of a substitute (alternative) dividend payment made to the grantor of a stock in a stock loan transaction or a stock sale with repurchase option transaction is determined in the same way as the source of a distribution of a stock transferred.

A payment of an amount equivalent to a dividend includes any gross amount that refers to a US source dividend and that is used to calculate any net amount transferred to, or from, a taxpayer under a contract, if the taxpayer is the long party under the contract. As a result, a taxpayer may be treated as if it had received a payment equivalent to dividends even if the taxpayer makes a net payment or no amount is paid because the net amount is zero. In 2024, an NPC or an ELI will generally be a specified NPC or a specified ELI, respectively, if the contract is a delta one designation transaction. In general, delta is the ratio of the change in the fair market value of an NPC or an ELI to a small change in the fair market value of the number of shares to which the contract refers. In general, the amount of an equivalent to dividends for a specified NPC or a specified ELI is the dividend per share amount multiplied by the number of shares to which the contract refers multiplied by the contract's delta. Special rules apply to complex contracts. See section 1.871-15 of the Regulations and Notice 2024-44 (or its successors) for more information.

If you are self-employed, you determine the source of compensation for work or personal services from self-employment using the base that most accurately reflects the proper source of that income according to the facts and circumstances of your particular case. In many cases, the facts and circumstances will require a proration based on a time base, as explained below.
The amount of additional benefits must be reasonable and must be justified by adequate records or by sufficient evidence.

The source of the additional benefits mentioned above, other than a tax refund or hazardous or difficult service pay, is determined based on your principal place of work. Your principal place of work is usually the place where you spend the most of your work time. That place may be your office, plant, store, workshop or any other location. If there is no single place where you spend the most of your work time, your principal place of work is the place where your work is centered, such as the place where you report to work or where you otherwise are required to “base” your work. If you have more than one job at any time, your principal place of work depends on the facts in each case. The most important factors to consider are: The total time you spend at each place, The amount of work you do at each place, and How much money you earn at each place.
Moving expense deduction is available only if you are a member of the United States Armed Forces on active duty and moved due to a permanent change of your place of service.

The local transportation supplement source is determined based on the location of your principal place of work. Your local transportation supplement is the amount you receive as compensation for local transportation for you or your spouse or dependents at the location of your principal place of work. The amount treated as a local transportation supplement is limited to the actual expenses incurred for local transportation and the fair rental value of any vehicle provided by the employer used predominantly by you, your spouse or dependents for local transportation. Actual expenses do not include the cost (including interest) of any vehicle purchased by you or on your behalf.
The source of the additional refund tax credit is determined based on the location of the jurisdiction that imposed the tax for which you are refunded.

The source of a moving expense reimbursement generally is based on the location of your new principal place of work. However, the source is determined based on the location of your former principal place of work if you provide sufficient evidence that such a source determination is more appropriate under the facts and circumstances of your case. Sufficient evidence generally requires an agreement between you and your employer, or a written company policy, that is put in writing before the move and that is performed or established to induce you or other employees to move to another country. The written statement or agreement must declare that your employer will reimburse you for moving expenses incurred to return to your former principal place of work, regardless of whether you continue to work for your employer after returning to that location. It may contain certain conditions on which the right to be reimbursed is determined as long as the conditions set out are definitely verifiable and that they can only be fulfilled before, or by the conclusion, of your return to your former principal place of work.

If you are an employee, you may determine the source of your compensation using an alternative base if you establish to the satisfaction of the IRS that, according to the facts and circumstances of your case, the alternative base more accurately determines the source of your compensation than the time or geographic base. If you use an alternative base, you must keep (and have available for inspection) records to document why the alternative base more accurately determines the source of your compensation. In addition, if your total compensation from all sources is $250,000 or more, mark “Yes” for both questions in line K of Schedule OI (Form 1040-NR), and attach a written statement to your tax return that states all of the following: 1. Your name and Social Security Number (written on the top of the written statement). 2. The specific income, or the specific supplement benefit, for which you are using the alternative base. 3. For each item in (2), the alternative base of assignment of the source used. 4. For each item in (2), the calculation that shows how the alternative assignment was calculated. 5. A comparison of the dollar amount of U.S. compensation and foreign compensation from a source determined on the alternative base and the time or geographic base discussed above.Return to the list of questions.Return to the list of questions.Return to the list of questions.

Transportation income is income from the use of a vessel or an aircraft, or from the provision of services directly related to the use of any vessel or aircraft. This is true whether the vessel or aircraft is owned, chartered, or rented. The phrase “vessel or aircraft” includes any container used in relation with a vessel or aircraft. All transportation income that begins and ends in the United States is treated as derived from U.S. sources. If transportation begins or ends in the United States, 50% of the transportation income is treated as derived from U.S. sources. For transportation income from personal services, 50% of the income is from U.S. sources if the transportation is between the United States and a U.S. territory. For nonresident aliens, this only applies to income derived from or in relation to an aircraft. For information on how transportation income from U.S. sources is taxed, see chapter 4.

Generally, the source of study grants, professional development grants, awards, and prizes is the residence of the payer, regardless of who actually disburses the funds. However, see Activities Outside the United States, later. For example, professional development or study payments in the United States made by the United States, a non-U.S. corporation, or a U.S. domestic corporation are from U.S. sources. Similar payments from a foreign government or a foreign corporation are from foreign sources, even though the funds may be disbursed through a U.S. agent. Payments made by an entity designated as a public international organization under the International Organizations Immunities Act are from foreign sources.

Scholarships, professional development grants, special grants, and awards for achievement received by nonresident aliens for activities performed, or to be performed, outside the United States are not U.S. source income. These rules do not apply to amounts paid as salary or other compensation for services. SeePersonal Services, above, for more information about the source rules that apply.

If you receive a domestic trust pension for services performed both in and outside the United States, part of the pension payment comes from U.S. sources. That part is the amount attributed to the pension plan income and employer contributions made for services performed in the United States. This applies whether the distribution is made under a qualified or nonqualified stock bonus, pension, profit-sharing, or annuity plan (with or without funding). If you performed services as an employee of the United States, you may receive a distribution from the U.S. government under a plan, such as the Civil Service Retirement System (CSRS), that is treated as a qualified pension plan. Your U.S. source income is the amount of the distribution that would otherwise be taxable, attributed to your basic pay from the U.S. government, apart from the pay that is exempt from taxes for services performed outside the United States.

Special rules allow withdrawals and re contributions with tax benefits from certain retirement plans (including IRAs) for taxpayers who suffered economic losses due to certain major disasters. For information on how to report disaster qualified distributions and re contributions, see Form 8915-F, Qualified Disaster Retirement Plan Distributions and Repayments, and its instructions.

Your U.S. source income includes rental income and royalties received during the tax year from a U.S. property or any interest in that property. U.S. source income also includes rental income or royalties from the use of, or the privilege of using, in the United States, intangible property, such as patents, copyrights, trade secrets, goodwill, trademarks, franchises, and similar property.
In these cases, you and your spouse have to declare income from community property, as explained below.

Income from the work of a spouse, other than income from an occupation or business, and the distributive share of a partner in the profits of a partnership, are treated as income of the spouse whose services produce the income. That spouse must report all of it on his or her separate return.

The income from a business or occupation, other than the distributive share of a partner in the profits of a partnership, is treated as income of the spouse who carries on the business or occupation. That spouse must report all of it on his or her separate return.
The distributive share of a partner in the income (or loss) of a partnership is treated as income (or loss) of the partner. That spouse must report all of it on his or her separate return.

Income derived from the separate property of a spouse (and that is not income from work, income from a trade or business, or income from distributions of income (or losses) from a partnership) is treated as income of that spouse. That spouse must report all of it on his or her separate return. Use the appropriate community property law to determine what is separate property.
All other marital property income is treated in accordance with the laws governing the marital property in question.

Residents and non-resident aliens are allowed to exclude certain income from gross income if they meet certain conditions. A gross income exclusion is generally income that you receive that is not included in your U.S. income and is not subject to U.S. taxes. This chapter covers some of the most common gross income exclusions allowed to residents and non-resident aliens.

If you are physically present in a foreign country or countries for at least 330 full days during any 12-month period, you may qualify for the foreign earned income exclusion. The exclusion is $126,500 in 2024. In addition, you may be able to exclude or deduct certain amounts for foreign housing. You may also qualify if you are a bona fide resident of a foreign country and are a citizen or national of a country with which the United States has a tax treaty. For more information, see Publication 54.
Non-resident aliens may exclude from their gross income the following items.

Interest income that is not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business is excluded from income if it is from: Deposits (including certificates of deposit) with banks in the banking business; Deposits or withdrawal accounts in savings and loan associations, credit unions, building and loan associations, and other savings institutions chartered and supervised as savings and loan associations or similar associations under state and federal law (if the interest paid or credited may be deducted by the association); and Amounts held by an insurance company under an agreement to pay interest on them.

Interest on obligations of a state or political subdivision, the District of Columbia or a U.S. territory is generally not included in income. However, interest on certain private activity bonds, arbitrage bonds, and certain bonds that are not in registered form is included in income.

Interest and discount on the original issue (OID) that qualifies as interest from portfolio debt securities are not subject to withholding under chapter 3 (of the Internal Revenue Code) under sections 1441 through 1443. However, that interest may be subject to withholding if it is a payment on which withholding is required and there is no exception to withholding under chapter 4 (of the Internal Revenue Code) under sections 1471 through 1474. For more information, see the explanation of portfolio debt securities interest in Withholding on Specific Income in Publication 515, Withholding of Tax on Nonresident Aliens and Foreign Entities. To qualify as portfolio debt securities interest, the interest must be paid on obligations issued after July 18, 1984, and otherwise be subject to withholding. For obligations issued after March 18, 2012, portfolio debt securities interest does not include interest paid on debt that is not in registered form. Before March 19, 2012, portfolio debt securities interest included interest on certain registered and unregistered (bearer) bonds if the obligations met the requirements described below.

An obligation that would otherwise be considered registered is not considered registered at a particular time if it can be converted at any time in the future into an obligation that is not registered. For more information on whether obligations are considered registered, see the explanation of interest from the investment portfolio under Withholding on Specific Income in Publication 515.

No documentation is required for interest on bearer obligations to qualify as interest from the portfolio of investment securities. However, in some cases, you may need documentation for purposes of the information reported on Forms 1099 and additional withholding of interest and certain dividends.

Certain payments to individuals and contingent interest payments do not qualify as interest from investment portfolio holdings. You must withhold tax using the applicable statutory rate for these payments, unless another exception applies, such as a treaty provision.

Interest from the investment portfolio does not include contingent interest. Contingent interest is one of the following: 1. Interest determined by reference to: Any receipt, sale or other cash flow of the debtor or related person; Income or gain of the debtor or related person; Any change in the value of the debtor's or related person's property; or Any dividend, distribution of a partnership, or similar payment made by the debtor or related person. For exceptions, see section 871(h)(4)(C). 2. Any other type of contingent interest identified by the Secretary of the Treasury in the regulations.

Contingent interest does not include interest paid or accrued on any fixed-term debt issued: On or before April 7, 1993; or After April 7, 1993, under a binding written contract in effect on that date and at all times thereafter before that debt was issued.
The following dividend income is exempt from the 30% tax.

There is no 30% tax on dividends from U.S. sources that you receive from a foreign corporation. See Exception for Dividends in Chapter 2 to learn how to calculate the amount of dividends from U.S. sources. This exception does not apply to payments of equivalent dividends.

There is no 30% tax on dividends related to interest from sources within the United States that you receive from a mutual fund or other regulated investment company. The mutual fund will designate in writing which dividends are related to interest.

You may not be taxed on certain 30% dividends from short-term capital gains from U.S. sources that you receive from a mutual fund or other regulated investment company. The mutual fund will designate in writing which dividends are short-term capital gains dividends. This tax relief will not apply to you if you are present in the United States for 183 days or more during your tax year.
If a foreign employer paid you, your U.S. source income may be exempt from U.S. taxes, but only if you meet one of the situations explained below.

If you do not meet all three conditions, your income from personal services in the United States is income from U.S. sources and is subject to taxes according to the rules in chapter 4. If your pay for these services is more than $3,000, the total amount is income from a trade or business within the United States. To determine if your pay is more than $3,000, do not include any amount you receive from your employer for advances or reimbursements of business travel expenses if you were required to account to your employer for these expenses and did so. If the advances or reimbursements are more than your expenses, include the excess in your pay for these services. A “day” means a calendar day during any part of which you are physically present in the United States.

Compensation for services performed by a non-resident alien in relation to the temporary presence of the individual in the United States as a normal crew member of a foreign ship (e.g., a boat or vessel) engaged in transportation between the United States and a foreign country or U.S. territory is not U.S. source income and is exempt from U.S. taxation. This exemption does not apply to compensation for services performed on foreign aircraft.
The term “foreign employer” does not include a foreign government. Pay from a foreign government that is exempt from U.S. taxes is explained in Chapter 10.

Any income that is exempt from United States taxation under a treaty in which the United States is a party is excluded from gross income. However, income on which the tax is limited only by a treaty is included in gross income. See chapter 9.
You can exclude from your gross income gains from legal betting initiated outside the United States in a pari-mutuel pool with respect to a live horse or dog race in the United States.

If you sold your main home, you may be able to exclude up to $250,000 of the gain from the sale of your home. If you are married and file a joint return, you may be able to exclude up to $500,000. For information about the requirements for this exclusion, see Publication 523. This exclusion does not apply if you are subject to the tax rules on expatriation discussed in chapter 4 ..

If you are a candidate for a degree, you may exclude from your income all or part of the amounts you receive as a qualified scholarship. The rules discussed here apply to both residents and nonresident aliens. If a nonresident alien receives a scholarship that does not come from U.S. sources, he or she is not subject to U.S. taxes. SeeScholarships, Grants, Awards and Prizes in chapter 2 to determine whether your scholarship is from U.S. sources. A scholarship for study or for professional development is excluded from income only if: 1. You are a candidate for a degree from an eligible educational institution and 2. You use the scholarship for qualified education expenses.

You are a candidate for a degree if: 1. You attend a primary or secondary school or are pursuing a degree in a college or university or 2. You attend an accredited educational institution that is authorized to provide: 1. A program that is acceptable for full credit toward a degree or higher or 2. A training program to prepare students for a remunerated occupation in a recognized occupation.

However, for educational expenses to be qualified, the conditions of the study or professional development grant cannot require that it be used for other purposes, such as accommodation and meals, nor specify that it cannot be used for tuition or the expenses related to courses.

This is true even if the charge is to be paid to the institution as a condition for enrollment or attendance. The amounts of the study or professional development grant used to pay those costs are taxable.
The amount of a scholarship used to pay any non-qualified expense is taxable, even if the expense is a charge that must be paid to the institution as a condition for enrollment or attendance.

You cannot exclude from income any part of any scholarship, fellowship, or similar award to the extent it represents payment for teaching, research, or other services performed in the past, present, or reasonably expected in the future. This is true even if all applicants for a degree are required to perform services as a condition of receiving the degree.

Foreign residents are generally subject to taxes in the same way as US citizens. This means that their worldwide income is subject to US taxes and must be reported on their US tax return. Foreign resident income is subject to the graduated tax rates that correspond to US citizens. Foreign residents use the Tax Table or the Work Sheet for Calculating Tax in the Instructions for Form 1040, for US citizens.

The difference between these two categories is that directly related income, after allowable deductions, is taxed at graduated rates. These are the same rates that are applied to U.S. citizens and residents. Indirectly related income is taxed at a flat 30% (or lower under a treaty). If you were previously a U.S. citizen or foreign resident, these rules may not apply. SeeExpatriation Tax, later in this chapter.

Generally, you must be engaged in a trade or business during the tax year in order to consider that the income received in that year is directly related to that trade or business. Whether you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States depends on the nature of your activities. The discussions below will help you determine whether you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States.

If you provide personal services in the United States at any time during the tax year, you are generally considered to be engaged in a U.S. occupation or business. Certain compensation paid to a nonresident alien by a foreign employer is not included in gross income. For more information, seeServices Rendered for a Foreign Employer in chapter 3.
Below are other examples of participation in a U.S. occupation or business.

If you are temporarily present in the United States as a nonimmigrant with an F, J, M, or Q visa, and did not engage in an occupation or business, you are considered to have engaged in an occupation or business of the United States if you have taxable income from participation in a scholarship or fellowship grant, as described in section 1441(b). The taxable portion of any scholarship or fellowship grant from a U.S. source is treated as directly related to an occupation or business of the United States.
If you own and operate a business in the United States selling services, products or merchandise, you are engaged in a business or occupation in the United States, with certain exceptions.

If you are a member of a partnership that at any time during the tax year participates in a trade or business in the United States, you are considered to participate in a trade or business in the United States.
If you are the beneficiary of an estate or trust that participates in a U.S. trade or business, you are treated as if you participate in the same trade or business.

If your only U.S. business activity is the trading of stocks, securities, or commodities (including hedging transactions) through a U.S. broker or other resident agent, you are not engaged in a U.S. occupation or business. For stock or securities transactions, this applies to any nonresident alien, including a dealer or a securities broker. For commodity transactions, this applies to commodities that are normally traded on an organized commodity exchange and to transactions that are normally made on that exchange. This discussion does not apply if you have a fixed U.S. business office or other fixed place of business at any time during the tax year through, or under the direction of, which you carry on your stock, securities, or commodity transactions.

You are not engaged in a U.S. occupation or business if the only commercial activity you carry on in the United States is negotiating for your own account in securities, commodities, or commodities futures. This applies even if the negotiations are conducted while you are present in the United States or if they are conducted by your employee or your stockbroker or other agent. This does not apply to negotiating for your own account if you are a dealer in securities, commodities, or commodities futures. However, this does not necessarily mean that, as a dealer, you are considered to be engaged in a U.S. occupation or business. Determine this on the basis of the facts and circumstances of each case or in the rules mentioned above under Negotiating in securities, commodities, or commodities futures.

If you are engaged in a U.S. occupation or business, all income, gain, or loss for the tax year that you receive from U.S. sources (other than certain investment income) is treated as income directly related. This applies regardless of whether there is or is not any connection between the income and the occupation or business that is carried on in the United States during the tax year. The two requirements described under Investment Income, below, determine whether certain investment income (such as interest, dividends, and royalties) is treated as directly related to that business. In limited circumstances, certain types of income from foreign sources may be treated as directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. For an explanation of these rules, see Foreign Income, below.
Generally, the stock of a corporation is not treated as an asset used in, or held for use in, a trade or business in the United States.
Under this requirement, if the conduct of the U.S. occupation or business was a significant factor in the production of the income, the income is considered directly related.

If you provided personal services in the United States after 1986 and, in a subsequent tax year, receive distributions from a pension or retirement plan attributable to these services when you were a nonresident alien, these distributions are directly related income to the extent attributable to contributions. This is true whether or not you are engaged in a U.S. occupation or business in the year you receive the distributions from a pension or retirement plan.

The concept of “fixed business establishment” generally means a place, site, structure or other similar establishment through which you carry on an occupation or business. The concept of “regular scheduled transportation” means that a ship or aircraft follows a published schedule with repeated voyages or flights at regular intervals between the same points for the trips or flights that begin or end in the United States. This definition applies to both scheduled air transportation and chartered air transportation. If it does not meet both of the above conditions, the income is not directly related and is subject to tax at the 4% rate. See Transportation Tax, later in this chapter.

All income and losses from U.S. sources that are generated from the operation of a business in the United States are directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. For example, income from sales in the United States of inventory of goods acquired in the United States or in a foreign country is income directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. A portion of the income and losses from U.S. sources of a partnership that engages in a U.S. occupation or business is also directly related to a U.S. occupation or business.

If you are a foreign direct or indirect partner in a U.S. partnership or a foreign person who participates (or is treated as participating) in a U.S. trade or business and dispose of an interest in the partnership, then the gain or loss from the disposition of that interest in the partnership may affect your U.S. federal tax liability. Under section 864(c)(8), your gain or loss from the sale, exchange, or other disposition of that interest in a partnership is treated as directly related to a U.S. trade or business (“directly related gain” or “directly related loss”). However, the amount of the directly related gain or loss is limited by the distributive share of the gain or loss that would have been your directly related gain or loss if the partnership had sold all of its assets at fair market value on the date of disposition. Section 864(c)(8) applies to sales, exchanges, or other dispositions on or after November 27, 2017. Final regulations under section 864(c)(8) were issued on November 6, 2020, with respect to transfers that occurred on or after December 26, 2018. See section 1.864(c)(8)-1(j) of the Regulations.

Any income from a foreign source that is equivalent to any type of income described above is treated as directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. For example, interest and equivalent dividends from foreign sources are treated as directly related to a U.S. occupation or business if the income is derived by a foreign person in the active conduct of a banking, financing, or similar business within the United States.

The income you receive during the tax year that is directly related to your occupation or business in the United States, after allowed deductions, is subject to the tax rates that apply to U.S. citizens and residents. Generally, you can receive directly related income only if you are a nonresident alien who participates in a U.S. occupation or business during the tax year. However, if you receive payments from the sale or exchange of property, the provision of services, or any other transaction during the tax year in which you do not participate in a U.S. occupation or business, but such payments would have been treated as directly related income in the year in which the transaction occurred or the services were provided, then they will be treated as directly related income in the tax year in which you received them.
You may choose to treat all income from real estate as directly related. See Income from Real Estate, later in this chapter.
The 30% (or lower rate under a treaty) tax rate applies to certain items of income or gains from U.S. sources but only if the items are not directly related to your U.S. occupation or business.

The 30% (or lower rate under a treaty) applies to the gross amount of U.S. source fixed, determinable, annual, or periodic (FDAP , for its acronym in English) income. Income is fixed when it is paid in known amounts in advance. Income is determinable when there is a basis for calculating the amount that is to be paid. Income may be periodic if it is paid from time to time. It need not be paid annually or in regular intervals. Income may be determinable or periodic although the time period during which payments are made increases or decreases. The items specifically included as fixed or determinable income are interest (other than discount from the original issue), dividends, alternative payments equivalent to dividends (defined in chapter 2), rents, premiums, annuities, salaries, wages, and other compensation. An alternative dividend or interest payment received under a securities loan or sale–repurchase transaction is treated as the amounts received in a value transferred. Other income, such as royalties, may also be subject to the 30% tax. Certain fixed or determinable income may be exempt from U.S. tax. See chapter 3 if you are not sure whether income is taxable.

Generally, nonresident aliens are subject to a 30% tax on gross income from gambling and betting won in the United States, if that income is not directly related to a U.S. occupation or business and is not exempt by a treaty. However, no tax is imposed on nonbusiness gambling income won by a nonresident alien while playing blackjack (21), baccarat (point and bank), dice, roulette, or big-6 wheel (roulette wheel) in the United States. Gross income from gambling won in the United States that is directly related to a U.S. occupation or business by a nonresident alien is subject to graduated rates. This income is exempt under certain tax treaties. See Table 1 of the Tax Treaty Tables, available at IRS.gov/TreatyTables, for a list of the tax treaties that exempt gambling income from U.S. taxation. For more information, see Publication 915.

A nonresident alien must include 85% of all Social Security benefits (and the Social Security equivalent portion of the Railroad Retirement benefit level 1) in the U.S. fixed or determinable annual or regular income. Social Security benefits include monthly retirement, survivor, and disability benefits. This income is exempt under certain tax treaties. See Table 1 (Table 1) in the Tax Treaty Tables (Tax Treaty Tables), available at IRS.gov/TreatyTables, for a list of treaties that allow Social Security benefits to be exempt from U.S. tax. For more information, see Publication 915.

The income in item (1) is not subject to the flat 30% (or lower under a tax treaty) rate if you elect to treat the income as directly related to a U.S. occupation or business. See Income from U.S. Real Property, later.

If you do not participate in a trade or business in the United States and have not established a tax year for a prior period, for purposes of the 183-day rule, your tax year will be the calendar year. In addition, you must file your tax return on the basis of a calendar year. If you were in the United States for less than 183 days during your tax year, capital gains (other than listed property) are exempt from tax, unless they are directly related to a trade or business in the United States during your tax year.

Declarar sus ganancias y pérdidas de las ventas o intercambios de activos de capital que no están directamente relacionados con una ocupación o negocio de los Estados Unidos en el Anexo NEC (Formulario 1040-NR). Declarar sus ganancias y pérdidas de las ventas o intercambios de activos de capital (incluyendo bienes inmuebles) que están directamente relacionados con una ocupación o negocio de los Estados Unidos en un Anexo D (Formulario 1040) o Formulario 4797, o ambos, por separado. Adjuntarlos al Formulario 1040-NR.

If you have income from real property located in the United States that you own or in which you have an interest and hold for the production of income, you may elect to treat all the income from that property as income directly related to a United States occupation or business. The election applies to all income from real property located in the United States and held for the production of income and to all income from any interest in such property. This includes rental income, royalties from mines, oil or gas wells or other natural resources. It also includes gains from the sale or exchange of domestic wood, coal or iron ore with a retained economic interest. You may make this election only for income from real property that is not directly related to your United States occupation or business. If you make the election, you may claim deductions attributable to the income from real property and only your net income from real property is subject to tax. This election does not treat a nonresident alien who otherwise would not participate in a United States occupation or business as if he or she were participating in a United States occupation or business during the year.

You can revoke the election without the approval of the IRS by filing Form 1040-X for the year in which you made the election and for subsequent years. You must file Form 1040-X within 3 years from the date of filing your return or within 2 years from the time the tax was paid, whichever is later. If this period has expired for the year of the election, you cannot revoke the election for that year. However, you can revoke the election for subsequent years only if you have the approval of the IRS. For information on how to obtain the approval of the IRS, see section 1.871-10(d)(2) of the Regulations.

This 4% tax applies to your gross transportation income from U.S. sources. This only includes transportation income that is treated as derived from sources within the United States if the transportation begins or ends in the United States. For personal services transportation, the transportation must be between the United States and a U.S. territory. For personal services of a nonresident alien, this only applies to income derived from, or in connection with, an aircraft.

Under this special rule, you are subject to taxes on your gross income and U.S. source gains in terms of net income at the graduated rates that apply to individuals (allowing deductions as permitted) for the period you were a nonresident alien, unless you were subject to a higher tax under section 871 (rules that normally apply to the income of a nonresident alien subject to tax, explained above) after taking into account any treaty tax benefits. For information on how to calculate this special tax, see Expatriation Tax, later.

If you are subject to this tax for any year in the period in which you were a nonresident alien, you must file Form 1040-NR for that year. The return must be filed by the due date (including extensions) of your U.S. income tax return for the year in which you became a U.S. resident again. If you have already filed returns for that period, you must file amended returns. You must attach a written statement to your tax return that identifies the source of all your U.S. and foreign gross income and the types of income subject to this special rule.

The expatriation tax provisions apply to U.S. citizens who have renounced their citizenship and long-term residents (LTRs) who have terminated their residency. The following section describes the expatriation rules under Section 877A that apply to persons who have expatriated on or after June 17, 2008. See Expatriation After June 16, 2008, below. If you expatriated before June 17, 2008, see Expatriation After June 3, 2004, and Before June 17, 2008 (Expatriation After June 3, 2004 and Before June 17, 2008) in Chapter 4 of Publication 519, 2018, and the Instructions for Form 8854, 2018. If you renounced your citizenship or terminated your long-term residency after June 3, 2004, and before June 17, 2008, you will still be considered a U.S. citizen or U.S. resident for tax purposes until you notify the Department of State or the Department of Homeland Security (as applicable) of your expatriation and file Form 8854 with the IRS.

You must file an initial Form 8854 in the year you renounce your U.S. citizenship or end your long-term residence, even if you are not a covered expatriate. In addition, you must file a Form 8854 annually after you expatriate if you are a covered expatriate and you: 1. Postponed the payment of the market value tax (see Postponement of the payment of the market value tax) below; 2. Have a qualified deferred compensation item; or 3. Have an interest in a non-granted trust.
For more information on payment deferral, see the Instructions for Form 8854.

You are considered to have terminated your long-term residence on the earliest of the following dates: 1. The date you voluntarily renounced your legal permanent resident status by filing Form I-407 with the Department of Homeland Security with an immigration or consular officer of the United States. 2. The date you became subject to a final administrative order that you abandoned your legal permanent resident status (or, if you appeal the order, the date of the final judicial order issued in connection with such administrative order). 3. The date you became subject to a final administrative order for your deportation from the United States under the Immigration and Nationality Act. 4. If you were a dual resident of the United States and a country with which the United States has a tax treaty, the date you began to be treated as a resident of that country under the provisions of the tax treaty and notified the IRS of that treatment on Forms 8833 and 8854. See Effect of Tax Treaties on the chapter 1 for more information about dual residents.

If you expatriated after June 16, 2008, you are treated as a covered expatriate, and the expatriation rules under Section 877A apply to you if you meet any of the following conditions: 1. Your average annual net income tax for the 5 years ending before the date of your expatriation or termination of residence is more than $201,000 if you expatriated or terminated your residence in 2024. 2. Your net worth is $2 million or more on the date of your expatriation or termination of your residence. 3. You did not certify on Form 8854 that you met all your U.S. federal tax obligations for the 5 years before the date of your expatriation or termination of your residence.

If you were a U.S. citizen who expatriated after March 18, 2010, you may be eligible for certain relief procedures that provide alternative means to satisfy the tax compliance process. For more information, see Relief Procedures for Certain Expatriates.

Certain dual nationals and certain minors (as defined below) are not subject to the exit tax even if they meet either (1) or (2) above. However, they still have to provide the required certification in (3) above.

You may qualify for the above described exception if the following conditions apply: At birth, you became a U.S. citizen and a citizen of another country and, as of the date of expatriation, continue to be a citizen of, and are subject to taxation as a resident of, that other country. You have been a U.S. resident for no more than 10 years during the 15-year period that ends with the tax year during which the expatriation occurs. For the purpose of determining residency in the United States, use the substantial presence test described in Chapter 1.

You may qualify for the above described exception if you meet both of the following requirements: You expatriated before you turned 18½. You have been a U.S. resident for no more than 10 tax years before the expatriation occurs. For the purpose of determining residency in the United States, use the substantial presence test described in Chapter 1.

In the year of expatriation, you are subject to income tax on the net unrealized gain (or loss) on your property as if the property had been sold at its fair market value on the day before the date of expatriation (the “market value tax”). This applies to most interests you held on the date of renunciation of citizenship or termination of residency. But see Exceptions, below. Gains from considered sales must be taken into account for the tax year of the considered sale regardless of other laws of the Internal Revenue Code of the United States. Considered loss sales must be taken into account to the extent otherwise required by the laws of the Internal Revenue Code of the United States. However, section 1091 (related to the denial of losses on considered sales of stock and securities) does not apply. The net gain that would otherwise be included in your income is reduced (but not to less than zero) by $866,000 if you expatriated or terminated your residency in 2024.

Instead, points (1) and (3) may be subject to withholding tax. In the case of point (2), you are treated as having received the present value of your accumulated benefit as of the day before your date of expatriation. In the case of point (4), you are treated as having received a distribution of your entire interest in the account as of the day before your date of expatriation. See Notice 2009-85 and the Instructions for Form 8854 for more information.

After you have determined your alien status, the source of your income, and whether that income is taxable in the United States and how, your next step is to calculate the tax. The information in this chapter is not as extensive for resident aliens as it is for nonresident aliens. Resident aliens will need to obtain publications, forms, and instructions for U.S. citizens, because the information for filing returns for resident aliens is generally the same as for U.S. citizens. If you are a nonresident alien and a resident alien in the same tax year, see Chapter 6 for a discussion of aliens with dual residency.

Non-resident aliens may claim some of the same deductions that resident aliens may claim. However, non-resident aliens may claim deductions only if they have income directly related to their occupation or business in the United States. There may be limitations that affect the amount of deductions you can claim on Schedule A. See the Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040) or Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) —Deductions on the Instructions for Form 1040-NR.

Foreign residents may claim the same itemized deductions as U.S. citizens by using the Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040). See Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040) for more information. If you do not itemize deductions, you may claim the standard deduction corresponding to your filing status for purposes of the return. For more information, see Instructions for Form 1040.

You may claim certain itemized deductions if you receive income directly related to your occupation or business in the United States. You generally can only include deductions and losses that are properly assigned and apportioned to income directly related to a United States occupation or business. You cannot include deductions and/or losses that are related to income exempt from tax or income not directly related to a United States occupation or business. However, you may deduct certain charitable contributions and losses due to a casualty or theft even though they are not related to your income directly related. Use Form 1040-NR Schedule A to claim itemized deductions. See the Instructions for Form 1040-NR.
Non-resident foreigners cannot claim the standard deduction. However, there is a special rule, described below, for certain non-resident foreigners from India.

See the Instructions for Form 4684 for more information about qualified disaster losses. To determine if you were affected by a major disaster (as declared by the federal government), go to IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.
Estas pérdidas no están sujetas a las limitaciones que aplican a la propiedad de uso personal. Use la Sección B del Formulario 4684 para calcular su deducción por estas pérdidas.

A special rule applies to students and apprentices in business who meet the requirements for the benefits of Article 21(2) of the US-India Tax Treaty. They may claim the standard deduction, provided they do not claim detailed deductions. Use Worksheet 5-1 to calculate your standard deduction for 2024. If you are married and your spouse files a return and details deductions, you cannot take the standard deduction.

If you are a business student or apprentice who meets the requirements for the benefits of Article 21(2) of the Tax Treaty between the United States and India that has been affected by a major disaster (major) declared as such by the federal government in 2024 (see IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief and FEMA.gov/disaster), you may choose to increase your standard deduction by the amount of your qualified disaster net losses related to your fortuitous personal property losses on your 2024 tax return. Use the 2024 Work Sheet 5-1 to calculate your standard deduction for 2024. See Form 4684 for 2024 and its instructions for more information about the tax benefits for qualified disaster net losses related to your fortuitous personal property losses.

You can deduct state and local income taxes you paid on income directly related to your occupation or business in the United States. Your deduction is limited to a combined total deduction of $10,000 ($5,000 if you're married and filing a separate return). If you received a refund or credit in 2024 for taxes you paid in a prior year, don't reduce your deduction by that amount. Instead, you have to include the refund or credit in your income if you deducted the taxes in the prior year and the deduction reduced your tax. See Recoveries (Recovery of funds) in Publication 525 for details on how to figure the amount to include in your income.

You may be able to deduct losses from accidents and thefts on your tax return. You can only deduct a loss from an accident or theft that is not business related if the loss is attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government. If your loss from an accident or theft is attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government, you can deduct your loss even if your property is not related to a trade or business in the United States. The property can be personal-use property or income-producing property not related to a trade or business in the United States. The property must be located in the United States at the time of the accident or theft. Theft losses only can be deducted in the year you discover the loss. Use Form 4684 and its instructions to figure your loss from an accident or theft that is deductible. For more information, see Publication 547.
For more information, see the instructions for line 7 under Instructions for Form 1040-NR —Detailed Deductions in the Instructions for Form 1040-NR. Also see Publication 529.

You may claim a credit, subject to certain limits, for income taxes you paid to or that you accrued with a foreign country for foreign source income. You cannot claim a credit for taxes you paid or accrued for foreign source income that is excluded. To claim a credit for income taxes you paid to or that you accrued with a foreign country, you generally will have to file Form 1116 along with your Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For more information, see Publication 514.

You may take this credit if you pay someone else to care for your eligible child under age 13 whom you claim as your dependent, or your disabled dependent or your disabled spouse, so you can work or look for work. For more information, see Form 2441 and Publication 503.

You may be eligible for this credit if you are 65 years old or older, or if you retired because of total and permanent disability. For more information about this credit, see Publication 524 and Annex R (Form 1040).

You may be eligible for these credits if you paid qualified tuition expenses for yourself, your spouse, or your dependent. There are two education credits: the American Opportunity Tax Credit and the Lifetime Learning Credit. You cannot claim these credits if you are married and filing a separate return. Use Form 8863 to figure the credit. For more information, see Publication 970. Nonresident aliens, see Education Credits under Nonresident Aliens, later.

You may be eligible for this credit (also known as the “saver’s credit”) if you made qualified contributions to an employer-sponsored retirement plan or to an IRA in 2024. Use Form 8880 and its instructions to figure the credit. For more information about the requirements for claiming the credit, see Publication 590-A.

A child adopted by you is always treated as your own child. An adopted child includes a child who was placed in your home legally for his or her adoption. If you did not have a SSN (or ITIN) issued in or before the filing deadline for filing your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for 2024 on your original or amended return. If your child did not have a valid SSN for work issued before the filing deadline for filing your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for this child but you may claim the credit for other dependents for this child. See Other dependents credit, later. Use Form 8812 (Form 1040) and its instructions to figure the credits.

The other dependents credit is for people who have dependents who cannot be claimed for the child tax credit. The eligible dependent must be a U.S. citizen or resident alien and have a SSN, ITIN or ATIN issued in or before the filing deadline for filing their 2024 return (including extensions). See Annex 8812 (Form 1040) and its instructions for more information.

You may be eligible to take a tax credit of up to $16,810 for qualified expenses paid to adopt a child who meets the requirements. This amount may be allowed to you for adopting a child with special needs regardless of whether you have qualified expenses. To claim the adoption credit, file Form 8839, Qualified Adoption Expenses, with your Form 1040 or 1040-SR.
The credits are allowed only if you receive income directly related. You may be able to claim some of the following credits.

If you receive income from foreign sources that are directly related to a trade or business in the United States, you may claim a credit for any income tax you paid to or that you accrued with a foreign country or U.S. territory on that income. If you do not have income from foreign sources that are directly related to a trade or business in the United States, you cannot claim credits against your U.S. taxes for taxes you paid to or that you accrued with a foreign country or U.S. territory. You cannot take a credit for taxes levied by a foreign country or U.S. territory on your U.S. source income if those taxes were levied only because you are a citizen or resident of the foreign country or territory. If you claim a credit for foreign taxes, you generally must attach Form 1116. See Publication 514 for more information.

You may take this credit if you pay someone else to care for your eligible child under age 13 whom you claim as your dependent, or your disabled dependent or your disabled spouse, so you can work or look for work. For the definitions of these terms, see Publication 503. Nonresident aliens who are married may claim the credit only if they file a joint return with a spouse who is a U.S. citizen or resident as explained under How to Make the Election in Chapter 1, or if they qualify as certain married persons who do not live together (see Joint Return Test (Joint Return Requirement) in Publication 503). The amount of your qualifying child and dependent care expenses for the credit in any tax year cannot be more than the amount of your U.S. work income for that tax year. Work income generally means wages, salaries, and professional fees for personal services performed. For more information, see Publication 503.
Additional information on the American Opportunity Tax Credit is available at IRS.gov/AOTC.
Use Form 8880 to calculate the credit. For more information, see Publication 590-A.

A child adopted by you is always treated as your own child. An adopted child includes a child who was placed in your home legally for his or her adoption. If you did not have a SSN (or ITIN) issued in or before the filing deadline for filing your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit on your original return or on an amended return. If your child did not have a valid SSN for working and issued before the filing deadline for filing your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for this child, but you may claim the credit for other dependents for this child. See Credit for other dependents, below. Use Form 8812 (Form 1040) and its instructions to calculate the credits.

Dependents who cannot claim the child tax credit may still qualify you for the other dependent credit. This is a nonrefundable credit of $500 per qualified person. The qualified dependent must be a U.S. citizen or resident alien. See Instructions for Form 1040-NR. To claim the other dependent credit, your dependents must have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued on or before the due date to file your 2024 return (including extensions). Only U.S. citizens; residents of Canada, Mexico, and South Korea; or residents of India who were students or trainees under the provisions of Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Tax Treaty may claim the other dependent credit.

You may be eligible to take a tax credit of up to $16,810 for qualified expenses paid to adopt a qualifying child. This amount may be allowed for the adoption of a child with special needs regardless of whether you have qualified expenses. To claim the adoption credit, file Form 8839 with your Form 1040-NR. Nonresident aliens married to U.S. citizens or residents may claim the credit only if they file a joint return with a spouse who is a U.S. citizen or resident as explained under Nonresident Alien Treaty as Resident in Chapter 1, or if they qualify as certain married persons not living together (see Married Persons Not Filing Jointly (Married Persons Not Living Together) in the Instructions for Form 8839).
If you paid the alternative minimum tax in a prior year, use Form 8801 and its instructions to see if you qualify for this credit.
You can claim the tax withheld during the year as a payment against your U.S. tax. You claim it on lines 25a to 25g of your Form 1040-NR. The tax withheld reduces any tax you owe on Form 1040-NR.

If you had two or more employers, you may be able to claim a credit against your U.S. tax liability for Social Security tax withheld in excess of the maximum required. See Social Security and Medicare Taxes in chapter 8 for more information.

If you are a shareholder in a mutual fund (or other regulated investment company (RIC , for its English acronym)) or real estate investment trust (REIT , for its English acronym), you may claim a credit for your share of any taxes paid by the company on its long-term capital gains not distributed. You will receive the information on a Form 2439, which you will attach to your return.

You may claim as a payment against any tax withheld at source on investments and other fixed or determinable income paid to you annually or periodically (FDAP, for its acronym in English). Fixed or determinable income includes interest, dividends, rents and royalties that you do not claim as income directly related. Salary or wage payments may be fixed or determinable income for you, but are usually subject to withholding as discussed above. Income tax withheld on fixed or determinable income is withheld at a 30% or lower rate under a tax treaty.

If you are a foreign partner in a partnership, the partnership will withhold tax on your share of the taxable income directly related to the partnership. The partnership will provide you with a Form 8805 showing the tax withheld. A partnership whose shares are traded on a stock exchange may withhold tax on its current distributions of directly related income. In such a case, the partnership will provide you with a Form 1042-S. Claim the tax withheld as a payment on line 25e or 25g of Form 1040-NR, as appropriate.

"English": "If you are a foreign direct or indirect partner in a U.S. or foreign partnership that engages (or is treated as engaging) in a trade or business within the United States and you directly or indirectly dispose of that interest resulting in a gain, then, for transfers that occur after 2017, the transferee generally will retain and pay to the IRS a portion of its own income equal to 10% of the amount received on the sale. The rules for the retention and payment of this amount are similar to the rules for sales of U.S. real property. You will receive a Form 8288-A showing the amount withheld that you then may claim as a credit against the tax due on the gain. You may be able to provide certain information to the transferee to reduce or eliminate the withholding. For example, if a nonrecognition provision of the Internal Revenue Code applies to all of the gain realized on the transfer, the transferee need not withhold the tax if you provide a notice describing the application of a nonrecognition provision. If you are a transferee who did not withhold, under section 1446(f)(4), the partnership may make the withholding on distributions to you.
