You may claim as a payment any tax withheld with respect to the disposition of a U.S. real property interest (or income treated as derived from the disposition of a U.S. real property interest). See Real Estate in Chapter 4, above. The buyer will give you a statement of the amount withheld on a Form 8288-A. Claim the withheld tax as a payment on line 25f of Form 1040-NR.

When you complete your tax return, be sure to record the correct amount of any taxes withheld shown on your information returns. The following table lists some of the common information returns and shows where to find the withheld tax amount.

If you are a non-resident alien who is a bona fide resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you are generally taxed in the same way as a non-resident alien. You must file Form 1040 or 1040-SR and report all income from sources within and outside the United States. However, you may exclude the income that is mentioned in the following paragraphs. However, for tax purposes other than income reporting, you will be treated as a non-resident alien. For example, you are not allowed the standard deduction, you cannot file a joint return, and you cannot claim a dependent, unless that person is a U.S. citizen or U.S. national. There are also limits on which deductions and credits are allowed. See Nonresident Aliens under Deductions, Deductions in Detail, and Tax Credits and Payments in this chapter.

If you are a bona fide resident of Puerto Rico for the entire year, you may exclude from your gross income all income from sources within Puerto Rico (except amounts for services performed as an employee of the United States or of any of its agencies). If you file your income tax return on the calendar year basis and do not have wages subject to withholding for 2024, file your return and pay your tax by June 16, 2025. You also have to make your first estimated tax payment for 2025 by June 16, 2025. You cannot file a joint income tax return or make joint estimated tax payments. However, if you are married to a U.S. citizen or resident, see Spouse Not Resident Treaty as Resident in Chapter 1. If you earn wages subject to withholding, the deadline to file your U.S. income tax return is April 15, 2025. You also have to make your first estimated tax payment for 2025 by April 15, 2025. For information on withholding and estimated tax, see Chapter 8.

If you are a bona fide resident of the American Samoa for the entire year, you may exclude from your gross income all income from sources within the American Samoa (except amounts for services as an employee of the United States or any of its agencies). An employee of the government of the American Samoa is not considered an employee of the United States or any of its agencies for purposes of this exclusion. For more information about this exclusion, see Form 4563 and Publication 570.

You must calculate your income and file a tax return based on a fiscal year of 12 consecutive months that ends on December 31. If you have not previously established a regular fiscal year, your tax year is the calendar year. A calendar year consists of 12 consecutive months that end on December 31. If you previously established a regular fiscal year (12 consecutive months that end on the last day of a month other than December or a 52 or 53 week year) and are considered a U.S. resident in any calendar year, you will be treated as a U.S. resident for any part of your fiscal year that corresponds to that calendar year.

The amount of your tax depends on your marital status for filing purposes. Your marital status for filing purposes is important in determining if you can take certain deductions and credits. The rules for determining your marital status for filing purposes are different for resident and non-resident aliens.
Foreign residents may use the same marital status for filing purposes as is available to U.S. citizens. See the instructions for your form or Publication 501 for more information on filing status.

Generally, you can file married filing jointly only if both you and your spouse were U.S. citizens or U.S. resident aliens for the entire tax year, or if you elect to be treated as a nonresident spouse, as explained in Chapter 1.

If your spouse died in 2022 or 2023 and you did not remarry before the end of 2024, you may qualify to file as a surviving spouse who meets the requirements and use the joint filing tax rates. This applies only if you could have filed a joint return with your spouse for the year your spouse died. For more information about filing status for a qualifying surviving spouse, see Qualifying Surviving Spouse under Filing Status for a Qualifying Surviving Spouse in the 2024 Form 1040 Instructions.

You may qualify as a head of household if you are not married or considered not married on the last day of the year and you paid more than half the cost of maintaining a home for you and a qualifying person. You must be a foreign resident for the entire tax year. You are considered not married for this purpose if your spouse was a nonresident alien at some time during the tax year and your spouse did not elect to be treated as a resident, as explained in Chapter 1 under Spouse Not Resident Treaty as Resident.
If you are a non-resident alien filing a Form 1040-NR, you may use one of the civil status states for purposes of the return explained below.

Non-resident aliens who are married and not married to U.S. citizens or residents generally must use the Table of Taxes or the Work Sheet for Calculating Tax for Married Filing Separately when determining the tax on income directly related to a U.S. occupation or business.

Foreign non-resident marrieds generally cannot use the Single column of the Tax Table or the Work Sheet for Calculating Tax for marrieds filing separately. However, you may be able to file as single if you lived separated from your spouse for the last 6 months of the year and you are a Canadian, Mexican or South Korean resident, or if you are a U.S. national who is married. See the Instructions for Form 1040-NR to see if you qualify. “U.S. national” is defined later in this section. A foreign non-resident generally cannot file as married filing jointly. However, a foreign non-resident who is married to a U.S. citizen or resident can elect to be treated as a resident and file a joint return on Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For more information about these options, see Chapter 1. If you do not make the election to file jointly, file Form 1040-NR and use the Single column of the Tax Table or the Work Sheet for Calculating Tax for marrieds filing separately.

A person who, although not a U.S. citizen, owes allegiance to the United States is considered a U.S. national. Moreover, U.S. nationals include the American Samoans (American Samoa) and the Northern Marianans (Northern Mariana Islands) who opted to become U.S. nationals instead of U.S. citizens.

You cannot file as head of household if you are a nonresident alien at any time during the tax year. However, if you are married, your spouse may qualify as head of household if: Your spouse is a resident alien or U.S. citizen for the entire tax year; You do not elect to be treated as a nonresident alien; and Your spouse meets the other requirements for this filing status, as explained above under Nonresident Aliens.
A foreign trust or heir that uses Form 1040-NR must use the rates in Annex W in the Instructions for Form 1040-NR when determining the tax on income directly related to a U.S. occupation or business.

A nonresident alien who is a bona fide resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year and who is temporarily working in the United States must consult Residents Bona Fide of the U.S. Virgin Islands or Puerto Rico, at the end of this chapter, for information on these special rules.

You must declare each taxable income item according to the rules in Chapters 2, 3, and 4. For resident aliens, this includes income from sources both within and outside the United States. For nonresident aliens, this includes income directly related to a U.S. occupation or business (subject to graduated rates) and income from sources within the U.S. that are not directly related (subject to a fixed 30% or lower rate under a tax treaty).

Foreign residents and non-resident aliens can claim similar deductions on their U.S. tax returns. However, non-resident aliens can generally claim only deductions related to income directly related to their U.S. occupation or business.

You may claim the same deductions allowed to U.S. citizens if you are a foreign resident for the entire tax year. Although the discussion below under Nonresident Aliens contains some of the same general rules and guidelines that apply to you, it is specifically directed to nonresident aliens. You must obtain the Instructions for Form 1040 for more information on how to claim your allowable deductions.

You can claim deductions to calculate your taxable income (CTI, for short). Generally, you can't claim deductions related to income that isn't directly related to your activities in the United States. Except for certain deductions explained below, you can claim deductions only to the extent they're related to your directly related income.

You can deduct all ordinary and necessary expenses incurred in carrying on your trade or business in the United States to the extent that they are related to income directly connected with that trade or business. For information on other business expenses, see Guide to Business Expense Resources.

If you paid interest in 2024 on a qualified student loan, you may be able to deduct up to $2,500 of the interest you paid. Generally, you can claim the deduction if you meet all the requirements. The deduction is claimed on line 21 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR. To calculate the deduction, see the instructions for Form 1040-NR. For more information, see Publication 970.

If you have income directly related to a trade or business in the United States, you may deduct up to 20% of your qualified business income from your trade or business, plus 20% of your qualified dividends from a real estate investment trust (REIT) or income (loss) from a publicly traded partnership (PTP) that is qualified. For more information, see Line 13a in the Instructions for Form 1040-NR. For more information about the deduction for qualified business income, see Form 8995, Form 8995-A and their attachments and instructions for the forms and attachments.

You may deduct losses resulting from transactions you have made for profit and which have not been reimbursed by an insurance, etc., to the extent that they are related to income directly connected with a U.S. occupation or business.

If you are a teacher who qualifies in 2024, you can deduct as a deduction from your income up to $300 of qualified unrefunded expenses that you paid or incurred during 2024 for certain professional development courses and for books, supplies (other than for health or physical education courses that aren't used in the performance of the sport), computer equipment (including computer programs (software) and related services), and other supplementary materials and supplies used in the classroom. For more information, see the instructions for your tax return. Qualified expenses include amounts paid or incurred in 2024 for personal protective equipment, disinfectants, and other supplies used to prevent the spread of coronavirus.

The moving expense deduction is only available if you are a member of the U.S. Armed Forces on active duty and, due to a military order, move because of a permanent change of station. For more information, see Publication 3, Armed Forces’ Tax Guide. If you qualify, use Form 3903 to figure the amount to deduct.

If you are self-employed, you may be able to deduct contributions to a SEP, a SIMPLE or a qualified retirement plan that provides retirement benefits for you and your employees, if any. To make deductible contributions for yourself, you must have net self-employment income that is directly related to your trade or business in the United States. See Publication 560, Retirement Plans for Small Business, for more information.

You must include in your income all interest income directly related that you receive or that is credited to your account during the year. Do not reduce it by any penalty you have to pay because you withdraw the funds before maturity from a term or time deposit. However, if the interest income is directly related to your occupation or business in the United States, you may deduct on line 18 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) the amount of the premature withdrawal penalty that the financial institution charged you. Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR.

If you do not report the SSN, ITIN or a taxpayer identification number in process of adoption (ATIN, for its English acronym) in the Dependents section of your tax return when it is required or if you report an incorrect number, you may be denied certain tax benefits. SeeTax Identification Number , previously.

If you are a foreign resident, a qualified dependent includes your qualified child or qualified relative. There are five requirements that must be met for a child to be your qualified child. There are four requirements that must be met for a person to be your qualified relative. For more information, see Instructions for Form 1040. If you don't report the SSN, ITIN or ATIN in the Dependents section of your tax return when it's required or if you report an incorrect number, you may be denied certain tax benefits. See Number Identification.

If you are a resident of Mexico or Canada, or a U.S. citizen, you can claim each of your dependents who meet certain requirements. Residents of Mexico or Canada, or U.S. nationals, must use the same rules as U.S. citizens to determine who is a dependent. See Publication 501 for these rules.

A non-resident alien who is a resident of South Korea (who is not an employee of the South Korean government) may be able to claim his or her child as a qualified dependent. In addition to using the same rules that U.S. citizens use to determine who is a dependent, under the tax treaty with South Korea, the child must have lived with the non-resident alien in the United States at some time during the tax year.

Students and apprentices in business who meet the requirements for Article 21(2) benefits of the US-India Tax Treaty may claim their dependents if they meet the same rules that are applied to US citizens.

You have a dual-status tax year when you have been a U.S. resident alien and a nonresident alien in the same year. Dual status does not refer to your citizenship; it refers only to your status as a U.S. resident. When determining your U.S. tax liability on U.S. income for a dual-status tax year, different rules apply to the part of the year you are a U.S. resident and the part of the year you are a nonresident. The most common dual-status tax years are arrival and departure years. See Foreign Residents with Dual Status in chapter 1. If you are married and elect to be treated as a nonresident spouse, as explained in chapter 1, the rules of this chapter do not apply to you for that year.

If you are a resident alien on the last day of your tax year and file your income on a calendar year basis, you must file your return by April 15 of the following year. If you file your income on a basis other than a calendar year, you must file your return by the 15th day of the fourth month following the close of your tax year. In either case, file your return by mailing it to the address for foreign residents with dual residency shown on the back of the Instructions for Form 1040 and 1040-SR. If you are a nonresident alien on the last day of your tax year and file your income on a calendar year basis, you must file your return by April 15 of the following year if you receive wages subject to withholding. If you file your income on a basis other than a calendar year, you must file your return by the 15th day of the fourth month following the close of your tax year. If you did not receive wages subject to withholding and file your income on a calendar year basis, you must file your return by June 15 of the following year. If you file your income on a basis other than a calendar year, you must file your return by the 15th day of the sixth month following the close of your tax year. In either case, mail your return to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 If you attach a payment, mail your return to: Internal Revenue Service P.O. Box 1303 Charlotte, NC 28201-1303 If the due date for filing your return falls on a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, the due date is the next day that is not a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday.

You must file your income tax return on the basis of a fiscal year called tax year. If you have not previously established a tax year, your tax year is the calendar year. A calendar year are 12 consecutive months that end on December 31. If you have previously established a regular fiscal year (12 consecutive months that end on the last day of a month other than December, or a year of 52 or 53 weeks) and are considered a U.S. resident in any calendar year, you will be treated as a U.S. resident for any part of your fiscal year that falls within that calendar year.

During the part of the year you are a foreign resident, you are subject to income tax on all sources. Income from sources outside the United States is taxable if you receive it while you are a foreign resident. Income is taxable even if you earned it while a nonresident alien or if you became a nonresident alien after receiving it and before the end of the year. During the part of the year you are a nonresident alien, you are subject to income tax on United States sources and on certain foreign source income that is treated as directly related to a United States occupation or business. The rules for treating foreign source income as directly related are explained in Chapter 4 under Foreign Income. Income from sources outside the United States that is not directly related to a United States occupation or business is not taxable if you receive it while a nonresident alien. The income is not taxable even if you earned it while a foreign resident or if you became a foreign resident or a United States citizen after receiving it and before the end of the year. Income from United States sources is taxable, regardless of whether you receive it as a nonresident alien or a foreign resident, unless it is specifically exempt under the Internal Revenue Code or a tax treaty provision. Generally, treaty provisions apply only to the part of the year you were not a resident. However, in certain cases, treaty provisions may apply while you were a foreign resident. See Chapter 9 for more information. In determining which income is taxable in the United States, you must consider the exemptions under United States tax law, as well as the reduced rates of tax and exemptions provided by tax treaties between the United States and certain foreign countries. For a detailed explanation of tax treaties, see Chapter 9.

You cannot take the standard deduction allowed on Form 1040 or 1040-SR. However, you can take any allowed deductions in detail.
You cannot use the column in the Tax Table or the Tax Calculation Worksheet for the marital status for the purpose of the head of family return.
You cannot file a joint return. However, see How to Choose the Foreign State of Residence under Foreigners with Double Residency in Chapter 1.

See the Instructions for Form 1040-NR to see if you qualify. A U.S. national is a person who, despite not being a U.S. citizen, owes allegiance to the United States. U.S. nationals include residents of American Samoa and the Northern Mariana Islands who elected to be U.S. nationals instead of becoming U.S. citizens.

As a dual resident taxpayer, you may be able to claim a dependent on your tax return. Generally, a dependent is a qualified child or a qualified relative. You may be eligible to claim additional deductions and credits if you have a qualified dependent. See the Instructions for Form 1040 or the Instructions for Form 1040-NR for more information. If you were a U.S. citizen or a resident of Canada or Mexico, you can claim a dependent in the same way as U.S. citizens. If you are a resident of South Korea or India, see Chapter 5.
When you calculate your U.S. tax for a dual-resident tax year, you are subject to different rules for the part of the year you are a resident and the part of the year you are not a resident.

All income from your U.S. residence period and all income directly related to a U.S. occupation or business for your non-residence period, after allowed deductions, are added together and the tax rate is determined that applies to U.S. citizens and residents. Income that is not related to a U.S. occupation or business during your non-residence period is subject to the fixed 30% rate or a lower rate under a treaty. You cannot claim any deductions against this income.

As a dual resident alien, you generally can claim tax credits using the same rules that apply to resident aliens. There are certain restrictions that may apply. These restrictions are explained here, along with a brief explanation of the credits that are usually claimed by individuals. You cannot claim the education credits, the EIC, or the credit for the elderly or disabled, unless you are married and choose to be treated as a resident for all of 2024 when you file a joint return with your spouse who is a U.S. citizen or resident, as explained in chapter 1 .

If you have paid or are responsible for paying a foreign country's income tax on foreign-source income, you may be able to claim a credit for foreign taxes. If you claim a credit for foreign taxes, you generally must file Form 1116 with your income tax return. For more information, see Form 1116 instructions and Publication 514.

You may qualify for this credit if you pay someone else to care for your eligible child who is under 13 years old and who you claim as a dependent, or your disabled dependent or your disabled spouse, so you can work or look for work. Foreigners with dual residency who are married may claim the credit only if they file a joint return, as explained in Chapter 1, or if they qualify as certain married people living apart. The amount of your expenses for the care of dependents that qualify for the credit in any tax year cannot be more than your work income for that tax year. For more information, see Publication 503 and Form 2441.
Use Form 8880 to calculate the credit. For more information, see Publication 590-A.

A child adopted by you is always treated as your own child. An adopted child includes a child who was placed in your home legally for his or her adoption. If you did not have a SSN (or ITIN) issued in or before the filing deadline for filing your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for 2024 on your original or amended return. If your child did not have a valid SSN for work issued before the filing deadline for filing your 2024 return (including extensions), you cannot claim the child tax credit for this child, but you may be able to claim the credit for other dependents for this child. See Other dependents credit below. Use Form 8812 (Form 1040) and its instructions to figure the credits.

The other dependents credit is for people who have dependents who cannot be claimed for the child tax credit. The qualified dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national, or foreign resident of the U.S. and must have an SSN, ITIN or ATIN issued in or before the filing deadline for their 2024 return (including extensions).

You may be eligible to take a tax credit of up to $16,810 for qualified expenses paid to adopt a child who meets the requirements. This amount may be allowed for the adoption of a child with special needs regardless of whether you have qualified expenses. To claim the adoption credit, file Form 8839 with your U.S. personal income tax return. Foreigners with dual residency who are married only may claim the credit if they elect the treated as a nonresident spouse state of residence, as explained in Chapter 1, or if they qualify as certain separated married persons (see Married Persons Not Filing Jointly (Married Persons Not Filing Jointly) in the Form 8839 Instructions).

You may claim as payments against your U.S. tax liability certain taxes you paid, that you are considered to have paid, or that were withheld from your income. These include: Withheld tax on wages earned in the United States, Withheld tax on various items of income from U.S. sources other than wages, Estimated tax paid with Form 1040-ES or Form 1040-ES (NR), and Tax paid with Form 1040-C at the time of leaving the United States.
The United States income tax return that you have to file as a dual resident alien depends on whether you are a resident alien or a nonresident alien at the end of the tax year.

All written declarations that you file must include your name, address and TIN. You do not need to sign a written declaration or separate attachment accompanying your return because your signature on the return also applies to the written declarations and supporting attachments.
The return you have to file, as well as when and where to file that return, depends on your status as a resident alien or nonresident alien at the end of the tax year.

Foreign residents must file Form 1040 or 1040-SR to the address shown in the Instructions for Form 1040. The deadline for filing your return and paying any tax due is April 15 of the following year after the year for which you file a return (but see ADVICE, above). Under U.S. immigration law, a legal permanent resident who is required to file a tax return as a resident and does not do so, may be considered to have abandoned his or her status as a resident and may lose permanently the status of a legal permanent resident.

Even if you left the United States and filed Form 1040-C upon departure, you still have to file a U.S. personal income tax return. If you are married and both you and your spouse are required to file, each of you must file a separate return.

If a foreign person owns in its entirety a domestic entity that is not considered separate from its owner (disregarded entity or DE , for its initials in English), the domestic DE is considered as a domestic corporation separate from its owner (the foreign person) to meet the limited requirements of Section 6038A that apply to 25% of domestic corporations whose owners are foreign. A foreign-owned domestic DE must file Form 1120 with the attached Form 5472 before the filing deadline (including extensions) of the return. The only information required to be considered as completed the Form 1120 is the name and address of the foreign-owned domestic DE and the entries B and E of the first part. A foreign-owned domestic DE may have had a tax requirement before 2017 if it had a U.S. occupation or business or other activity that otherwise had a tax requirement. See the Instructions for Form 5472 for additional information and coordination with the filing of the Form 5472 by the domestic DE. Also, note that because the DE is generally a transparent entity, the foreign person will include (or continue to include) any of the tax items that are subject to being declared on Form 1040-NR. A DE (foreign or domestic) may also have tax requirements related to payroll taxes and use and consumption taxes. See sections 301.7701-2(c)(2)(iv) and (v) of the Regulations.

If you are an employee and earned wages subject to US federal income tax withholding, you generally file your return before the 15th day of the fourth month after the end of your calendar year. For the calendar year 2024, file your return before April 15, 2025. If you are not an employee who earned wages subject to US federal income tax withholding, you must file your return before the 15th day of the sixth month after the end of your calendar year. For the calendar year 2024, file your return before June 16, 2025.

If you can't file your return by the due date, file Form 4868 or use one of the electronic filing options explained in the Instructions for Form 4868. For the 2024 tax year, the due date is extended to October 15, 2025. If your original due date is June 16, 2025, this will extend your due date to December 15, 2025. You must file the extension request before your return's regular due date. An automatic 6-month extension to file your tax return does not extend the time to pay the tax. If you don't pay the amount you owe by your return's original due date, you'll owe interest on the amount of tax you don't pay and perhaps have to pay penalties. See Form 4868 for more information.

The following credits are not affected by this time requirement: Tax credits. Special fuel use tax credits. Credit for taxes paid by a mutual fund (or other RIC) or REIT on long-term capital gains not distributed.

If your activities in the United States were limited and you do not believe that you had any gross income directly related to an occupation or business in the United States during the year, you may file a protection return (Form 1040-NR) by the deadline explained above. When you file a protection return, you protect your right to receive the benefit of deductions and credits in the event that part or all of your income is later determined to be directly related. You are not required to report any directly related income or any deductions on the protection return, but you must provide the reason for filing the protection return. If you believe that some of your activities resulted in income directly related, file your return to report that income and the related deductions before the regular due date. To protect your right to claim deductions or credits resulting from other activities, attach a written statement to that return explaining that you wish to protect your right to claim deductions and credits if it is later determined that the other activities produced directly related income. You may follow the same procedure if you believe that you have no tax liability in the United States because of a United States tax treaty. Be sure to complete also line L of Schedule OI (Form 1040-NR).

The IRS may not apply the filing deadline if you establish that, based on the facts and circumstances, you acted reasonably and in good faith in failing to file a federal income tax return (including a protective return) and you cooperate with the IRS in determining your U.S. income tax liability for the tax year for which you did not file a return.

You must file Form 8938 if the total value of those assets exceeds an applicable threshold (the “filing threshold”). The filing threshold varies depending on whether you live in the United States, are married or file a joint federal income tax return with your spouse. Financial assets include any financial account held by a foreign financial institution and, to the extent held for investment, any stock, securities or any other interest in a foreign entity and any financial instrument or contract with a non-U.S. issuer or counterparty. You may be subject to penalties if you are required to file Form 8938 and do not, or if you have an underpayment of tax due to any transaction involving a foreign financial asset not disclosed.

If you don't file your return and don't pay your taxes by the deadline, you may have to pay a penalty. You may also have to pay a penalty if you declare considerably less taxes than you owe, if you file a frivolous return (without a reasonable basis) or if you don't provide your TIN. If you provide false information in your return, you may have to pay a civil fraud penalty.

If you do not file your return by the due date (including extensions), you may have to pay a penalty for failing to file the return. The penalty is based on the taxes that have not been paid by the due date (including extensions). The penalty is usually 5% per month or part of a month that a return is late, but not more than 25%.

If a position on your return is attributable to a tax haven, there is no disclosure reduction. However, there is a reduction for a substantial authority position, but only if you reasonably believed that the tax treatment you elected was, more likely than not, the appropriate treatment.

Substantial authority for handling a tax matter depends on the facts and circumstances. Some points that might be considered are court opinions, Treasury regulations, revenue rulings, tax administrative procedures, and notices and announcements issued by the IRS and published in the Internal Revenue Bulletin (Internal Revenue Bulletin) that relate to circumstances that are the same or similar to yours.

To properly disclose the relevant facts of the tax treatment you give to a position, use Form 8275. You must have a reasonable basis for treating that position as you did. In cases of only substantially incomplete tax returns, positions that meet the requirements of Revenue Procedure 2024-44 (Revenue Procedure 2024-44), available at IRS.gov/irb/2024-52_IRB#REV-PROC-2024-44 (or its successor), are considered properly disclosed in your return. Revenue Procedure 2024-44 does not take into account the effect of changes in the tax law for tax years beginning after December 31, 2024. If a line referenced in this revenue procedure is affected by such a change and requires additional reporting, a taxpayer may need to file Form 8275 or Form 8275-R, Regulation Disclosure Statement, until regulations or other guidance are issued to comply with the requirement. A complete and accurate disclosure of a tax position in the UTP (Form 1120), Uncertain Tax Position Statement, of the applicable year is considered as if the corporation filed Form 8275 or Form 8275-R with respect to the tax position. However, the filing of a Form 8275 or Form 8275-R will not be treated as if the corporation filed an UTP (Form 1120). Use Form 8275-R to disclose items or positions that are contrary to the regulations.
For more information on foreign financial assets not disclosed, see section 6662(j) or the Instructions for Form 8938.

You will not have to pay a penalty if you can show a reasonable cause for the way you treated any item. You will also have to show that you acted in good faith. This is not applicable to a transaction that lacks economic substance.

You may be liable for a penalty if you file an incorrect refund or credit claim. The penalty is 20% of the amount of the claim rejected except where you can show a reasonable basis for the treatment you gave to any item. However, the reasonable basis does not apply to an amount that has been rejected because it is not economically reasonable. This penalty will not be calculated on any part of the amount of the claim for the credit for income from work or on which penalties for inaccuracy or fraud are charged.

You could have to pay a $5,000 penalty if you file a frivolous return or other frivolous documents. A frivolous return is a return that does not include enough information to calculate the correct tax or that contains information that clearly demonstrates that the tax you reported is substantially incorrect. For more information about frivolous returns and other frivolous documents and a list of positions that are considered frivolous, see Notice 2010-33 (Notice 2010-33), available on page 609 of Internal Revenue Bulletin 2010-17 (Internal Revenue Bulletin 2010-17), at IRS.gov/irb/2010-17_IRB#NOT-2010-33 (or the most current version). You will have to pay the penalty if you filed this type of return or document based on a frivolous position or by a desire to delay or interfere with the administration of the federal tax laws. This includes altering or erasing the preprinted text that appears above the space where you sign. This penalty is in addition to any other penalty imposed by law.
If there is an underpayment of tax on your return due to fraud, a penalty of 75% of the underpayment due to fraud will be added to the taxes due.

If you do not include your Social Security Number (SSN) or the Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) or the SSN or ITIN of another person as required in a tax return, written statement, or other document, you will be subject to a $50 penalty for each failure. You will also be subject to a $50 penalty if you do not give your SSN or ITIN to another person when it is required in a tax return, written statement, or other document. For example, if you have a bank account that earns interest, you must give your SSN or ITIN to the bank. That number must appear on Form 1099-INT or another report that the bank sends to you. If you do not give your SSN or ITIN to the bank, you will be subject to a $50 penalty. You may also be subject to additional withholding of income taxes. You will not have to pay the penalty if you can show that the failure was due to reasonable cause and not willful neglect.
If your failure to file the requirement is due to fraud, your fine is 15% for each month or part of a month that your return is late, up to a maximum of 75%.
If you file your return more than 60 days after the due date or the due date after a filing extension, the minimum penalty is $510 or 100% of the tax not paid, whichever is less.
You will not have to pay the penalty if you can show that you did not meet the requirement to file your return on time for a reasonable cause and not for intentional negligence.

You will have to pay a penalty for failure to pay the half (½) of 1% (that is, 0.005) of the taxes not paid for each month or part of a month after the due date in which the taxes were to have been paid. The penalty does not apply during the 6-month automatic extension period for filing the return if you paid at least 90% of your tax due by, or before, the due date for filing your return and pay the remaining balance when you file the return. The monthly penalty rate for failure to pay is half the regular rate, 1/4% (0.0025 instead of ½% (0.005)), if a payment plan is in effect for that month. You must have filed your return by the due date (including extensions) to qualify for the reduced penalty. If you are issued a notice of intent to levy, the rate will increase by 1% at the beginning of the first month at least 10 days after the day the notice is issued. If you are issued a notice and claim of immediate payment, the rate will increase by 1% at the beginning of the first month after the day the notice and claim of immediate payment is issued. The penalty cannot be more than 25% of your taxes due. You will not have to pay the penalty if you can show that you had a reasonable cause for not paying your taxes on time.

If both penalties, both for failure to file and for failure to pay taxes (explained above), correspond in any month, the 5% (or the 15%) of the penalty for failure to file will be reduced by the penalty for failure to pay taxes. However, if you file your return more than 60 days after the filing deadline or the filing deadline after an extension, the minimum penalty is $510 or 100% of the unpaid taxes, whichever is less.

The penalty is 20% of the insufficient payment. The penalty is 40% of any part of the insufficient payment that is attributed to an undisclosed transaction that lacks economic substance or to an undisclosed transaction of a foreign financial asset. This penalty will not be imposed on any part of an insufficient payment on which a fraud penalty, explained below, is imposed.

Negligence includes the failure to make a reasonable effort to comply with the tax law or to have a reasonable common sense in preparing a return. Negligence also includes the failure to keep adequate records and documentation. You will not have to pay a penalty for negligence if you have a reasonable basis for the position you took or if you can show a reasonable cause and that you acted in good faith. Negligence includes all negligence that is due to carelessness, irresponsibility (imprudencia) or intentional negligence.

You can avoid a penalty for failure to file a return or report if you disclose in your return a position that has a reasonable basis. See Disclosure statement, later. This exception does not apply to any item that can be attributed to a tax haven. Also, it does not apply if you fail to maintain proper books and records or if you do not properly substantiate the items.

You may be subject to criminal prosecution for actions such as: 1. Tax evasion; 2. Intentional failure to file, furnish information, or pay taxes due; 3. Fraud and false statements; or 4. Preparing and filing false returns.

Loss from fortuitous events are deductible during the tax year in which you sustain the loss. Usually, this is the tax year in which the loss occurred. However, you may be able to deduct a loss from fortuitous events in a later year than the year in which the fortuitous event occurred. See When to File and the Table 3, later.

The three types of losses refer to a disaster declared as such by the federal government, but the requirements are different for each type of loss. A “disaster declared by the federal government” is one that the President of the United States has determined meets the requirements for federal assistance under the Stafford Act. A disaster declared as such by the federal government includes (a) a major disaster declaration (major) or (b) an emergency declaration under the Stafford Act.

A federal accidental loss of an individual is a loss by accidental event or theft of personal property that is attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government. The loss must occur in a state that has received a federal disaster declaration. You are eligible to claim a deduction for accidental loss if you suffered a federal accidental loss. If you suffered an accidental loss or theft of personal property that is not attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government, it is not a federal accidental loss and you cannot claim a deduction for accidental loss, unless you qualify for an exception. Losses by theft incurred in a transaction made with a profit motive might still be deductible. See the Caution under Deductionable losses, below.

A disaster loss of an individual includes a loss by accidental fire or theft of personal property that is attributable to: A major disaster (as defined in section 401 of the Stafford Act) declared by the President; Hurricane Harvey; Harvey Tropical Storm; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; Uncontrollable wildfires in California in 2017 and January 2018; A major disaster declared by the President under section 401 of the Stafford Act before February 19, 2020 by a disaster that occurred in 2018 or during 2019, but before December 21, 2019, and which did not continue after January 19, 2020 (except those losses attributable to the uncontrollable wildfires in California in January 2018 (that already received tax relief previously)); and A major disaster declared by the President during the period between January 1, 2020 and February 10, 2025 (inclusive). In addition, this disaster has to have a period of incident that has begun on or after December 28, 2019 and on or before December 12, 2024 and that has not ended after January 11, 2025.

For tax years 2018 to 2025, accidental losses of personal-use property held by an individual are deductible only if they are attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government (federal accidental loss). Personal-use property is any other than business or income-generating property. If the event for which you suffered an accidental loss (not attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government) occurred before January 1, 2018, but you did not hold the accidental loss until January 1, 2018, or after, the accidental loss is not deductible. See When to Claim Losses and Gains, later, for more information about when a loss is held.
Loss of property due to damage caused by a family pet is not deductible as accidental loss unless the requirements mentioned above under Accidental Loss are met.

Loss of property due to progressive deterioration is not deductible as an act of God. This is because the damage occurs as a result of a cause that operates continuously or a normal process, rather than being the result of a sudden event. Here are some examples of damage caused by progressive deterioration: The gradual weakening of a building due to normal wind and weather conditions. Damage and damage caused to a water heater that explodes. However, rust and water damage to carpets and curtains caused by the explosion of the water heater is considered an act of God. Most losses of property due to drought. In order for a loss related to drought to be deductible, it is generally necessary to incur in the course of a trade or business or some transaction in which one participates for the purpose of profit. Damage by termites or moths. The damage or destruction of trees, shrubs or other plants caused by fungi, diseases, insects, worms or similar pests. However, if there is a sudden destruction due to an unexpected or unusual infestation of beetles or other insects, this may give rise to a loss by act of God.

Taking money or property by fraud or false statements is theft if it is an illegal act under state or local law.

For tax years 2018 to 2025, accidental losses of personal-use property held by an individual are deductible only if they are attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government (federal accidental loss). An exception to the rule that limits the deduction of accidental losses or theft of personal-use property to federal accidental losses applies if you have accidental gains of personal-use property. If so, you may deduct your accidental losses of personal-use property not attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government to the extent that they do not exceed your accidental gains of personal-use property.

You cannot deduct as a theft loss the decrease in value of the stock you acquired in the open market for investment purposes if that decrease is caused by the disclosure of a fraudulent accounting or other illegal conduct by the officials or directors of the corporation that issued the stock. However, you may be able to deduct it as a capital loss on Schedule D (Form 1040) when you sell or exchange the stock or if the stock loses all of its value. For more information about selling stock, stock without value, and capital losses, see chapter 4 of Publication 550.

The simple disappearance of money or property does not constitute a theft. However, an accidental loss or disappearance of property may be considered as a fortuitous event if it is the result of an identifiable event that occurs suddenly, unexpectedly or in an unusual manner. Sudden, unexpected and unusual events are defined in the previous section titled Fortuitous Event.

In order to deduct a loss by force majeure or theft, you must be able to demonstrate that such force majeure or theft occurred. You must also be able to demonstrate the amount you declare as a deduction as explained below.

If there is a loss by force majeure, you must be able to demonstrate all of the following: That you were the owner of the property or, if you rented it from someone else, you had the contractual responsibility to the owner for the damage. The type of force majeure (car accident, fire, storm, etc.) and the date it occurred. That the loss occurred as a direct result of such force majeure. If there is a claim for reimbursement with reasonable expectations of receiving it.

It is important that you have the necessary documentation to justify (verify) the amount of the deduction. If you do not have documents that corroborate or verify this deduction, you may use other types of satisfactory evidence for these purposes.
To determine the deduction to include in case of loss by force majeure or theft, first you have to calculate the loss itself.
In the case of personal-use property, apply the limits of the deduction that are explained later to calculate the amount of loss that you can deduct.

Si en el año del hecho fortuito hay una solicitud de reembolso con una expectativa razonable de recuperación de fondos, la pérdida no se sostiene hasta que usted sepa con certeza razonable que recibirá dicho reembolso. Si espera un reembolso parcial o total de la pérdida, tiene que restar la cantidad del reembolso esperado cuando calcule la pérdida. Tiene que reducir la pérdida aun si no recibe el pago hasta un año tributario posterior. Vea más adelante la sección titulada Reembolso Recibido Después de la Deducción de una Pérdida.

If your property is insured, you must file a claim with the insurance company in a timely manner. If you do not file a claim with the insurance company, you cannot deduct the entire amount of the loss that you have not been able to recover as a loss by accident or theft and you can only deduct the portion of the loss that is not covered by your insurance policy. The portion of the loss that is generally not covered by insurance (for example, a deductible) is not subject to this rule.
The most common type of reimbursement is payment of insurance for stolen or damaged property. Other types of reimbursements are explained below. See also Instructions for Form 4684.

If you receive money from your employer's emergency fund in the event of a disaster and you use that money to repair or replace property on which you claim a loss from disaster deduction, you must take that amount into account when you calculate that deduction. Take into account only the amount you used to replace the property that was destroyed or damaged.

Yes, if you are a victim of a disaster and receive cash gifts that are not taxable and there are no limits on how you can use the money, do not reduce the loss by accident with this type of gift. This is applicable even if you use the money to pay for repairs of the damaged property in the disaster.

Do not reduce the loss by force majeure with payments that you have received from the insurance to cover maintenance expenses in either of the following situations: If you lose the use of your main residence due to a force majeure. If the government authorities do not allow you access to your main residence by reason of a force majeure or by threat of that happening.
Ordinary maintenance expenses are those in which you would normally have incurred, but did not, because of an accident or the threat of one.

The taxable portion of the insurance payment is included as income during the year in which you again use your principal residence or, if later, the year in which you receive the taxable portion of the insurance payment.

Do not reduce your loss from a loan used to rehabilitate or replace the property for which you are claiming the loss deduction. If you have a federal loan that has been canceled (forgiven), see Federal Loan Canceled, later, under Disaster Losses.

If you calculated your loss by accident or theft, using the amount of the expected refund, you may have to adjust your tax return for the tax year in which you actually receive your refund. This section explains the adjustments you may have to make. If you paid any amount to repair damage to a personal residence with concrete foundation damage and claimed a deduction on your original or amended tax return and payments were made to you (or on your behalf to contractors) by the Connecticut Foundation Solutions Indemnity Company (CFSIC), you must include some or all of the payments in your gross income. See Announcement 2020-5, which is on page 796 of Internal Revenue Bulletin 2020-19, available at IRS.gov/irb/2020-19IRB#ANN-2020-5, for more information.

If you later receive a refund less than you expected, include that difference as a loss along with any other (if any) in the return for the year in which you reasonably expect to receive no additional refund.

You have a gain if the refund is greater than the adjusted base of the property. This occurs even if the decrease in the fair market value of the property is less than the adjusted base. If you have a gain, you may have to pay taxes on that amount or you may be able to defer reporting that gain. See How to Calculate a Gain, later.

There are two ways to deduct a loss of inventory by accident or theft, including items that you have for sale to customers. One way is to deduct the loss through the increase in cost of goods sold, declaring properly the beginning inventory and closing inventory. Do not again declare this loss as a loss by accident or theft. If you take the loss through the increase in cost of goods sold, include all insurance or other refunds you receive for said loss in your gross income. The other way is to deduct the loss apart. If you deduct the loss in this way, remove the affected inventory items from cost of goods sold, making a decrease adjustment to beginning inventory or purchases. Reduce the loss by the refund you receive. Do not include the refund in gross income. If you do not receive the refund by the end of the year, you cannot claim a loss while you have a reasonable expectation of recovery by such amount of the loss.

Si usted es responsable de los daños causados por un hecho fortuito a una propiedad que alquila, su pérdida es la cantidad que tiene que pagar para reparar la propiedad menos todo seguro u otro reembolso que reciba o espere recibir.

Generally, if a single fortuitous event or theft affects more than one item of property, you must calculate separately the loss for each item. Then, add the losses to determine the total amount of loss for that fortuitous event or theft.
The fair market value of goods immediately after a theft is considered zero, because you no longer have the goods.

Stolen property recovered is your property that was stolen and subsequently returned to you. If you recover property after having taken a deduction for theft loss, you must recalculate the loss using the lesser of the adjusted basis of the property (which is explained later) or the decrease in fair market value from the time immediately before it was stolen to the time it was recovered. Use this amount to recalculate the total loss for the year in which you took the deduction. If the recalculated amount of the loss is less than the loss you took, you generally must report the difference as income in the year you recovered it. But report the difference only up to the amount of the loss that reduced your taxes. For more information about the amount you must report, see Recoveries (Recovery of funds) in Publication 525.

To calculate the decrease in fair market value due to a fortuitous event or theft, you generally need a competent (credible) appraisal. However, other measures can also be used to establish certain decreases. See the topics Appraisals, Cleaning and Repair Costs, and Special Procedure — Safe Harbor Methods for Determining Losses from Theft or Fortuitous Event presented below.

You may use an appraisal used to obtain a federal government loan (or a federal government loan guarantee) as a result of a disaster declared as such by the federal government to establish the amount of your disaster loss. For more information about disasters, see later in this section the section titledDisaster Losses ..

The cost of restoring gardens to their original condition after a fortuitous event may indicate a decrease in the fair market value. You may be able to measure the loss by what you spend on the following activities: Remove destroyed or damaged trees and shrubs, less any residual value you received for the item. Prune and take other steps to preserve damaged trees and shrubs. Replant, if necessary, to restore the property to its approximate value before the fortuitous event.

The books of various automotive organizations that include information on the model and manufacturer of your car can be useful for calculating the value of the same. You can use the retail values of your vehicle that appear in the books and modify them according to factors such as mileage and the condition of your vehicle to calculate the value of the same. The prices are not official, but they could be useful for determining the value of the car and suggest relative prices that serve as comparison with sales and offers in your area. If your car does not appear in those books, determine the value based on other sources. The offer you receive from a dealer for your car as part of the payment for one new is usually not a calculation of its real value.

To calculate the amount of the loss from theft or accident, you generally have to determine the decrease in the fair market value of the lost or damaged property by means of a competent appraisal or by using the cost of the repairs that you actually make. However, the safe harbor methods in Revenue Procedure 2018-08 (Revenue Procedure 2018-08), which is on page 286 of Internal Revenue Bulletin 2018-02 (Internal Revenue Bulletin 2018-02), allow you to determine the decrease in the fair market value of other ways. Losses from accident of personal-use property that is held by an individual are only deductible if they are attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government. An exception to the rule that limits the deduction of losses from accident or theft of personal-use property applies if you have other-than-ordinary gains from personal-use property. If so, you may deduct your losses from accident or theft of personal-use property that are not attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government to the extent that they do not exceed your other-than-ordinary gains from personal-use property.

The Revenue Procedure 2018-08 (Revenue Procedure 2018-08), which is on page 286 of the Internal Revenue Bulletin 2018-02 (Internal Revenue Bulletin 2018-02), available at IRS.gov/irb/2018-02IRB#RP-2018-08, provides safe harbor methods that you can use to calculate the amount of your losses from theft or accidental destruction of your personal residential real property and personal property. If you meet the requirements for using and actually use the safe harbor methods described in Revenue Procedure 2018-08 (Revenue Procedure 2018-08), the IRS will not dispute your determination. Using the safe harbor methods described in Revenue Procedure 2018-08 (Revenue Procedure 2018-08) is not mandatory.

The replacement cost safe harbor method for federally declared disasters allows you to determine the fair market value of your personal use property located in a disaster area, immediately before a disaster declared as such by the federal government, to calculate the amount of your accidental loss or theft. To use this safe harbor method, you first have to determine the current cost to replace your personal use property with a new one and then reduce that amount by 10% for each year that you owned the personal use property. See the Personal Belongings Valuation Table in Revenue Procedure 2018-08. If you opt to use the replacement cost safe harbor method, then you have to use that method for all your personal use property, with certain exceptions identified in Revenue Procedure 2018-08. Each of these safe harbors is subject to additional rules and exceptions. For more information, see Revenue Procedure 2018-08.

Attach a written statement to Form 4684 that indicates that you used Revenue Procedure 2018-08 (Revenue Procedure 2018-08) to determine the amount of your loss from a casualty. Include the specific safe harbor method you used. When you complete Form 4684, do not enter an amount in line 5 or line 6 for each property. Instead, enter the decrease in fair market value determined under the safe harbor method in line 7. For losses from Hurricane Harvey, Hurricane Irma, and Hurricane Maria, see Revenue Procedure 2018-09 (Revenue Procedure 2018-09), which is on page 290 of Internal Revenue Bulletin 2018-02 (Internal Revenue Bulletin 2018-02), available at IRS.gov/irb/2018-02IRB/RP-2018-09 for the cost index safe harbor method.

Generally, a residential real property used for personal use is the real property, including improvements, which is owned by the individual who suffered a loss by force majeure and in which there is at least one residential property used for personal use. It does not include a residential property used for rental property or if any part of it is used as an office used for a trade or business or any transaction in which a profit is made. For more details, see Revenue Procedure 2018-08 (Revenue Procedure 2018-08). The safe harbor methods for residential real property used for personal use available through Revenue Procedure 2018-08 (Revenue Procedure 2018-08) are the following: Estimated repair cost method. De minimis method. Insurance method. Disaster declared by the federal government—contractor safe harbor. Disaster declared by the federal government—disaster loan appraisal.

The insurance safe harbor method allows you to calculate the decrease in the fair market value of your residential real property based on the estimated loss reported by your homeowners insurance company or flood insurance company. These reports must state the estimated loss you sustained due to damage or destruction of your property.

If the loss occurred in a disaster area and was due to a disaster declared as such by the federal government, then you may use the contractor's safe harbor method or the loan valuation method for disaster. Under the contractor's safe harbor method, you may use the cost to repair the specified repairs in a contract prepared by an independent and licensed contractor to determine the decrease in the fair market value of your residential rental real estate. This safe harbor method does not apply unless you are subject to a binding contract, signed by you and the contractor, establishing the detailed costs to restore your residential rental real estate to its condition immediately before the casualty.

According to the Disaster Loan Appraisal Method, you can use an appraisal prepared for a federal disaster loan (or a federal loan guarantee) that identifies your estimated loss as a result of a disaster declared by the federal government to determine the decrease in the fair market value of your residential real property.

The cost of protecting your property against a fortuitous event or theft is not part of the losses from a fortuitous event or theft. The amount you spend to protect your home from storms, whether in insurance or by putting boards over the windows, does not constitute part of the loss. If the property is commercial property, these expenses can be deducted as business expenses. If you make permanent improvements to your property to protect it from a fortuitous event or theft, add the cost of these improvements to the base of the property. An example would be the cost of a levee to prevent flooding.

You cannot increase the base in the property by the expenses you have incurred in relation to the qualified disaster payments (explained more below under Disaster Losses), nor can you deduct such expenses as business expenses.

Unforeseen expenses incurred by reason of a fortuitous event or theft, such as expenses for treatment of personal injuries, expenses for temporary housing or expenses for renting a car, are not part of your loss by fortuitous event or theft. However, they may be deductible as business expenses if the damaged or stolen property is business property.
The costs of replacing stolen or destroyed property are not part of the loss by force majeure or theft.

Do not consider sentimental value when calculating your loss. If a family portrait, heirlooms or mementos have been damaged, destroyed or stolen, you must base your loss only on the fair market value of these property, as limited by your adjusted basis in the property.

Photographs taken after the fortuitous event occurred will be used to establish the condition and value of the property after the damage. They may also be useful in showing the condition of the property after it has been repaired, restored or replaced. Appraisals are used to calculate the decrease in the fair market value by a fortuitous event or theft. For information on appraisals, see Appraisals under the section above titled How to Calculate the Decrease in the Fair Market Value —Points to Consider. The costs of photographs and appraisals used as evidence of the value and condition of the damaged property by a fortuitous event are not part of the loss. They are expenses that will help you determine your tax liability. For tax years 2018 to 2025, these expenses are no longer allowed as miscellaneous itemized deductions.

The basis of the property you own is the starting point. In the case of the property you purchase, the basis is usually what you pay for it. If you acquire property in some other way, for example, as an inheritance, gift or nontaxable exchange, you must figure the basis in a different way, as explained in Publication 551.

During the time you own your property, several events may occur that change the base. Some of these increase the base, such as the case of permanent additions or improvements to the property. Others, such as losses from accidents and deductions for prior depreciation, decrease the base. By adding the increases to the base and subtracting the decreases from the same, the result is the adjusted base. For more information on how to calculate the base of your property, see Publication 551.

After calculating the amount of your loss by force majeure or theft, you must calculate what percentage of the loss you can deduct. The deduction of losses by force majeure and theft of personal property is limited. For tax years 2018 through 2025, personal property force majeure losses sustained by an individual are only deductible to the extent they are attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government. Personal property force majeure or theft losses attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government are limited by the $100 per event and the 10% rules, explained below. The $100 and 10% rules are also summarized in Table 2. An exception to the rule (explained above), which limits the deduction of personal property force majeure or theft losses to those losses attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government, applies if you have gain from force majeure events in the tax year. If so, you can reduce your gain from force majeure events by any non-disaster force majeure losses. The excess of such gains, if any, is used to reduce disaster force majeure losses. The 10% of your adjusted gross income rule applies to the remaining disaster force majeure losses. Business and income-generating property losses are not subject to these rules. However, if the force majeure or theft loss included a residence that was used for business or rented to another person, your deductible loss may be limited. See the instructions for Section B in the Form 4684 instructions.

Once you have calculated the loss of personal-use property by a fortuitous event or theft, as explained above, you must subtract $100 from that loss. This reduction is applicable to each total loss by a fortuitous event or theft, including those losses that are not attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government that you use to reduce your fortuitous property gains. The number of items affected by the event is not important. Only one reduction of $100 will be allowed.

If you suffer more than one loss by accident or theft during the tax year, you must deduct $100 from each loss.
If two or more persons (other than spouses filing a joint return) have losses from the same fortuitous event or theft, the $100 rule will be applied separately to each person.

If you and your spouse file a joint return, your case is treated as one person when the $100 rule applies. It doesn't matter whether the property is both or each of you independently. If you and your spouse suffer a loss from a casualty or theft and file separate returns, each of you must deduct $100 from your loss. This is true even if both are owners of the property. If only one spouse is owner of the property, only that spouse can deduct the loss on a separate return. If the casualty or theft loss occurs on property that both spouses own in joint tenancy, each spouse can calculate his or her deduction only on half of the loss in separate returns. Neither spouse can calculate the deduction on the total loss in a separate return. Each spouse must deduct $100 from the loss.

If two or more people (other than spouses who file a joint return) suffer a loss of property in a joint property, the $100 separate rule applies to each. For example, if two sisters live in a house they bought together and have a loss by casualty in the house, each sister must apply the $100 separate rule.

You must subtract 10% of your adjusted gross income from your total federal fortuitous losses. Apply this rule after you've subtracted $100 from each loss. For more information, see Instructions for Form 4684. If you have fortuitous losses and gains, see later in this section under Fortuitous losses and gains.

If you have more than one loss from theft or accident during the tax year, reduce each loss by subtracting your refund and deducting $100. Then, subtract 10% of your adjusted gross income from the total of your theft losses.

If you and your spouse file a joint return, your case is treated as one person for the 10% rule. It doesn't matter if you jointly or separately own the property. If you file a separate return, the 10% rule will be applied to each return in which a loss is declared.
If two or more persons (other than spouses filing a joint return) have a loss of property in which they are jointly owners, the 10% rule will apply to each of them separately.

If you have gains from accidental events or theft, as well as losses of your personal use property, you must compare the total of gains with the total of losses. Do this after deducting refunds and $100 from each loss, but before deducting from federal accidental losses the 10% of your adjusted gross income. Accidental gains or losses do not include gains you have decided to postpone. See later the section titledPostponing the Filing of a Gain ..

If losses exceed gains recognized, subtract gains from losses and subtract 10% of your adjusted gross income from the result. The remainder, if any, is the loss deductible from personal-use property. If you have losses not attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government, see Line 14 in the instructions for Form 4684, because these can only be used to reduce gains. If you have disaster losses, see Line 15 in the instructions for Form 4684 for more information.

If your recognized gains exceed your recognized losses, subtract your losses from your gains. The difference is considered a capital gain and must be reported on Schedule D (Form 1040). The 10% rule does not apply to gains. If you have losses not attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government, see Line 14 in the Instructions for Form 4684.
Generally, you must first calculate the loss separately for each item stolen, damaged, or destroyed. However, there is a special rule for real property that you own for personal use.
To calculate a loss of real property that you own for personal use, all improvements (such as buildings, ornamental trees, and the land with improved areas) are considered together.

Personal property is any property that is not real property. If your personal property has been stolen or damaged or destroyed due to an act of God, you must calculate your loss separately for each item of your property. Then, add these amounts to get the total loss. Subtract $100 and 10% of your adjusted gross income from the total loss to determine your deduction for your loss.

When a fortuitous event includes both real and personal property, you must calculate the loss separately for each type of property. However, a single $100 reduction is applied to the total loss. Then, the 10% rule applies to calculate the deduction for the fortuitous loss.

When the property is used partly for personal purposes and partly for business or income-generating purposes, you must calculate separately the deduction for accidental loss or theft for the personal use part and the business or income-generating use part. You must calculate each separately, because the losses attributed to these two uses are calculated differently. When calculating each loss, allocate between the commercial and personal use of the property the total cost or base, the fair market value before and after the accidental loss or theft, and the amount covered by insurance or other refunds. The $100 and 10% rules apply only to the accidental loss or theft incurred in the personal use part of the property.

The amount received includes all money plus the value of all property received, less all expenses incurred in obtaining such refund. Also includes all refund used to pay the total balance of a mortgage or tax lien on damaged, destroyed or stolen property.

If you receive a gain because your principal residence was destroyed, you generally can exclude the gain from your income as if you had sold or exchanged it. You generally can exclude up to $250,000 of the gain (up to $500,000 if you're married and file a joint return). To exclude a gain, you generally must have owned the home and lived in it as your principal residence for at least 2 years during the 5-year period that ends on the date it was destroyed. See Publication 523 for more information about this exclusion. If your gain is more than the amount you can exclude, but you buy replacement property, you may be able to postpone reporting the excess gain. See later in this section under Postponing Reporting of an Excess Gain.

Generally, you must report the gain as income in the year you receive the refund. However, you will not have to report your gain if you meet certain requirements and decide to defer the filing of your gain under the rules explained below in the section Deferring Filing of a Gain. For more information on how to report a gain, see later in this publication the section titled How to Report Losses and Gains. If you receive a gain from a theft or accidental loss of personal property and have decided to defer the filing of that gain (as explained below) and you also have another theft or accidental loss of personal property, do not count the gain you will defer when you calculate the theft or accidental loss deduction.
