In the case of force majeure and thefts described in the condition (3) above, the gains cannot be offset against losses in determining whether the total gain exceeds $100,000. If a partnership is the owner of the property, then the $100,000 limit will apply to the partnership and to each partner. If the property belongs to an S corporation, the $100,000 limit will apply to the S corporation and to each of its shareholders.

According to this rule, related entities include, for example, a parent and a child, a brother and a sister, a C corporation and a person who owns more than 50% of its outstanding shares, and two partnerships in which the same C corporations are owners of more than 50% of the partnership capital or profits (earnings). For more information about related entities, see Nondeductible Loss under Related Persons in Chapter 2 of Publication 544.

If a taxpayer dies after obtaining a gain but before purchasing replacement property, the gain must be reported for the year in which the deceased realized the gain. The executor or the person with rights of succession to those funds resulting from the fortuitous event or theft cannot postpone the reporting of that gain by purchasing replacement property.

You must buy replacement property for the specific purpose of replacing the property that was destroyed or stolen. Property that you receive as a gift or inheritance does not meet the conditions in this case. You do not have to use the same funds that you receive as a refund of your previous property to buy replacement property. Even if you spend the money you receive from insurance on other things and then take out a loan to buy replacement property, you can postpone reporting the gain if you meet the other requirements.

If the gain from the refund you receive because of the destruction of your principal residence is more than the amount you can exclude from your income (see the topic Destruction of the principal residence in the section How to Calculate a Gain), you can postpone the reporting of any excess gain by purchasing a similar or related replacement property. To postpone the reporting of any excess gain, the replacement property must cost at least as much as the amount you receive because of the destruction, less the gain excluded. In addition, if you postpone reporting any part of the gain under these rules, you are considered to have been the owner and to have used the replacement property as your principal residence for the period you were the owner and used the destroyed property as your principal residence.
You must reduce the base of the replacement property (the cost) by the amount of the deferred gain. In this way, the tax on the gain is deferred until you dispose of the replacement property.

The standing timber (not the land) purchased with the gains (profits) received from the sale of fallen timber by a fortuitous event (such as strong winds, earthquakes or volcanic eruptions) meets the conditions to be considered a replacement property. If you purchased the standing timber within the replacement period stipulated, you can defer the reporting of that gain.

There are special rules that apply to property replacement in relation to damage or destruction of your principal residence (or its contents) if it is located in a disaster area declared as such by the federal government. For more information, see Disaster-Area Housing Income, later.

If you are a landlord-investor, the expression “similar or related in terms of the service or use it offers” means that, for you, the replacement property must be similar in terms of the services or uses it offers to the property that it replaces. You can determine this by answering the following points: If the property offers you a similar service. The nature of the business risks with respect to the property. What the property requires of you in terms of administration, service and relationship with tenants.

You can replace your property by acquiring a majority interest in a stock corporation that is the owner of similar or related property in terms of the service and use that they offer in relation to their own damaged, destroyed or stolen property. You can postpone the declaration of the total gain if the cost of the shares that give you a majority interest is at least equal to the amount received (reimbursed) for your property. You own a majority interest if you own shares that have at least 80% of the combination of all the votes for all classes of voting shares and at least 80% of the total number of any other type of shares.

If two or more assets fall into the same category, allocate the reduction to each asset in proportion to the adjusted bases of all assets in that category. No asset may have a reduced base that is less than zero.

You can postpone the date of declaration of a gain by force majeure or theft by recording it in the tax return for the year in which you received said gain. You obtain the gain in the year in which you receive the insurance refund or other refunds that result in gain. If a partnership or corporation is the owner of the stolen or destroyed property, only they can choose to postpone the declaration of said gain.

You must attach to your tax return for the year in which you realized the gain a written statement that includes the following information: Date and details of the accident or theft. Insurance or other reimbursements you received for the accident or theft. How you calculated the gain.

If you acquired replacement property before filing your tax return for the year in which you realized the gain, the written statement also must include detailed information on the following: Replacement property. Deferred gain. Adjusted basis reflecting deferred gains. Any gain you report as income.

If you intend to acquire replacement property after filing the tax return for the year in which you have the gain, the written statement also must indicate that you elect to replace the property within the required replacement period. You must then attach another written statement to the tax return for the year in which you acquire the replacement property. The statement must contain detailed information about the replacement property. If you acquire a part of the replacement property in one year and another part in another year, you must write a statement for each year. The statement must contain detailed information about the replacement property that was acquired in that year.

Once you have acquired the replacement assets you have designated as such in a written document attached to the tax return, you may not subsequently replace them with other assets that qualify. This is true even if you acquire the other assets within the applicable replacement period. However, if you discover that the original replacement assets were not assets that qualify, you may (within the applicable replacement period) replace them with new replacement assets that qualify.

You must file an amended return (individuals may use Form 1040-X) for the tax year of the gain in either of the following situations: If you do not acquire replacement property within the required replacement period, including extensions. In this amended return, you must report the gain and pay any additional tax due. If you acquire replacement property within the required replacement period, including extensions, but at a cost less than the amount you received by accident or theft. In this amended return, you must report the portion of the gain that you cannot defer and pay any additional tax due.

The period for determining the tax on all gains ends 3 years after the date on which you notify the director of the IRS in your area of any of the following situations: You replace the property. You do not intend to replace the property. You do not replace the property within the replacement period.

If you receive a refund of insurance or other type that is greater than the adjusted base in the property that was destroyed or stolen, you have a gain resulting from the fortuitous event or theft. You must include this gain in your income for the year in which you receive the refund, unless you decide to postpone the declaration of the gain, as explained above.

Generally, you can deduct a loss by casualty that is not refundable only in the tax year in which the casualty occurred. This is true even if you do not repair or replace the damaged property until a year later. (However, see the exception below in the section titled Disaster Losses). You can deduct losses by theft that are not refundable only in the year you discovered the property was stolen. If there is a refund request in the year of the casualty with a reasonable expectation of recovery of funds, the loss is not sustained until you know with reasonable certainty that you will receive said refund. If you are unsure whether you will be reimbursed any part of the loss by casualty or theft, do not deduct that part until the tax year in which you become reasonably certain that you will not be reimbursed. That later year is when you sustain the loss.
If your loss is a loss of deposits in a financially insolvent or bankrupt financial institution, see the previous section titled Monetary Deposit Losses.

If you rent property of another person, you may deduct a loss of the property in the year in which you determine your legal liability for the loss. This is applicable even if the loss occurred, or the amount for which you are liable was paid, in a year different from the year in which you determine your liability under the lease. You are not entitled to a deduction until you can determine your legal liability under the lease with reasonable accuracy. Your legal liability may be determined when you settle, adjudicate, or abandon a claim for recovery.

This section deals with special rules for losses in areas declared disaster areas by the federal government. It includes information on when you can deduct the loss, how to report the loss, how to treat your home in a disaster area, and what types of tax deadlines can be postponed. It also provides phone numbers for the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). (See below How to Contact the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA))). A disaster loss is a loss that has occurred in an area that the President of the United States has determined meets the requirements for receiving federal assistance under the Stafford Act and that is attributable to a disaster declared by the federal government. A disaster area includes areas that are eligible for public or individual assistance (or both). A disaster declared by the federal government covers all major disasters (or emergency declarations). A list of areas eligible for public or individual assistance (or both) under the Stafford Act is found on the Spanish-language website FEMA.gov/es/Disaster ...

Your home will be considered uninhabitable only if both of the following conditions are met: Your home is considerably more dangerous after the disaster than it was before the disaster. The danger comes from a substantial increase in the risk of destruction in the future due to the disaster.

When you choose to deduct the loss in the previous year, unless you have a disaster loss, as explained above, you must calculate the loss under the usual rules for accidental losses, as if it had occurred in the year before the disaster.

You must adjust your deductions on Form 1040-X. The Instructions for Form 1040-X show how to do this. Explain the reasons for your adjustment and attach Form 4684 to show how you calculated the loss. See How to Calculate a Loss, previously. If the damaged or destroyed property was not a business asset and you did not detail your deductions on the original tax return, you must first determine whether the deduction for casualty loss makes it advantageous for you to now detail the deductions. It is advantageous to detail the deductions if the total of your casualty loss deduction and all other deductions detailed is greater than your standard deduction. If you detail the deductions, attach to your amended tax return the Schedule A (Form 1040) or Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) and Form 4684. Complete Form 1040-X to recalculate your tax in the rest of the form and determine the amount of your refund.

You must keep records that verify your loss deduction. You don't have to attach them to the amended return. If your records were damaged or lost, you may be required to reconstruct them. You can find information about reconstructing records at IRS.gov/es/Newsroom/Reconstructing-Records-After-a-Natural-Disaster-or-Casualty-Loss or see Publication 3067, IRS Disaster Assistance - Federal Disaster Declaration Area.

It will be easier to prepare Form 1040-X if you have a copy of your tax return from the previous year. If a preparer helped you complete your return, he or she should be able to give you a copy. If not, you can get a copy by sending IRS Form 4506, Request for Copy of Tax Return. There is a charge for each return you request. However, if your principal residence, principal place of business, or tax records are located in an area declared by the federal government as a disaster area, the charge will not be made. Write in English the name of the disaster in the top margin of Form 4506 (for example: “ Tennessee Tropical Storm Helene ” (Tennessee Tropical Storm Helene)).

If your inventory loss qualifies as a fortuitous loss and is attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government in an area that FEMA has determined meets the requirements for public or individual assistance (or both), you may choose to deduct the loss on the return or the amended return for the year immediately before. However, decrease the initial inventory for the year of the loss, so you don't declare it again in the inventory section.
If part of your federal disaster loan was canceled under the Stafford Act, the canceled amount is considered a refund of the loss. The cancellation reduces your loss deduction.

Do not include in your income disaster assistance payments you received under the Stafford Act, if the payments are to help you cover necessary expenses or emergency needs for medical, dental, housing, personal property, transportation, or funeral services. Do not deduct losses from force majeure or medical expenses until the point at which these losses are specifically reimbursed by those payments. If the payment specifically reimbursed the force majeure loss and you received the payment after the year in which you took the deduction for that loss, see Reimbursement Received After Taking a Deduction for a Loss, above. Payments of unemployment assistance received under the Stafford Act are taxable unemployment compensation.

A grant received by a company through a state program to reimburse companies for losses suffered by damage or destruction of property due to a disaster is not excluded from income under the general exclusion for welfare, as a gift, a payment qualified as disaster assistance (explained below) or a contribution to capital. However, the company may elect to defer the reporting of its gain from that grant if it purchases eligible replacement property within a certain time period. See Deferring Reporting of a Gain, above, for more information on the applicable rules.

Disaster assistance payments also include amounts that the federal, state, or local government has paid to individuals affected by a disaster declared as such by the federal government. These payments must be made from a government fund, must be based on individual or family need, and may not be paid as compensation for services rendered. Typically, payments made to businesses do not meet the requirements as disaster assistance payments.
You cannot take a credit or deduction, or increase the basis of your property, in relation to any expense for which you were compensated by a qualified fire disaster payment.

Disaster relief payments made under the Stafford Act or the National Flood Insurance Act (as in effect on April 15, 2005) are not included in income. You receive these payments, as a property owner, to reduce the risk of future damage to your property. You cannot increase the basis in the property, or take a deduction or credit for expenses incurred in connection with those payments.

Generally, if you sell or exchange property, you must report all gain or loss for tax purposes, unless the property is your main home. You report the gain or deduct the loss on your tax return for the year you realize the gain or loss. (You cannot deduct a loss on personal-use property, unless the loss was from an accident, as explained above). However, if you sell or otherwise exchange property to the federal government, a state or local government, or a tribal government of American Indians under a hazard mitigation program, you may postpone reporting the gain if you buy qualified replacement property within a certain time. See the section titled Postponement of Reporting a Gain, above, for information about the rules applicable to this case.

The IRS can postpone certain tax deadlines for up to one year for taxpayers affected by a disaster declared by the federal government. Tax deadlines that the IRS can postpone include those for filing income tax returns, sales and use tax returns, and payroll tax returns; and also can postpone deadlines for paying income tax, sales and use tax, and payroll tax as well as those for making contributions to a traditional IRA or a Roth IRA. If a tax deadline is postponed, the IRS will announce this postponement in its area through a press release and, as necessary, in revenue procedures, revenue rulings, notices, announcements, and other communications in the Internal Revenue Bulletin (IRS Bulletin or IRB, for short) that can help you. Visit IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief and click on Español to see if any tax deadlines have been postponed in your area.

If the IRS delays a tax deadline, the following taxpayers are eligible for this delay: Any individual whose principal residence is located in a disaster area with coverage (as defined below). Any business entity or sole proprietor whose principal place of business is located in a disaster area with coverage. Any individual who is providing humanitarian assistance and is affiliated with a recognized governmental or charitable organization and is providing assistance in a disaster area with coverage. Any individual, business entity or sole proprietor whose records are needed to comply with a tax deadline already delayed, provided that such documentation is maintained in a disaster area with coverage. It is not necessary that the principal residence or principal place of business be located in the disaster area with coverage. Any estate or trust that has tax records needed to comply with a tax deadline already delayed, provided that such documentation is maintained in a disaster area with coverage. The spouse who files a joint return with a taxpayer who is eligible for a delay. Any individual, business entity or sole proprietor not located in a disaster area with coverage but whose records needed to comply with a tax deadline already delayed are maintained in such disaster area with coverage. Any individual who visited the disaster area with coverage and who has died or suffered injury as a result of the disaster. Any other individual that the IRS determines has been affected by a disaster declared by the federal government.
This is a disaster area declared by the federal government in which the IRS has decided to postpone tax deadlines for up to one year.

Certain taxpayers affected by disasters declared as such by the federal government that occur after December 20, 2019, may be eligible for a mandatory 60-day extension of certain tax filing deadlines such as filing and paying income, sales and use, and payroll taxes; and for making contributions to a traditional IRA or Roth IRA arrangement. The period that begins on the earliest incident date specified in the disaster declaration and that ends on the date that is 60 days after the earliest incident date or the disaster declaration, whichever is later, is the period during which tax deadlines are extended. For information on disaster assistance available in your area, including extensions, go to Around the Nation.
The IRS can reduce the interest and penalties on taxes that are not paid in full for the length of any tax filing deadline extension.

You can get information by visiting DisasterAssistance.gov/es or calling the following phone numbers. These numbers will only be activated after a disaster is declared by the federal government. 800-621-3362. Dial 711 and provide the operator with the Telecommunications Relay Services (TRS, for short) number 800-621-3362 if you are deaf, have a hearing disability, or have a speech impairment.

The year of disaster is the tax year in which you sustained a loss attributable to a disaster declared as such by the federal government. Generally, a disaster loss is sustained in the year the disaster occurred. However, it is possible to sustain a disaster loss in a later year than the year in which the disaster occurred. For example, if there is a refund claim for which there is a reasonable expectation of recovery, no part of that disaster loss for which a refund may be received is a loss sustained until it can be determined with reasonable certainty that you will be reimbursed.

Generally, you must deduct a loss from a casualty in the year of the disaster. However, if you have a loss from a casualty by a disaster declared as such by the federal government that occurred in a public assistance or individual assistance (or both) area, you may choose to deduct that loss on your return or an amended return for the tax year immediately before the year of the disaster. If you make this election, the loss is treated as if it had occurred the year before. A list of public assistance or individual assistance (or both) areas is available on the FEMA website at FEMA.gov/es/Disaster. You must make the election to claim a loss from a casualty by the disaster in the year before the due date for filing your original return (without extensions) for the disaster year. If you are a taxpayer who follows the calendar year for filing your tax returns, you have until October 15, 2025, to amend your 2023 tax return to claim a loss from a casualty that occurred during 2024.

If you have already filed your tax return for the previous year, you can choose to claim a disaster loss against your income of that year by filing an amended return. Individual tax returns are filed using Form 1040-X. (See How to Claim the Disaster Loss on Form 1040-X, later). To make this election, complete Part I of Section D of Form 4684 for 2023 and attach the same to your 2023 tax return or amended tax return in which you claim the disaster loss deduction. You must make the election to claim the loss in the previous year no later than six (6) months after the regular due date for filing your original tax return (without extensions) for the year of the disaster. If you are a calendar year taxpayer, the due date for making the election to take the 2024 disaster loss deduction on your 2023 tax return is October 15, 2025. See the 2023 Form 4684 Instructions for more detailed information on how to claim these losses on your original or amended tax return for 2023. If you claimed a deduction for a loss caused by a disaster on your tax return for the disaster year and you want to deduct the loss in the previous year, you must first file an amended return to remove the previously claimed loss deduction. This amended return must be filed no later than the date you file your return or amended return for the previous year in which you include the disaster loss deduction. Claiming a qualified disaster loss on your tax return for the previous year may result in a lower tax for that year, which often produces or increases a cash refund.

Complete Section D, Part II of Form 4684 for 2023 if you want to revoke the disaster year election to deduct a disaster loss that was declared as such by the federal government that occurred in 2024 in the preceding year. Attach the completed Section D to your amended return for the prior tax year (i.e., an amended 2023 return to revoke the disaster year election for a disaster loss that occurred in 2024). You must file your amended return to revoke the election by the 90th day after the due date for making the election and no later than the date you file your return or amended return for the year in which you include the disaster loss deduction. In your amended return (revoking the previously elected disaster loss deduction), you must recalculate your tax liability as a result of revoking the election. You must pay or make arrangements to pay any tax or interest due as a result of the revocation.

Disaster losses of an individual include losses by accidental fire or theft of personal property that are attributable to: A major disaster (as defined in section 401 of the Stafford Act) declared by the President; Hurricane Harvey; Harvey Tropical Storm; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; Uncontrollable wildfires in California in 2017 and January 2018; A major disaster declared by the President under section 401 of the Stafford Act for a disaster that occurred in 2018 or during 2019, but before December 21, 2019, and which did not continue after January 19, 2020 (except those losses attributable to the uncontrollable wildfires in California in January 2018 (which already received tax relief previously)); A major disaster declared by the President during the period between January 1, 2020 and February 10, 2025. In addition, this disaster has to have an incident period that began on or after December 28, 2019 and on or before December 12, 2024 and which did not end after January 11, 2025.

The alternative minimum tax (AMT) adjustment for the standard deduction has been made inapplicable retroactively to disaster-qualified net losses. See Taxpayers who also file the 2024 Form 6251, Alternative Minimum Tax for Individuals in the Instructions for Form 4684 for more information.

If your home is located in a town that the federal government has declared a disaster area, you may postpone filing the gain if you spend the refund to repair or replace your home. There are special rules for replacement property related to the damage or destruction of your principal residence (or its contents) if your home was located in one of these areas. For more information, see Disaster Area Home Sales, previously.

If your home is located in a town that the federal government has declared a disaster area, your local or state government may order you to demolish or move it, because it is not a safe place to live because of the disaster. If this happens, treat the loss in value as a loss by force of nature due to disaster. Your local or state government must issue a demolition or move order within 120 days after the area has been declared a disaster area. Calculate the loss the same way you calculate losses by force of nature for personal property. (See the previous section How to Calculate a Loss). To determine the decrease in the fair market value, use the value of the home before moving or demolishing it as the fair market value after the force of nature.

The work income credit (EIC, for its English acronym) is a tax credit for those who work and who receive income from work less than $66,819. A tax credit usually means that you will have more money at your disposal. It reduces the amount of tax you owe. The EIC could also provide you with a refund.

If none of the situations listed above apply to you, the instructions for the tax form probably contain all the information you need to know if you can claim the EIC and to calculate the amount of the credit. You may not need this publication, but you can read it to see if you can claim the EIC and to learn more about this credit.

No. You may qualify for the EIC even if you don't have a qualified child if you are at least 25 but less than 65 years old and your work income is less than $18,591 ($25,511 if married and filing a joint return). See Chapter 3.

If you can claim the EIC, you have the option of asking the IRS to calculate the credit for you or you can calculate it yourself. To calculate it yourself, you can complete the worksheet that is included in the instructions for the form you file. To find out how to ask the IRS to calculate the amount of the credit, see chapter 4.

Your AGI must be less than: $59,899 ($66,819 if married filing jointly) if you have three or more eligible children with a valid SSN, $55,768 ($62,688 if married filing jointly) if you have two eligible children with a valid SSN, $49,084 ($56,004 if married filing jointly) if you have one eligible child with a valid SSN or $18,591 ($25,511 if married filing jointly) if you do not have an eligible child with a valid SSN.

If you are married but qualify to file as head of household or married filing separately under certain special requirements for married taxpayers living apart (see Requirement 3) and live in a community property state, your AGI includes the part of your salary as well as your spouse's that you must include in gross income. This is different from the community property requirements under Requirement 7.

To claim the EIC, you (and your spouse if you file a joint return) must have a valid SSN issued by the Social Security Administration (SSA, for its initials in English) for the due date of your 2024 tax return (including extensions). Your eligible child must have a valid SSN issued for the due date of your 2024 tax return (including extensions) for you to claim a higher amount of EIC based on that child. If you have at least one eligible child who meets the requirements to be an eligible child for purposes of claiming the EIC, but that child does not have a valid SSN issued for the due date of your 2024 tax return (including extensions), you may qualify to claim the EIC only for yourself if you otherwise meet the requirements to claim it. For more information about how to complete Form 1040, Schedule 1 (Form 1040) if your eligible child or children do not have a valid SSN issued by the due date of your 2024 return, see Form 1040, Schedule 1 (Form 1040). An SSN is valid for purposes of the EIC unless it was issued after the due date of your 2024 return (including extensions) or it was issued solely for requesting or receiving a federally funded benefit and does not authorize the person to work. A federally funded benefit is an example of Medicaid. If you, your spouse, or your child has a Social Security card with the phrase “Not Valid for Employment” printed on the card and the immigration status of you, your spouse, or your child has changed, so the person is now a U.S. citizen or permanent resident, ask the SSA for a new Social Security card without that inscription.

Sara Rojas is 63 years old and retired. Sara received $7,000 in Social Security benefits during the year and $17,000 from a part-time job. She also received payments from a taxable pension of $7,400. Sara received no other income. Her AGI in line 11 of the 1040 is $24,400 ($17,000 + $7,400). Sara is not married and lived alone in the United States during the entire year. Sara cannot be claimed as a dependent on another person's return, she did not receive any investment income, and she does not have a qualified child. Sara checks to see if she qualifies to claim the EIC by reading the steps in the Instructions for Form 1040. In Step 1, she discovers that because her AGI of $24,400 is not less than $18,591, she cannot claim the EIC. Sara completes the rest of the 1040 and files it with the IRS.

Cielo and Jaime Ramírez have two children, ages 10 and 8. The children lived with them during the entire 2024 tax year. Cielo's salary was $15,000 and Jaime's $18,030. The Ramírezes received $525 of interest from a savings account. They did not receive any other income in 2024. Cielo and Jaime have the 2024 Form 1040 and its instructions. They want to know if they qualify for the EIC. Therefore, they follow the steps for line 27 that appear in the instructions for Form 1040.

The amount that Cielo and Jaime entered on line 11 of the 1040 was $33,555. Both have valid SSNs, which they have had for several years. They are married and will file a joint return. Cielo and Jaime are not foreign residents. Therefore, the answers to the questions in Step 1 allow them to proceed to Step 2.
The only investment income the Ramírezes received is the $525 of interest. The amount is not greater than $11,600; therefore, they answer “No” to the second question of Step 2 and proceed to Step 3.

Your children meet the relationship, residency, age, and joint filing requirements to be qualified children of Cielo and Jaime, so Cielo and Jaime answer “Yes” to the first question in Step 3. Your children are not qualified children of another person. Both have valid SSNs, which they obtained at birth. Cielo and Jaime are filing a joint return; therefore, they answer “Yes” to the second question in Step 3. This means they can skip questions 3 to 6 and Step 4; and proceed to Step 5.
Cielo and Jaime calculate that their work income is $33,030, the amount of their combined salaries. This amount is less than $62,688, so they continue to Step 6 to calculate their credit.
Cielo and Jaime want to calculate their EIC themselves; therefore, they complete the EIC Worksheet in the Instructions for Form 1040.

Cielo and Jaime complete their work sheet in the following manner: 1. Cielo and Jaime enter their total earnings from work ($33,030) in line 1. 2. To determine the credit, they consult the 2024 Income Credit Table (EIC). They find their work income, $33,030, in the range of $33,000 to $33,050. Since both of their children have a valid SSN, they follow the horizontal reading under the married joint filers heading, until the 2 children column in that section. They find and write $6,247 in line 2. 3. In line 3, they write their AGI of $33,555 and notice that it is different from the amount in line 1. 4. They look up $33,555 in the 2024 Income Credit Table (EIC) and write $6,131 in line 5. 5. They write $6,131 in line 6. This is the smallest amount between the amount in line 2 ($6,247) and the amount in line 5 ($6,131). 6. The Ramírezes write $6,131 in line 27 of the 1040 form. Now they will complete the EIC form and attach it to their return. They will keep the EIC work sheet for their records.

In this post, we discuss who can represent a taxpayer before the IRS and what forms or documents are used to authorize a person to represent a taxpayer. Often, attorneys, certified public accountants (CPA) and registered agents can represent taxpayers before the IRS. Registered agents for retirement plans and registered actuaries can offer representation with respect to the Internal Revenue Code sections specified in Circular 230, in English. In limited and particular circumstances, other persons, including tax preparers, family members, employees and non-registered students, may represent taxpayers before the IRS. For more information about taxpayer representation, see the section Who Can Act for a Taxpayer? below.
Many of the terms used in this publication, such as "registered agent" and "professional" are defined in the Glossary, which is at the end of this publication.

Any person may, for the purpose of compensation, prepare or assist in the preparation of a tax return, claim a refund, appear as a witness for a taxpayer before the IRS, or provide information at the request of such entity or any of its officers or employees.

The following persons are subject to the regulations set forth in Circular 230, in English. However, any person who is generally authorized to practice (a recognized representative) must be designated as a representative of the taxpayer and file a written statement with the IRS in which it is stated that such person is authorized and qualified to represent a particular taxpayer. Form 2848(SP) may be used for such purposes.

All persons who prepare appraisals that justify the valuation of property in relation to one or more federal tax matters are subject to the regulations set forth in Circular 230, in English. Appraisers have no representation rights, but may appear as witnesses on behalf of taxpayers.

Due to their special relationship with a taxpayer, the following persons may represent the specified taxpayers before the IRS, provided they present satisfactory identification and, except in the case of a person described in (1) below, a proof of authority to represent the taxpayer. 1. A person. A person may represent himself or herself before the IRS and need not present a written statement of qualification and authority. 2. A member of the immediate family. A person may represent immediate family members. The immediate family may be a spouse, child, daughter, son, parent, mother, father, brother or sister of the person. 3. An officer. An officer of a corporation (which includes a parent, subsidiary or other affiliated corporation), partnership or organized group may represent any of these three entities. An officer of a unit, authority or governmental agency, in the course of his or her official duties, may represent these entities before the IRS. 4. A partner. A general partner may represent a partnership before the IRS. 5. An employee. A full-time regular employee may represent his or her employer. An employer may be, among others, any person, partnership, corporation (for example, a parent, subsidiary or other affiliated corporation), association, trust, syndicate, guardianship, estate, organized group or unit, governmental agency or authority. 6. A trustee. A trustee (trustee, executor, personal representative, administrator, syndic, guardian or guardian ad litem) is in the position of a taxpayer and acts in that capacity and not as a representative. See Trustee in the section When a Power of Attorney Is Not Required, below.
Any person may represent another or a foreign entity before the IRS when such representation also occurs outside the United States. Refer to section 10.7(c)(1)(vii) of Circular 230, in English.

Any CPA who is not currently suspended or disbarred from practicing before the IRS or who is otherwise duly qualified to practice as a CPA in any state, territory, possession, or commonwealth of the United States, or in the District of Columbia may practice before the IRS.
Any agent registered in good standing who is not currently suspended or disqualified (disbarred) from practicing before the IRS may practice before this entity.

All registered retirement plan agents in good standing who are not currently suspended or disabled from practicing before the IRS may practice before this entity. The practice of registered retirement plan agents is limited to certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code that are associated with their area of expertise, particularly those sections under which employee retirement plans are governed.

Any person who registers as an actuary through the Collective Board for the Registration of Actuaries and who is not currently suspended or disqualified from practicing before the IRS may practice before this entity. The practice of registered actuaries is limited to certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code that are associated with their area of expertise, particularly those sections under which employee retirement plans are governed.

In certain circumstances, a student who is under the supervision of a practicing professional in the tax program of a law school or equivalent through which tax services are provided to low-income taxpayers may request authorization to represent a taxpayer before the IRS. For more information, see Special Appearance Authorization later in this section.

A registered tax preparer is a person who is not an attorney, CPA, registered agent, registered retirement plan agent, or registered actuary and who prepares and signs the tax return of a taxpayer as a paid preparer or prepares a return but is not required (pursuant to the instructions of the return or regulations) to sign it. Registered tax preparers may represent taxpayers only before IRS inspectors, customer service representatives, or similar IRS officials and employees (including the Taxpayer Advocate Service) and only during a review of the tax returns that they prepared and signed prior to December 31, 2015. These preparers may not represent taxpayers before appeal officials, tax collection officials, advisors, or similar IRS or Treasury Department officials or employees. In addition, they may not enter into closing agreements, extend the period of limitations for assessments or collection, sign waivers, or sign any document on behalf of a taxpayer. If a preparer of this type does not meet the requirements for limited representation, you may authorize him or her to inspect or request your tax information by filing Form 8821, Tax Information Authorization, in English. Completing this form does not authorize the preparer to represent you before the IRS. For more information, see Form 8821 and its instructions separately, both available in English.

Generally, individuals who are not eligible, or who have lost the privilege as a result of certain actions, cannot practice before the IRS. If a person loses eligibility to practice, the IRS will not recognize a power of attorney under which they are named as representative.

Generally, people lose their eligibility to practice before the IRS in the following ways: They fail to meet the requirements for renewal of registration (such as continuing professional education). They apply to be registered agents in inactive retirement status. The Office of Professional Responsibility suspends or disbarred or finds them ineligible to practice because they violated regulations under Circular 230, in English, or the Internal Revenue Manual 81-38, in English. They lose their state license to practice as attorneys or certified public accountants, regardless of the basis for the revocation of the license.

The IRS will notify individuals who are registered and who hold the tax compliance record of the Annual File Season Program (AFSP, for its English acronym) that they do not meet the eligibility requirements for renewal. In the notice, the reason for the ineligibility will be explained and the person will be given an opportunity with strict deadlines to provide information for reconsideration.

People who are registered and request to be placed in inactive retirement status are not eligible to practice before the IRS. They must continue to meet all renewal requirements. They can re-establish themselves in active registration by filing a renewal application and showing proof that they have completed the required hours of continuing professional education for the registration cycle.

All persons who practice before the IRS are subject to disciplinary procedures and are susceptible to censures, suspensions, debarments, or monetary penalties for violating any of the regulations set forth in Circular 230, in English. This includes engaging in acts that demonstrate incompetence or misconduct. For more information, see Incompetence and misconduct under the section What are the rules for practice?, above. Professionals who are suspended or debarred in the course of a disciplinary proceeding may not represent taxpayers before the IRS during the period of suspension or debarment. A professional may apply for reinstatement to the Office of Professional Responsibility during a specific period of suspension or after five years of debarment, whichever occurs first. See What is practice before the IRS?, above. If the practicing professional applies for reinstatement, he or she may not practice before the IRS until the Office of Professional Responsibility grants such reinstatement. The Office of Professional Responsibility may reinstate the practicing professional: If, by future conduct, this person is not susceptible to violating the regulations. If granting reinstatement is not contrary to the public interest. Subject to other conditions for a reasonable period of time.

The IRS website IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Enrolled-Agents/Become-an-Enrolled-Agent, in English, provides complete information on the steps you must take to become an Enrolled Agent. To learn about the complete requirements for getting an Annual Filing Season Program Record of Completion, visit IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/General-Requirements-for-the-Annual-Filing-Season-Program-Record-of-Completion, in English.

The rules governing practice before the IRS are published in Subpart A, Section 31, Part 10 of the Federal Regulations and are posted online as Treasury Department Circular 230, in English. Regulations can be accessed at IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Circular-230-Tax-Professionals, in English. A lawyer, CPA, registered agent, registered retirement plan agent or registered actuary authorized to practice before the IRS (hereinafter referred to as the practicing professional) and an appraiser have duties to perform certain acts and are restricted in performing other acts. Also, the practicing professional may not be engaged in conduct of bad reputation (hereinafter referred to as bad conduct). Practicing professionals who fail to comply with the practice rules or who are engaged in incompetent or bad conduct are subject to disciplinary action. In addition, non-registered preparers must comply with the practice and conduct standards for the limited privilege of practicing before the IRS. There are two specific sets of standards that apply, both established pursuant to Circular 230: 1. Duties and restrictions for practice (Subpart B of Circular 230, in English). 2. Conduct considered to be a source of incompetence or bad reputation (Section 10.51, Subpart C of Circular 230, in English).

People subject to Circular 230 must file, without delay, the returns or information upon the appropriate and lawful request of IRS officials or employees, except when the practicing professional in tax matters reasonably and in good faith believes the information is privileged. Communications about tax advice between the practicing professional in tax matters authorized by the federal government (see section 7525 of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC, for its acronym in English)) and a taxpayer, generally, are confidential to the same extent that the communication would be privileged if it were between a taxpayer and an attorney in the case of advice relating to: Tax matters that are not of a criminal nature before the IRS; or Criminal tax proceedings and the United States files in a federal court or against the United States.

This protection for tax advice communications does not apply to written communications between a tax professional in practice with federal authorization and any other person, including a director, shareholder, officer, employee, agent or representative of a corporation if the communication involves the promotion of direct or indirect participation by such corporation in any tax haven.

A person who is in compliance with Circular 230 and who knows that his client has not complied with the income tax laws or has committed an error or omission in any return, document, statement, or other document required, has the responsibility to inform the client immediately of the noncompliance, error, or omission, and the consequences that may result therefrom.

People subject to Circular 230, in English, must exercise due diligence when performing the following tasks: Prepare or provide assistance for the preparation, approval and filing of returns, documents, declarations and other documents relating to IRS matters. Determine the accuracy of verbal or written representations that said person has made to the Treasury Department. Determine the accuracy of verbal or written representations that this person has made to clients with respect to any matter administered by the IRS.

The presumption of due diligence will apply in situations where the product of another person's work has been relied upon if, in a reasonably prudent manner, the person was involved, supervised, trained and evaluated, taking into account the nature of the relationship between the person as set forth in Circular 230 and the person.

People who are in compliance with Circular 230 may not take acuses de recibo, administer juraments, certify documents, or perform other official acts in the capacity of a Notary Public with respect to matters administered by the IRS and for which they have been employed as attorneys, lawyers, or agents, or in which they may have an interest in any way.

People who are subject to Circular 230 may not endorse or otherwise negotiate any check (including directing or accepting payment by any electronic or other means into an account that the practicing professional, or a company or other entity with which the subject is associated, owns or controls) that the government has issued to a client with respect to a federal tax liability.

People who are subject to Circular 230 may be disqualified (disbarred) or suspended from practice before the IRS, or censured, for incompetence or misconduct. A monetary penalty may be imposed, in addition to any other discipline, on individuals and their businesses. The following list illustrates examples of conduct that is considered misconduct. Other examples are set forth in section 10.51(a) of Circular 230, in English. Being convicted of any crime under the internal revenue laws or of any crime involving dishonesty or breach of trust. Giving, knowingly, false or misleading information relating to federal tax matters or engaging in such activity. Applying for employment by means prohibited, as set forth in section 10.30 of Circular 230, in English. Failing to file, intentionally, a federal tax return, evading or attempting to evade any federal tax or payment, or engaging in such actions. Misappropriation, or failure to remit appropriately and timely, funds received from clients for a tax payment or other obligation due to the United States. Attempting directly or indirectly to influence IRS official action by means of threats, false accusations, coercion, or bribery, or by offering gifts, favors, or any special inducement. Being disqualified (disbarred) or suspended from practice as an attorney, CPA, public accountant, or actuary, by the District of Columbia or any state, possession, territory, commonwealth, or any federal court, or any agency, instrumentality, or board of the United States. Knowingly assisting and encouraging another person to practice before the IRS during a period of suspension, disqualification, or ineligibility of that other person. Using offensive language, making false accusations or statements knowing that they are false, circulating or publishing malicious or defamatory matters, or engaging in any disrespectful conduct relating to practice before the IRS. Providing a false opinion knowingly, recklessly, or by gross incompetence or engaging in a pattern of providing incompetent opinions on questions arising under the federal tax laws.

The Secretary of the Treasury, or delegate, after notice and opportunity for a hearing, may disqualify, suspend, or debar a person from practice before the IRS under Circular 230 if it is shown that the person is not competent or of good reputation, does not comply with the regulations in Subpart B, or, with intent to defraud, intentionally and knowingly deceives or threatens a client or prospective client. Disqualification is a public reprimand. Persons under Circular 230 may be attorneys, certified public accountants, registered agents, registered retirement plan agents, or registered actuaries who participate in the representation of the taxpayer or in advisory activities, as well as the holders of the Annual Filing Season Program Compliance Registration who represent taxpayers and appraisers engaged in appraising property for federal tax purposes.

A power of attorney is your written authorization for a person to receive your confidential tax information from the IRS and perform certain actions on your behalf. If the authorization is not limited, the person, generally, can perform all the acts that you can perform, except negotiate or endorse a check. It is limited the authority granted to registered retirement plan agents, registered actuaries and non-registered return preparers who are holders of compliance records. To obtain information about the limits on compliance record holders, see IRS Publication 5300, IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Return-Preparer-Office-RPO-At-a-Glance, both in English.

Attorneys, certified public accountants, and registered agents may perform the following acts: 1. Represent you before any IRS office or employee. 2. Sign an offer or a waiver of restriction for the determination or collection of a tax deficiency or a waiver of notice of rejection of a claim for a credit or refund. 3. Sign a consent to extend the legal period for the determination or collection of a tax. 4. Sign a closing agreement.
When a representative signs a return, it must be accompanied by a power of attorney (or a copy) under which you authorize him to sign it. For more information, see Instructions for Form 2848(SP).

A recognized representative may substitute or delegate authority under the power of attorney to another recognized representative only if you specifically authorize such an act in the power of attorney. After a substitution has been made, only the representative most recently recognized will be recognized as the representative of the taxpayer. If a power of attorney has been delegated, the IRS will recognize both the original representative and the delegate to represent the taxpayer.

Your representative cannot sign consents under which the IRS is permitted to disclose your tax return or return information to a third party, unless you specifically authorize this power to your representative on line 5a of Form 2848(SP).

However, the legal power may continue in the case of your disability or incompetence if you authorize it in the line 5a entitled "Other acts authorized" of Form 2848(SP) and if your durable power not belonging to the IRS meets all the requirements for the institution to accept it. See the section Powers not belonging to the IRS, further down." }{ "English": "A legal power, generally, is terminated if you become disabled or incompetent. However, the legal power may continue in the case of your disability or incompetence if you authorize it in the line 5a entitled "Other acts authorized" of Form 2848(SP) and if your durable power not belonging to the IRS meets all the requirements for the institution to accept it. See the section Powers not belonging to the IRS, further down." }

Submit a power of attorney when you want to authorize a person to receive your confidential tax information and to represent you before the IRS, whether or not the representative performs any of the other acts cited above in What is a power of attorney?. Most often, a power of attorney is required when you want to authorize another person to perform, at least, one of the following acts on your behalf: 1. Represent you at a meeting with the IRS. 2. Prepare and file a written response to an IRS inquiry.

Use the Form 2848(SP) to designate a recognized representative to act on your behalf before the IRS. The persons recognized to represent you before the IRS are listed in Part II. Representative's Declaration of Form 2848(SP). Your representative must complete that part of the form.Use the Form 2848(SP) to designate a recognized representative to act on your behalf before the IRS. The persons recognized to represent you before the IRS are listed in Part II. Representative's Declaration of Form 2848(SP). Your representative must complete that part of the form.

The IRS will not accept your non-IRS power of attorney if it does not contain all of the above information. You may sign and send a completed Form 2848(SP) or a new non-IRS power of attorney that includes all this information. If you cannot sign an acceptable replacement document, your representative may perfect (make acceptable to the IRS) your non-IRS power of attorney by following the procedure described below.
The following tips are summaries of some of the line-by-line instructions for Form 2848(SP).

Generally, you can send a Form 2848(SP) paper copy directly to the IRS by mail or fax. To determine where to file the Form 2848(SP), see Where to File the Form , in the Instructions for Form 2848(SP). If this form is intended for a specific use, send it by mail or fax to the office that is handling the matter. For more information about specific uses, refer to Line 4. Specific use not listed in the (CAF) , in the Instructions for Form 2848(SP).

The IRS accepts copies of the legal powers that are sent by fax transmission. If you choose to submit a legal power by fax, make sure that the IRS office concerned is equipped to accept this type of transmission. !This is an Image: taxtip.gif Your representative can submit Form 2848(SP) electronically through the IRS website. For more information, your representative can visit IRS.gov/eServices, in English. If you complete Form 2848(SP) for electronic signature authorization, do not submit it to the IRS. Instead, give it to your representative to keep.

Send all updates or changes made to an existing power of attorney in writing. A signature (or the signatures of the persons authorized to sign on your behalf) is required. For this purpose, send Form 2848(SP) or an updated non-IRS power of attorney to the IRS offices where you previously sent the originals, including the service center where the related return was filed or will be filed. A recognized representative may substitute or delegate authority if you specifically authorize him to substitute or delegate the representation in the original power of attorney. For purposes of making a substitution or delegation, the representative must file the following documents with the IRS offices where the power of attorney was filed: 1. A written notice of substitution or delegation signed by the recognized representative. 2. A written statement from the representative making the new representative. 3. A copy of the power of attorney under which the substitution or delegation is specifically authorized.

Pursuant to a recently filed legal power that relates to the same matter, a legal power that was filed before will be revoked. However, the prior legal power will not be revoked by a new legal power if, in the latter, it is specifically stated that the prior power will not be revoked and if one of the following documents is attached to the new power: A copy of the prior unrevoked legal power; or A written statement signed by the taxpayer specifying the name and address of each authorized representative under the prior unrevoked legal power.

Revoke the power of attorney that is currently in effect and do not wish to appoint a new representative. Write "REVOKE" (Revoke) at the top of the first page of Form 2848(SP) with the current signature and date immediately below this notation. Then, mail or fax a copy of the power of attorney with the notation about the revocation to the IRS as indicated in the table titled Where to File the Form, in the Instructions for Form 2848(SP), or, if the power is for a specific matter, to the IRS office that manages the matter. If you do not have a copy of the power of attorney that you wish to revoke, you must send to the IRS a statement of revocation in which you state that the power of attorney has been revoked, specify the matters and years or periods, and mention the name and address of each recognized representative whose power is being revoked. You must sign and date this statement. If you intend to revoke the power in its entirety, write "Remove all years/periods" in place of specifying the specific matters and years or periods.

If your representative wishes to withdraw from the representation, this representative must write "WITHDRAW" (Retire) on the top of the first page of Form 2848(SP) with the current signature and date immediately below the annotation. Then, the representative must provide a copy of the power of attorney with the withdrawal annotation to the IRS as described in the section Revocation of the taxpayer, previously. If your representative does not have a copy of the power of attorney that you wish to withdraw, this representative must send to the IRS a written statement indicating the withdrawal in which it is indicated that the power of attorney is withdrawn, the matters and years or periods and the name, taxpayer identification number (TIN, for its acronym in English) and address (if known) of the taxpayer. The representative must sign and date the written statement. The power of attorney that a student has will be registered in the CAF system for 130 days from the date of receipt. If you authorize a student to represent you after that period, you must send another Form 2848(SP) updated.

"English": "This is an Image: caution.gif For tax years of the partnership beginning after December 31, 2017, the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015 (Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015), which repealed the procedures and rules for the audit and litigation of partnerships under the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982 (TEFRA) applicable to the election of large partnerships and replaced them with a new centralized audit regime for partnerships, eliminated the figure of "tax matters partner" and replaced it with "partnership representative". In accordance with Treasury Regulation 301.9100-22T, certain partnerships may elect that the new regime apply to the returns of those partnerships for tax years beginning after November 2, 2015 and before January 1, 2018."

A power of attorney will be recognized after the IRS receives and reviews and determines that it contains the required information. However, until a power of attorney is entered into the CAF system, IRS staff may not be aware of the authority of the person you have named to represent you. Therefore, during this interim period, IRS staff may request that you or your representative bring a copy to any meeting with the IRS.
The manner in which legal power is processed or managed depends on whether it is a complete or incomplete document.

If Form 2848(SP) is incomplete, IRS will attempt to obtain the missing information by contacting you or your representative in writing or by telephone. For example, if your signature or date of signature is missing, IRS will contact you. If information about your representative is missing and there is sufficient information in the document for communication (such as an address or telephone number), IRS will attempt to contact your representative. In any case, the power of attorney is not valid until all required information is entered in the document. The person(s) named as representative(s) will not be recognized as your representative before IRS for the year in question until the document is complete and IRS accepts it.

If the power is complete and valid, IRS will take steps to recognize the representative. In most cases, this includes processing the document in the CAF system. The registration of data in the CAF system allows IRS to send correspondence to authorized representatives and easily recognize the scope of authority granted.

After a valid power of attorney is filed, the IRS will recognize your representative. However, if, apparently, the representative is responsible for unduly delaying or obstructing the prompt resolution of an IRS matter by not providing, after repeated requests, non-privileged information, it is possible that this institution will contact you directly. For example, in most cases where a power of attorney is recognized, the IRS will contact the representative to schedule appointments and provide the lists of required documents. However, if the representative is not available, does not respond to repeated requests and does not provide the required documents (other than those that are considered privileged), it is possible that the IRS will bypass the representative and contact you directly. If a representative exhibits the above behavior, it is possible that the matter will be referred to the Office of Professional Responsibility to consider possible disciplinary action.

If you wish to authorize your representative to receive copies of all notices and all communications that the IRS sends to you, check the box below the representative's name and address. Two representatives may receive copies of the notices and communications that the IRS sends to you. Do not check the box if you do not wish to have copies of the notices and communications sent to your representatives.

If you have questions about a tax matter; need help preparing your tax return; or if you want to download publications, forms or instructions for free, go to IRS.gov/Spanish to find resources that can help you right away.

The Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS , for its acronym in English) is an independent organization within the IRS that helps taxpayers and protects their rights as a taxpayer. The duty of TAS is to ensure that each taxpayer is treated fairly, and that you know and understand your rights as per the Taxpayer Bill of Rights.

The Taxpayer Bill of Rights describes ten basic rights that all taxpayers have when dealing with the IRS. The Taxpayer Advocate resources, available in English at TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov, can help you understand what these rights mean to you and how they apply to your situation. These are your rights. Know them; use them.

The Low Income Taxpayer Clinics (LITC) are independent of the IRS. The LITC represent taxpayers whose income is below a certain level and who need to resolve tax problems with the IRS, such as audits, appeals and problems associated with tax collection. In addition, these clinics can provide information about the rights and responsibilities of taxpayers in different languages for those who speak English as a second language. Services are offered at no cost or at a low cost. To locate a clinic near you, go to TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/about/litc, in English, or see Publication 4134(SP), List of Low Income Taxpayer Clinics PDF, in Spanish.

Access IRS.gov/Forms, in English, to download, view or print all forms, instructions and publications you may need. Otherwise, you can download and view tax publications of much interest (including Instructions for Forms 1040 and 1040-SR, in English) in eBook (eBook) format on your mobile devices for free. Or, you can access IRS.gov/OrderForms, in English, to make a request and receive by mail the forms, instructions and publications you need. Your request will be sent within ten (10) business days after we receive your request.

The fastest way to receive a tax refund is to combine electronic filing (e-file) with direct deposit of your refund. When you use direct deposit, your refund is transferred electronically and securely directly to your bank account. Eight out of 10 taxpayers use direct deposit to receive their refunds. The IRS issues most refunds in less than 21 days.

Due to changes in the legislation, the IRS cannot issue refunds prior to mid-February of the year for returns where the earned income credit (EIC) or the additional child tax credit (ACTC) were claimed properly. This delay applies to the refund in its entirety, not just the portion associated with these credits.

The fastest way to get a transcript of your tax return is to go to IRS.gov/Transcripts and click on Spanish. Then, click on Get a transcript online or Get a transcript by mail to order a copy of your transcript. If you prefer, you can: Request your transcript by calling 800-908-9946. Send Form 4506-T (in English) or Form 4506T-EZ (SP) (both available at IRS.gov).
